dOs3vl9Dq50JjoIlwph4PA.text: This is one of our favorite places to eat on the strip.  As a part-time residence in Vegas, we eat out all the time & do come here about 1-2 times per week.  Everything on the menu is good & the prices are fair for being located inside the Venetian.  They are conveniently open til 3 am; so it is perfect for late night eating.  My personal favorites are the pai goo noodle, the beef stew noodle & the Foo Kiem Shrimp, Calamari, Glassy and Rice Noodle dish.  The chicken wings & siu mai are also very tasty.  We have been eating here for many years & the service is very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pai goo noodle soup.

nYpaiMoB5120_sJUAJuayg.text: Love love love noodle Asia. Specially at 3AM after gambling and a bit drunk. No wait, delicious food, Friendly and quick service and best part is affordable price. Been here in a few occasions and it's been very consistent. My favorites are spicy noodle and Shanghai rice cakes. Yummmmm

uQw8NJ8adX_2pGr_5UvuXg.text: The dinner was is so tasty!!!  Everything was wonderful! courteous staff, delicious food, large portions, all brought very quickly.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wQU4NOWH7zBPo0IhUNChhQ.text: Came here after a night of clubbing and the soup really hit the spot! We ordered the Szechuan spicy beef noodle soup and it was super flavorful and warm. The spicy level was pretty good - spicy enough to still taste the flavors and enjoy the food. It came with thicker egg noodles that were cooked perfectly - not too hard and not too chewy. Everything was great except they gave a loot of fat in their beef pieces, maybe its because we came at like 1:30am and they ran out of good meat, but there were pieces that were straight up just fat. Its also waaay overpriced for Chinese food. Pho was $18!! Our Szechuan spicy beef noodle soup was on the slightly cheaper side at around $13, cheaper but definitely not worth the price. My friend also got a small cup of hot and sour soup for $6! The food here is good but too expensive.

pjDxVVJv7R28UmAEU8LQmA.text: Lunch--busy place. It is definitely very popular with the Asian crowd in Vegas. I ordered the Pai Goo noodle dish. It was good. I had no complaints--it had a full body flavor that was enhanced by a touch of ginger and the slow cooked, fried pork chop just added to the broth flavor of my meal. The only negative--not spicy at all! It was also disconcerting to be served a noodle dish without any toppings, but I do understand that hoisin sauce, thai basil, bean sprouts, and other condiments could just be a western cultural thing when it comes to noodle soups. My friend ordered the Spicy Ying Nan rice noodle and from what she said, it was spicy!  Overall, the only real negative comment about this restaurant was their rushed service. As soon as we were seated, our waitress came over and asked us what we wanted to order--we had just sat down and didn't even get a chance to look at the menu! Besides that, the water took a long time to be brought to our table as well.

0xj8wG0k2ieo4TAtCphB4w.text: Woahhhhhhh. Service needs some (LOADS) work.  The food itself is pretty good considering its Vegas, the price is very reasonable for being Vegas. It is definitely the place to go. The location is bomb. Food is bomb (when you are slightly inebriated). Service has something to be desired. I realize that they have to deal with drunk people all day and night BUT I WAS SOBER.   My problem is with the service. Not once did someone come to refill our waters. I happened to down my water in the first 5 minutes at the table. YES I was hungover. YES my mouth was like the Sahara desert. Everything was pretty do it ourselves including getting our bill. Had to flag down 2 different people just to get our ONE bill.  This is the part that gets me. When the lady came by with our check she handed it to us then proceeded to STARE US DOWN AND BREATH ON US until we put a card in and returned it to her. UM.. can we please get a minute to ourselves since we had to give you 10 minutes to even get this to us? Life isn't always fair I guess. Then the lady returned WITHOUT the credit card we had put in it but with somebody else's signed receipt. The only thing that could make the service worse at this point was if she started eating off of our plates.   I'm glad the service was nonexistent when we needed it but the minute we wanted to pay everyone was at our table, not always with the right checks but at our table nonetheless. That really sealed the deal. Glad you took the time out to make us so uncomfortable and unwanted so I could reflect it in your tip.   BTW. I'M STILL WAITING FOR MY WATER TO BE REFILLED, even after you stood at our table for a full 5 minutes. Glad you wanted me to die from my MSG induced coma!

RiRwfVDMSmQ_-Gznj-0pyw.text: Had the egg drop soup which was pretty standard.  I ordered the Singapore Chow Fun which, to my surprise, was great. It was seasoned well, had good flavor from the wok, and was up to par with an authentic Chinese restaurant (NOT take-out).  Though the prices are a little higher given the restaurant's location, it was definitely a great value considering the amount of food you get.  Service was good, except our waiter didn't speak English very well. We were trying to figure out what on the menu was vegetarian-friendly, but the term "vegetarian" is very loosely interpreted by Chinese people. Should've busted out the Canto!

Or14Eu8FkI3XSlCW7owHLg.text: Located inside The Venetian, Noodle Asia is apparently a very convenient place for people to fulfill their soup craving after a whole night of drinking and dancing, especially Asians.  Like what I just said, we found our way to Noodle Asia after checking-out on Sunday after drinking and dancing til 4am and sleeping for like 2-3 hours.  We didn't expect to get cheap and good China-Town-noodle-soups, but NOodle Asia definitely didn't disappoint us.  They have many different types of Chinese noodle soups, Dim Sum, Appetizers, and other dishes like rice and fried noodles which I didn't look at. We ordered Ha Cao and Xiu Mai from Dim Sum. The Xiu Mai came out pipping hot. It was VERY good. All of us love it very much.  We then waited soooooooo long for the Ha Cao to come out. The Ha Cao was Okay in my opinion. The shrimps inside were very fresh and cooked just perfect; however, the skin outside was a lil over-cooked, so it was kinda powdery and a lil bit mashed. The good Ha Cao skin should be a bit chewy.   We then waited very long again for our noodles to come out. 2 wonton noodle soups for my cousins came out first. And about 5 minutes later, my wonton soup came out. i seriously don't understand why it took them longer to make my wonton soup while mine was exactly like my cousins' wonton noodle soups without the noodles. It didn't make any sense to me. But anyway, the soup was very good. The broth is clear. Wonton seemed to be freshly made. I tried the noodles from my cousin, and they were cooked just right. Very good.   The other 2 girls ordered spicy beef noodle soups. The beef was very tender. Lots of meat also. They like it.   Service meets standard. The place looks clean and modern which is no surprise because it is located in the Venetian :)  This is definitely a good place for soups without going anywhere far. I would recommend Noodle Asia to open 24/7 if they haven't done so because apparently after getting out of XS at 4am, all we think about is a bowl of soup (if you're still awake enough to think)

hy6MeaMiF0AuD7VpsYxhvA.text: Pretty good dim sum. Hot and sour soup was just OK. Pot stickers were pretty good too. Nothing to write home about but WAY WAY better than Zine.(the atmosphere was much better at Zine but I will take food over atmosphere anytime!).

lNyXJap0mW29g5XvupwD-A.text: Decent place for "quick" Chinese food on the strip.  Prices are not cheap but it's the strip and it's in the Venetian so get over it.  The food quality is generally pretty good.  The soup noodles are nicely chewy and definitely worth getting.  The wok-fried noodles are also tasty and crispy.  The stir-fried baby bok choy were delicious.  Some other items weren't so good - the pot stickers were full of holes and the Shanghai rice cakes were swimming in oil.  The worst item was the beef ... way over-tenderized.   Hey Yan-can-cook!  Take it easy on the baking soda next time!

3LEL5GFmkeUQaGYpEny69g.text: GET THE POT STICKERS. Best pot stickers I've ever had, anywhere. Good price range for good food. This really hit the spot when we were in the Venetian and starving but didn't want to spend $50 a pop for dinner. It was also still serving even though it was 11pm. We had a group of 6 and were sat right away, and comfortably. I got the spicy shrimp and pork udon, which was very good. Overall, I wasn't impressed with their soft noodles - they were a bit to thick and not al dente in texture. Tasted fine, but I just prefer a different style. We also got spring rolls, lo mein type dish, and edamame. I'd recommend stopping by if you're looking for something reasonable! Great late-night option.

T2vhrRM92G28QLOX-wJkYw.text: Went there on Labor Day weekend for lunch. Spicy beef noodle is average, soup is ok but noodles taste like low quality packaging stuff. Waitress is cold. No smile or greetings. Just came to us and took out a note, started to write what we said then left. Would never go there for this type of service.

wXMq9DzbIbuGygV26GCHCg.text: This three-star review is not a bad review. We are very happy we went to Noodle Asia - it was cheap, convenient, comfort food, casual, laminated menus...just easy.  Did it blow our minds? No. But we really had a good dinner here after our drive to Vegas.  We started with a BBQ Pork Appetizer which was very good. For my entree I had a cup of Wonton Soup (wasn't that hungry).  Mr R ordered Cha Tsai which were veggies with pork over noodles.  It was a lot of food, fine service, and a really easy spot to grab a bite at the Venetian.

kNrL2TQF0uLzU1URMos5aw.text: I came here with one goal in mind: the Schezuan Beef Noodle Soup.  I am a beef noodle soup, uh, obsessor, let's say. I have had it in different corners of the world and will always order it if it's available. So when I was planning my Vegas trip, I had to do a search for it and wouldn't you know, Noodle Asia popped up all nice and affordable ($14 really is over-priced but for Vegas, it's affordable).  NA's gets the flavor precisely right with just the perfect mixture of soy sauce and chili pepper. Furthermore, the beef is in chunks as it should be and incredibly tender, so you know it's been stewing forever. The noodles were my favorite kind, thick and flat. The only thing missing were the vegetables. Not the pickled garnish but the bok choy (or sometimes spinach). No vegetables included. That makes my healthy voice sad.  The shu mai were quite good, considering we were eating at 1am. And my boyfriend's Dan Dan noodles were spicy, brothy, peanut-y delicious. They did not hold back on the accompaniments. The potstickers were cold and gross. Don't order those.  Yay! I can now put a pin on Las Vegas on my beef noodle soup world map. The pin means "go back here".

Iw-NtY0WeZus9nkyBUYA_w.text: Unfortunately I am one of those Asian that cannot live without noodles for more than 48 hours.  I go to Vegas via plane, it is a short flight from OC so very convenient.  But that means my noodle resources are limited in the strip hotels.  So I pretty much tried all the noodle restaurants on the strip, and I can only sum up with one word - #$%^&.  Yeah, most are that bad!  Overpriced, terrible attitude, small portion, terrible food.  The only exception is this one. They cannot compare to 626 or OC noodle shops but they do have the best quality on the strip.  More importantly, their staff are all very helpful and smiley.  The lady serving us took five minutes to explain most of their popular noodles, that was unheard of.  So even though this place is a little far from my hotel, I always make a point to go there.  Trust me, if you want noodle, and you are limited on the strip, then don't think, this is your only place. But if you have a car, then the options are wide open, think China Town....

7ElBvUc4sYA69CrpcLTXAw.text: Considering the location in The Venetian, on The Strip where everything is grossly overpriced, I think only the most jaded Chinese food super critic could give this place less than 4 stars.  There are VERY FEW places ON THE STRIP in one of the MAJOR HOTELS that isn't a complete rip-off (aside from the Food Court places.)  This is one of those very few.  We had Hot and Sour Soup, Stir Fried Soft Noodles with BBQ Pork, Mu Shu Pork, Chicken Pineapple Fried Rice, Brocolli Beef. Not the best Chinese food I've had, definitely, but solid, good Chinese food.  The beef in the broccoli beef was a bit fatty so I wouldn't recommend that one.  Best of all, portions were large enough for the 3 adults and two teens to share family style and we were stuffed with a little leftovers at the end.  And for The Strip, prices were very reasonable - most in the $13-17 range so with beverages (two of them alcoholic) the bill for the 5 of us was under $100 (not including tip.) Practically unheard of on the strip for in-hotel semi-upscale dining.  Service was good too, although the place was only about 1/3 full when we ate there so YMMV.  The atmosphere of the place is semi-upscale casual and it's in the casino with a nice view of the screens in the sport book through huge glass windows so bonus you can watch the game(s) while eating. One of the better finds I've discovered on the strip.

lwbZKnkGKuMxCMq3k-pAsg.text: We ate here a couple of times while staying at the Palazzo.   The decor and ambiance aren't anything special, but that is not the draw, its the noodles.   My two favorite noodles were the spicy ying ran rice noodle and the XO shrimp lai fen. Both had intense flavors and were probably enough to share.   Stay away from the szechwan beef noodle soup. I think that was really greasy beef, or all gelatinous fat. Just not right.   Service was fast and efficient. It does get pretty busy around lunch so get there early.

Yf6sflJhLnnBRL01trkTag.text: Great food. Awesome location. Service was kind of sub par. I had the mopa tofu and it's the best I've ever had.

oPbrkxYNVuDt7OgYpDJjiQ.text: The manager in the restaurant speak nothing to us and then no smile ,  the food is ok ,the restaurant is clean but a very bad service ,I can't understand how can u open a restaurant like that and say nothing to your costumer

XAfAf5ptDyhhGQjVZBtuJQ.text: 2 stars only because the food was delicious. Otherwise, they would not receive a star for their poor service. As soon as we sat down, we were rudely instructed to rearrange our seating for reasons I'm still not sure of. Then, the waitress taking our order was very short and frankly extremely rude. But that was nothing compared to our server. Instead of asking my 12-year old little cousin to move her glass of water, he rolled his eyes, shook his head and moved it himself. All he had to do was ask. It would've been a very simple request. At the very end, they asked for a tip on top of the gratuity that came with the bill. So in total, it was a really bad experience. All we wanted to do after a long day was to enjoy a nice meal to end it. I understand that it's a really busy restaurant but I also work in customer service and I've never ever treated a customer the way we were treated tonight regardless of the situation. We won't be returning.

J9PdNconAct-9GQFggyAuA.text: If your a noodle liver then this place is for you.  Definitely hands down delicious Noodle soups.  Good luck with picking which noodle to order.  Big portion size and flavor of the soups are delicious. Service is great.  The female manager is really awesome.  She has great customer service that makes you want to come back.  You feel at home in this bustling Restaurant.  They get really busy.

gABrm26HwM8b-LsVITSnsg.text: Pretty decent chinese food for the strip.  It's strip prices for sure, but when you crave crispy Hong Kong style fried seafood noodles this place won't disappoint.  The red oil wontons are a pass, not good.  the beef noodle soup was good as is the beef chow fun.  It'd be great if they were open a little later on the weekends, because coming back from the club at 3am they're already closed.

XS3obTeZ2ccuQBXhNh7kEw.text: After we finished eating, the waitress sent in the bill. I didn't check the detail, and gave her my credit card. A minute later she came back with the slip for me to sign. Everything seemed normal so far. But then friends were having a conversation at the table at the time, so I didn't sign it right away. As I took my time to take a look at the bill before I signed, the waitress immediately came and told me, "No worries. You don't have to sign. It's been taken care of." as she tried to take the slip away from me. Turns out, she already faked the tip in writings on the slip, and she charged tips on my card already. I had to demand her to give me back the slip before I removed the tip completely and signed my name. I was going to tip her in the first place but this fraudulent and stealing behavior completely ruined our experience. The food is fine but I will NOT come back again for such low practice!!!

MdAIaNE398TgV-k5RIg4Lg.text: Every time I am genuinely surprised by how legit this place is!  Of course, I've had my share of coming here at 2am on Saturday nights and I usually end up going with my default, the beef noodle soup, but this time around I went for lunch and actually got to try a bunch of different items from the menu.  First the beef noodle soup is good.  It has a good amount of kick and the brisket has been braised long enough so it's tender.  Portion's a little small but it is always satisfying.  If you like rice, YangChow fried rice is the way to gooo.  You can definitely tell that it's been wok-ed in a super hot wok and oil glistens on every rice kernel.  Lots of BBQ pork and diced veggies.  You can even make it spicy if you request it!  As for other noodles, black pepper beef udon is great if you love peppery flavors.  It's not black pepper sauce that you see from most cafes in LA but actual cracked black pepper.  Shanghai noodles has a little bit of curry powder in it and loaded with shrimp and other goodies.  Of course can't go wrong with the wonton soup either.    For me, I'm just really surprised at how... authentic or as authentic as it can be.  I mean, it sits right next to the casino and the sports book.  Usually spots like these are reserved for a crappy deli or something.  Definitely nice to have something like this when you've had Grand Luxe so many times!  It is a bit overpriced and be prepared to wait around noon, dinner, or late night.  It's not a big place!

D6aJNLe_TcPUYW3mNRYSSA.text: Surprisingly, this is one of the best meals in Vegas (especially for the price).  I love the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup and the potstickers.  And trust me, I wouldn't eat the soup if the meat were gristly (which it is not).

wD9aSu3ZuoFkvzi6yF0LPQ.text: Really good Chinese food.  The duck and pork noodle soup is awesome.  Portions are not that generous so be advised but worth it for Chinese hotel strip food.

YGZFx6uJcIItgqKv9Vwn2Q.text: This place is has surprisingly good chinese food, but it's waaaaayyyyy overpriced.  But I eat here anyway since it's close to TAO and I'm usually way to drunk to stumble any further for food.

IlsgYj5sfrkpY7-yt2wJgQ.text: We had the noodles with bbq pork and duck and the Shanghai rice cakes.    The noodles with pork and duck was very average.  The duck had way too many bones it it and there wasn't enough pork.  The Shanghai rice cakes was very average tasting.  The service was very spotty.  I had to grab my own extra napkins. And the bill was $38.  They should lower the prices due to the poor economy.

HPYuhr6kdOGidlmrZKKS_g.text: Over priced Chinese food.  It's a great place to eat between 12-3 AM.  But other than that time time slot, I don't think I'd pay so much for white-washed Chinese food. Especially considering Panda Express is not that far away.

h8Rd91DH1gkTlIKnNSgweA.text: the food was alright but definitely cost more than it should.  we went for a quick lunch and the service was alright too but the food was not up to par with your typical vegas food.  btw don't get the kim chee, not good.

FulwyWk1aU1rTGUncCkU2g.text: located off the casinos, below tao, in the venetian , through the woods... you will find noodle asia - the noodle house that all your asian friends talk about, and that is how you have validated the quality....  except for this time... Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup - is , eh disappointing to say, but nothing close to all the hype that it has been built up to. its very salty, the noodles seems as though its been hand made (a lot like korean kal gook soo) yes the beef is tender, the soup is sour / salty.  if you really want it to hit the spot, pack yourself some korean cup onoodles and order in some hot water through room service.

M_dwfYj2bQ-fBMoaB0iy8A.text: I had came here for some quick dinner and ordered a beef congee, chinese broccoli, and singapore mei fun. The beef congee was bland. I think they forgot salt. The chinese broccoli did not seem fresh, and the mei fun was ok, but also bland. Overall, service sucked. I didn't know if they wanted me to really feel like I was in China and wanted bad service. The waiter certainly didn't know how to be a waiter. The price was high when I think about the quality of the meal and the quality of the service I received. I would rather go to the one at Mandalay Bay.

_XnkjI9pcaUyBmD7qjjIyQ.text: This is a great place to go after long party night in Vegas and somehow we ended up at Noodle Asia two nights in a row. It's definitely good food after 5 straight hours of dancing and drinking. The prices are a bit high, but the food is actually really authentic. All the dishes are pretty good. The noodle soups, porridge, nian gao and the shrimp xo lai fen are good. The first night we ate there, JH, B and I got there first..ordered our food. Our friend M came by a bit tipsy and cleaned up B's noodle soup. I guess it was pretty darn good to him. The next day, we were walking to Tao through the casino floor, but JH started walking towards Noodle Asia. I guess he really loves it that much! We partied it up at Tao and ended up at Noodle Asia again. Again, good chinese food and the portions are pretty decent. The service is quick too...one thing to note that it closes at 3AM. So, it's open late..but, not vegas-late.

250ivZJAXMD0-RlNmaMAhw.text: I only tried one thing here... the Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup. It was so flavorful and delicious. There was just the right amount of spice in the sauce that gave it a slight tang that put it over the top for me. The noodles themselves were perfect. They weren't too soft or too hard. The only thing I didn't like was having to pay $14 for beef noodle soup.

JKzi409rAxcaFqwxhDCb9Q.text: i first ordered the hk wonton noodle soup because my two friends just kept talking about it... so 3 out of 4 of us ordered that.. however one of my friends wontons were very undercooked  (i only ate one wonton and i guess i was so hungry that i didnt even care to look to see if it was undercooked or not) so then i opened up another wonton and it was pink.. we flagged down what looked to be the manager and she took our noodles back and asked if there was anything else we wanted.. i didnt even like the wonton noodles that much in the first place so i decided to change my order to the curry beef brisket.. i am sOoo glad the wonton came undercooked because i loved the curry noodles!! hahaha i am definitely ordering this next time..

XZWLJCYSkdemWbKKD9UXxA.text: we thought noodles or congee would be a good way to soak up the alcohol after an evening of drinking.  the service here is fast, but the foods is so-so.  i agree w/ bennet a.  overpriced and underflavored.  everything we got was lacking in some flavor, even if the soup looked heavily sauced, there was not much taste.  i got the calamari rice noodle soup, which i thought would come in a clear broth, but it came in a cornstarchy soup w/ egg and green onions.  it was ok but nothing to write home about.

Hh7oJHulZvr_ll0f0TeT3Q.text: very good.  came out here on business with a colleague.  went for dinner and had fried rice and a beef dish.  very good.  so good we went back for lunch the next day before leaving town.  most awesome fried rice.  the chicken noodle dishes are fantastic also.  very good place and i beleive it was tucked away inside the venetian.  when  you are done with this meal walk to the gellato store in the venetian for an 8.00 cone of heaven.  wow.  good stuff all around.

pfU6b4ou-UvYI-2GACIoew.text: food is good, service is ok, speed is way too slow...we had our main entrees first and appetizers came after...if u are looking for a causual dinning, it should work out.

-eLhFfFNPT5fOD3jQxknvQ.text: we ate here for our last day in vegas. everyone was hung over and we needed some soup to make us feel better. i ordered the fire chicken wings which weren't spicy at all. but it wasn't bad. the dim sum was yummy because they had a good amount of shrimp inside. the duck noodle soup thing was ok. the duck was good. hot and sour soup- a bit spicy, too much pepper. and the chrysanthemum iced tea was delish.

JbWyV2C_uqV5e5P2cmUeEQ.text: its over priced, but when youre craving some fried rice (salty fish)at like 3 am oh man it hits the spot....thats all i remember having....thank you venetian for taking my money, but i do love your suites!!!!

JXvdidRtj9YZuu-vnDmOwQ.text: stayed at the venetian for a weekend. im so disapointed i didnt try this earlier in my stay.  came back to the hotel really drunk and hungry, we went to the cruddy pizza joint in the nearby food court.  the night we left though, we decided to try it. awww man the soup here would have definetly hit the spot after a night of drinking. beef noodle soup:  spicy broth, tender beef, good noodles. and its open late! would have really wanted to try more of the menu. we sat at the bar area and watched all the orders go out. next time im in vegas, im coming here late night forget steak and eggs.

JQsfackgRJuPx3MolIA1QQ.text: I went here twice during a recent visit to Vegas.  I plan to return.  The first time I had the Shanghai Noodles.  They were very good and overall tasted a lot like home cooking --- nicely sliced cabbage and lots of black mushroom.  Just a little more chicken and maybe a little less oil, and I would call the dish excellent.  The second time, I had the Szechuan Beef Noodles; it usually doesn't come with any vegetables, so I asked for some to be added -- $2 extra.  The noodles had a nice, fresh texture.  The beef was also very good, tasty chunks of some non-steakhouse cut cooked until even the little bits of embedded tendon were tender.  It was moderately spicy, but only maybe a weak New Mexican medium.  Of course, I could have bit into the little red chilis for more heat.  The soup was just okay --- a noticeable soy sauce taste and not enough beef taste.  The dish was good enough to enjoy, but next time I'll try something else on the menu.  For a moderately priced Chinese restaurant at a hotel on the Strip, this place is very good.

YsUqMYYWbj5Jk1rZQRc2HQ.text: I have eaten at Noodle Asia probably over 20 times.  I have had everything from the shanghai style rice cake and noodle, beef chow fun, beef szechuan noodle soup (Mama Wu's special), spicy cucumber, jelly fish, seafood curry noodles,  and at least three of the fried rice dishes.  This is my favorite noodle place in Vegas and is one that I usually go to at least 2-3 times when I'm out there.  Its open from the 10am till 3am so you can get your favorite chinese food whenever you want.  The line is usually long, however, they do have a carry out.  The people that work there are pretty much the same people for the at least the past three years or so.  The service is excellent and they know what they are doing.  Whenever someone asks for good chinese food, I always recommend Noodle Asia.  The dishes lean more on the real chinese dishes.  Which means you won't find dishes like general tso's chicken or sesame beef on the menu.  However, it should be a must-try if you are serious about food.  Can get slighly oily at times but that should be expected.  Oh, did I say the portions are large?  Slightly more expensive than say chinese off the street but well worth it for a noodle house in a great hotel next to the sportsbook.

sjTzWN51FqSIvlSdtZO5Xw.text: We liked Noodle Asia because of the food, price, and atmosphere.  We found the restaurant after walking around for a long time just to find a restaurant for dinner.  This is a pain when you are hungry.  We went there on a weekday night and it was completely full. Meals at many restaurants were over-priced in LV, so Noodle Asia is my new favorite.  I liked my fried noodle with pork and vegetables.  Their service was fast and we were happy.

J12xQtUFqwtLaf7ZEZjgQw.text: When we were here working CES back in January, we asked our associates from China where they'd been eating while they were here:   "Noodle Asia."  "Really? Chinese food? Didn't want to try anything else?"  "Noodle Asia's good."  That about sums it up. It's the only Chinese I've had on the Strip that actually caters to Asians and doesn't orange chicken-up or gourmet bland-out the food. In 626 it might have to work a little harder, but in Vegas it hits the spot when you want a Chinese restaurant meal. Both noodle dishes were excellent, the Buddha Feast (veggie) Pan-Toasted and the Combo Stir-Fried Soft. BBQ Pork was tender, spring rolls crisp, fried rice clean.

NUz-Ut-E445WWBVzvvIEkw.text: I think this place is super underrated. We came here late one night at around 130 am and had a great experience. The food was pretty authentic for Asian food on the strip and it was delicious. They even had fresh coconut juice! Service was pretty good as well, fast and friendly.   We ordered some Dim Sum items, Braised Beef Noodle Soup, and Fried Rice. It was all tasty and very affordable. For the reviews that say it's too pricey here... I disagree. Its hard to find Asian food on the strip this authentic and affordable. They also give you hella big portions!   Delicious, authentic, affordable and opened late? Can't beat that.

Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Braised beef noodle soup

-U9pR-kRmnGoeTi1wm-CXg.text: Noodle Asia was my Vegas hero. After blacking out at a pool club and waking up at midnight with a hangover that I can't believe, we were starving and in need of sustenance. Noodle Asia was there for us   While I was still too hungover at the restaurant to eat, I cannot express the excitement I had when I ate those leftovers later that evening. Thank you Noodle Asia.   We went back to Vegas a couple years later and couldn't find Noodle Asia. I believe that it only appears when it's truly needed.

DNMsDMF__m_ZisOOzjW7Rw.text: Greasy overcooked noodles and dim sum that insult how good this Chinese delicacy can be. If you are really hungry and in the mood for Chinese food you be better off if you looked elsewhere, but if you don't want to leave the Venetian, don't say I didn't warn you.

ZdELS93FY7UhJHffKnwfjg.text: Busy during 2pm. We came here for late lunch and waited 10 mins  for table.  Food: porridge with pork and preserved egg- this is soo good! seafood fried rice- less salty so its good pork stir-fried rice noodle- too salty beef tendon noodle soup- too salty  Prices are more expensive than normal chinese resaurants, but its expected from a hotel restaurant. Service was ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. beef tendon noodle soup, porridge with pork and perserved egg, pork stir-fried rice noodles

68IldXWJ4FsCvGD-aM2ZNw.text: 3.5 stars.  Portions were very generous, but pretty pricey for Chinese... Oh Vegas!  I was tempted to order the $20 bowl of pho that ppl were raving about but couldn't convince myself it would be worth $20...   Went w the Yunnan noodle soup - so glad I did!!  Very flavorful - spicy, garlicky the and fishballs were cooked perfectly... However, msg overload as it was way too salty and I drank several cups of tea and water during my meal.   Don't waste your time or $ on the pork and duck egg congee... Meh.  My gf ordered one of the chicken noodle soups and it was uber plain, don't recommend that either.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yunnan noodle soup w fishballs!!  Must order if you love some spice and garlic in your life.

eVyAJgQYiFsY30KO9lO4Pw.text: This place is BOMB... Whether you are drunk, hungover, or sober... (I've been all three and still enjoy the food here).  I get extremely excited when my friends want to come eat here during a Vegas trip.  They also serve a great Vietnamese iced coffee, Thai iced tea, and they have fresh coconuts too.  You cannot go wrong with their noodle soups.  I think this place is known for their wonton soup but I like them all.  I had the bbq pork and roasted duck egg noodle soup and I was scared that the soup would de-flavor my bbq pork but it did not.  I love roast duck and BBQ pork and was surprised that I could find both of my favorite meats inside of a soup, and I LOVE soups!!   The congee is also cooked to a good consistency and you can taste a hint of ginger in each bite, and I normally don't even like ginger.  The tea eggs were also very yummy  We tried the orange chicken just for the heck of it but it was wonderful, crispy and flavored very well!    Expect each entree to be a little pricey, but what do you expect when you're eating comfortably in your hotel.  Even though this place is pricey, they sure do their best to make it worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Example of prices

DI4QaYdVny1CBgw0yRcvbg.text: I wish I had taken a picture...the szechuan beef noodle soup was so delicious. The depth of flavor was amazing. Definitely one of the top 5 bowls of noodle soup I've had!! Service was great on top of it. Worth standing in line.

w3R93OWa61VhgslfOJqB2A.text: Spicy beef noodle soup!!!  They serve dim sum, but we came solely for the soup after a long night of fist pumping. Service isn't too warm and friendly, but they're prompt. The beef noodle soup comes out piping hot, and the broth has just the perfect amount of spice. The chunks of beef are soft and exude flavor, and the noodles are great. LOVED it!! It's also perfect for hangovers... just saying. Definitely want to make this one of our stops on our many Vegas excursions.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy beef noodle soup

Zmx90OKb3adLSjFdggXNfA.text: In Las Vegas and hungry?  Go here!   It's located on the gaming floor by the sports book and it was fantastic.  This place was a recommendation from a good friend who goes here every time he's in Vegas and I am glad he was spot on.  Decor was very authentic, clean and modern.  All the waitstaff were very friendly and all spoke English fairly well.  The menu is vast and there were so many items we wanted to try we all ordered a dish to share.  BLACK PEPPERED BEEF UDON MOO SHU PORK MIXED SEAFOOD PAN-TOASTED NOODLES POT STICKERS BBQ CHICKEN WINGS (was served cold - not sure why) CHASHIU BBQ PORK (was served cold - not sure why) WON TON SOUP  Everything was hot and delish!  I think I had the best pot stickers ever there!  The pan friend noodles with a creamy sauce was also a favorite of mine.   Noodle Asia goes on my list of places to visit again!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I don&#39;t remember ...
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pot Sticker
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. BBQ chicken

v8XKixhZ7DyWlUqg0R8Icw.text: This place is delicious! I asked a poker dealer how this place was and he said it was ok? (He wasn't Asian) I gave it a try and it's the real deal! I return to the poker table and a player asked how I liked it and I said it's excellent! He responds this place is crap. I asked what he thought was good Chinese food and he responded pandas didn't talk to him the rest of the night!

NQ_kbHYSbbzKN8DpEyCy8A.text: I think some people take this place for granted, but when you come from a place like Portland OR where there is little authentic Chinese food - and Hong Kong food to be exact - this place is golden. I had the wonton noodles and brings me back to the flavors I grew up with. Also great Cantonese BBQ dishes as well. Priced somewhat reasonably for Vegas standards.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hong Kong wonton noodle

Vp0neA0ry_W3Y3Q2JDG7Jg.text: We been coming here for 10yrs. John usually takes care of us but now his gone. Staff are still friendly. I would recommend beef chow fun, Chinese sausage with egg white fried rice, and spicy yin-yang noodle soup with egg noodles.

xQ--nxNCnRMLTULIRC2F2g.text: As Terry K told me, "don't go looking for Asian food on the Strip, go Spring Mtn", but yep we hard head!  But this place, we really like.  Our usual over order of mix fried rice, beef udon stir fry, Won ton soup, Har gau and spring rolls.  Only the spring rolls were mediocre, but everything else tasted really good.  So yep five star for me for finding good Chinese food in a casino.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Z9bGgfbOTSwGKi2R7TyAeQ.text: If you can't eat gluten, I'd avoid this place (in the same way you avoid gluten). I incorrectly assumed I could get a decent gluten-free meal here. Usual Asian cuisine is a good road to go down to get GF food.   Of their unbelievably limited selection of GF items, I chose the Broccoli and Chicken because I am a moron. It was literally the blandest meal I have ever eaten. Almost entirely devoid of spice, the chicken had a boiled unpleasant texture. The broccoli was lazily steamed. I ate it anyway because it was late and I didn't have time to find another place. Gross. At least it was healthy. 1 star for that. I was too demoralized to send it back. I just sat there and ate it like a loser. Pathetic. Now I hate myself.  Maybe their breaded deep fried gluten food is yummy.   The waitress was nice. That gets them a star.  Changing my review to 1 star because I was hungry 20 minutes later and had eat a second meal.

ZfT8tt90bXwIePHeqeUXXg.text: Worst noodle soups you'll ever find in Vegas. Pretty much they serve you hot water with your choice of noodles. No flavor in the broth. Absolute disappointment.

C0JF-gSJ76gUsU8fY-R_jw.text: Now where do I begin? This is the worst restaurant I've been to! If there was just a single positive aspect to this place, I wouldn't complain as much. Firstly, our server (won't mention name) was VERY rude.  She would not give us enough time to even look at the menu and kept coming back as if she was trying to rush us out. The food was terrible. Ordered Shrimp Fried Rice and asked them to make it spicy and make sure to add veggies. That came out with no flavor and an additional $4 for "extra" veggies - which would have been just had there been actual extra veggies. Also ordered Kung Pao Chicken, again asked for spicy, and it came in some sticky sweet sauce and tasted absolutely awful. So overall, meal was garbage. Service was garbage. Upon questioning the additional charge, the same server VERY rudely explained to us that it's for the rice. We said we didn't care about the charge, we'll pay it because we wanted to gtfo.  I do not recommend this place to anyone.

1fUzxERF2iN135g4eGmAJg.text: My friend and I found this place on Yelp. We were searching for an Asian place that served soupy dishes to get to go. This was the only one we found at the Venetian.  We came to the podium entrance to put in our to go orders. The waitress did give suggestions on what to order if we liked spicy dishes, wanted to know popular dishes, etc. She also let us know that it would take 30 minutes for our order, but we decided to wait for it because we wanted some soup! I ordered the won ton noodle soup and swapped the noodles for vermicelli noodles. I believe the total was about $12. When I got my dish, I didn't think it was worth $12 to be honest but then I guess it's food on the Strip so it's overpriced lol. The wontons were made of shrimp and pork I believe. The noodles were so soggy and there was barely any broth because our to go food was just sitting at the counter and not given to us when it was ready. I had to check with the waitress to see when it would be done for her to realize it had been sitting there. I'm not sure if I'd come back.

2f5qHRA3VuKWqbMmcpTc-A.text: Very good food. Not quite to the level of a restaurant that I would fantasize about while twiddling my thumbs in my cubicle, but solid food, for a reasonable price, given that it is inside the Venetian hotel

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

aRcbu2kxwUYaZzGwbBDjqw.text: I wanted to love this restaurant, I really did. I was big time craving some authentic noodles and I had looked forward to it all day.   To start, it wasn't awful. It was clean and there was a nice view to the mostly open kitchen and woks. The service was decent, a little slow, but I've come to expect that anywhere when I'm a party of 1 sitting alone.   I ordered crab rangoons and the Szechuan beef noodle soup bowl. The rangoons were very good. I watched them come out of the fryer so they were definitely fresh.  Imitation crab as almost all are, but there was plenty of it as well as smooth cream cheese and chives. The dipping sauce was also good. The noodle bowl LOOKED really good. It had a pungent smell, overwhelming with Chinese 5 spice. The noodles were cooked perfectly, but the beef and broth tasted not at all fresh.

esCi1r9XHa8jCXdF04PySw.text: Delicious meals. Haven't had something I didn't like at this place. Ambiance is bright and modern. Efficient staff and service is good. A nice little gem in Vegas. Recommend you try it out.

RIBFCIUWylY_dGzyILJBKw.text: I once again found myself with a tuff decision; do I do the sad buffet for one or......I passed Cesar's. Got a gin and club soda near the fountain. Passed through the Venetian shops. By now it's 130. My drink is kicking in. I make it to the Palazzo. Decide to go back to Venetian. Start with the Lychee sake. It's OK, but honestly I'd pass. The shrimp dumplings were delicious however . Huge pieces of shrimp. The beef with rice noodles was equally good. The dish was full of tender pieces of beef and the noodles.... each one kissed by the pan. Service is fast and attentive. The nails approve! Hours are wonderful as well. 11am to 3 am. Um Kay!

sZRlLSuXe2sfFN2sX4rEdw.text: This is a decent serviceable Chinese place. No sense of customer service as a waitress never came over and we eventually asked a busboy to get someone to help us. Decent food, but think we can all do better.

9kMiSxL0J2Cynl8LMtaxzw.text: I simply loved their chicken fried rice , simple yet delicious will visit again when in Vegas ! There is long wait time though but it's worth the wait as I'm a huge fried rice fan! Though the Wait time was longer but the order was very quick :)

cCh7NboU6r7fM_3p6k-fDg.text: Great food! Recommend the potstickers for a gummy meaty app, and Dan Dan noodles. Really nice service and super reasonable prices for strip restaurants

F_Ig1pJdkGzGjZkyKuQEnA.text: Legit Asian Noodles on the strip?  No need to drive to China town.  Just come to the Venetian.  The line was out the door with people who know the hidden secret.  It's a little pricey but it's worth it!   Lots of big shrimp in all the dishes.   Great service - in a legit Chinese place that means lots of hustling about, maybe not the chatting and smiles.   We are definitely going to become one of our regular spots.

IQPxIF4GGnNp-G9N0pcqTQ.text: This place is excellent.  We got 4 dishes and we devoured them all. Wonton Noodles are excellent.  Pricey, but relative to other options adjacent, it's a real deal and reasonable.  Will definitely come again.

NGllVnQv32CLTq8UgbPF1g.text: This restaurant located in the casino, but the restaurant is not as loud as the casino outside. They have a nice environment, the menu has both Chinese and English, and the staffs are very nice. However, when I asked them some food suggestion, they told me all of the food that I asked are good, but the True was they are just OK. Also, when I ordered them in Chinese, they took the order wrong, so this kinda disappointed me. The price is ok but not cheap (maybe only for the ppl who win the gambling lol), dont think will come back and try again.

SeTd75-inLB3sCKqXJVWug.text: WATCH OUT!  We were excited to try this place. The food menu and aroma made it looked like a good place for some authentic food. But then it was too authentic. We ordered the Chinese broccoli and as I was chewing on me green piece, I hear a gasp continue with a gag and spit.   I looked over in my lady plate and asked what's wrong!? She replied in shock, "I think it's a caterpillar" I was in disbelief and replied "no way" maybe it's just and old dried up leaf"   I looked closed and it had legs, I immediately Raise my hand and called the waitress over.  I see the look in her face as soon as she realize what it was.  All they can do was apologize and asked me if I wanted to a new dish?   No thank you. Don't want to eat out of the same garden of boiled insects . She counter offer with edame  Are you kidding?!?! We didn't finish our food . Just paid and left . Went to grab some pizza and beer....

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Pwn5OUPVo1tm7xVZFYpclg.text: Of course I had noodles! It's a nice quick bite. The noodles were massive and pretty good. I liked the generous amount of veggies. Service was quick and friendly. A tad pricey ($20 for a plate) but standard for vegas fast food. It's a decent place to grab a quick bite for lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Veggie fried rice
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodles (not a fan of the crispy noodles) lots of veggies

Sw57zvLSYIx2ePHEiSv5zg.text: Do not go there and save yourself. We started with dumplings. Not much variety. They were ok. As soon as we started eating the entree we suddenly felt very full and could not eat much. After that I felt uneasy for the rest of the evening. Food has too much salt or too much sugar. Wine is BAD.

HR7uCzb_QiREsJLclPLM6Q.text: Only come here if your dying from starvation even then I would consider death first. No service at all after ordering food. Food is tasteless and full of msg. The only thing I can recommend is the water. So if your dying of thirst this place has you covered.

ksj6KMQ5b0wkCIeC1nEvTA.text: Really good food. If u like Peking duck, make sure u order it, in the appetizer category, with a very good volume, one of the best I have had.  Other foods are a bit pricy, that's why I gave 4stars. But really taste great.

flY-PThCxa9Ipi6c0LCnjA.text: The food, especially, the noodles are fabulous! The service is decent but it can get very busy. It's in the Venetian Casino, right next to the sports booking. You can watch sports and slurp noodles. Watch out for the hot meals, they are spicy.

7OCNpdVJ11lPZnzuHUZJ6Q.text: The food was just ok.  Service was good with attentive staffs. I had Cha Tsai noodle and it's not good.  Soup is quite bland. Disappointed as it's a noodle house.  Other family members had different type of fried rice and those are pretty good.  While I only give it three stars, I will give it another chance when I visit Vegas next time.

_IDP07YKMaEiLG-s-UGHxw.text: Authentic! My husband is half Chinese and this restaurant reminds me of his grandmas cooking, especially the soy chicken/duck. Unfortunately, they were out of the soy chicken but my husband loved the duck. The sauce that comes with it was the perfect combination of tangy, sweet and spicy. We also ordered the spicy cucumbers which were good but I have had better. I prefer a little more of a vinegar based sauce on mine. For dinner I ordered the beef noodle soup and it was delicious! The broth has such an amazing hearty beef flavor. The noodles were also perfection. I ordered mine extra spicy and it was the perfect amount of heat for me! Will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

37Viih4ePPLGWIjH3hpCcw.text: Not bad actually, especially for a place like in a casino. I liked all the dim sum items we tried and the service was good too...which I don't usually expect at places like this.

t0wuaht-5-3p_9oQGLxAeQ.text: After getting seated we waited around 10 minutes just to have our water be served. The servers are kind and the food is reasonably priced for their delicious food. I ordered the Cantonese beef and Stir Fry Chicken and both were so delicious. I would come again and order those two entrees.

KltQ8OX00UG7-z874-fCVw.text: Can't go to Vegas without going to a good noodle restaurant. My favorite is the one located inside the Bellagio, but got good recommendations about the Noodles Asia located inside the Venetian.   So there we went.  Awesome food.  Portions are huge. Me and my companion enjoyed every bit of our meals.  Service can be a bit slow because it gets crowded. But be patient and you will be rewarded.  Prices are very reasonable.

tGHoK_1LrS2YY_sY-q7WCg.text: They had good dim sums and decent portion on all food. Their pan fried chive dumpling with juicy pork dumplings were awesome. The place doesn't have any reservations but the wait is not that much given it's Vegas

mg4SvWsiIqL2vL5i89C1Zw.text: The Vegetable Fried Rice and Shrimp Noodles are amazingly good, and the portions are large. The miso soup was flavorful, and the vegetable rolls were  crunchy and packed with vegetables. Service was fast, with zero wait time.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso with Enoki Mushroom Soup

jCvX2c6pG0hfd11dJgs9KQ.text: I was STARVING when I came here and even though the quality of the food and service was kind of blah, I'm giving it a star higher than I probably should.   At lunch, there was about a 15 minute wait around 2 pm on a Friday afternoon...I stayed at the Bellagio and wanted something sit-down but not too fancy and this seemed to fit my description.  When we were finally seated, our server was plain rude. I know she was busy and in a hurry but she was pretty nasty. She was very impatient, snappy, and didn't really provide the greatest service all around.  We ordered the soy-beef noodles and Mandarin Chow Mein - I liked the chow mein much better than the soy-beef noodles. Maybe I don't really like soy but I didn't love the flavor of these. It was very unusual for chinese food (to me) and I wasn't crazy about it. Mine was much better although very generic and Americanized. It was tasty - but not of super high-caliber quality. The food was definitely filling and the portions were big - we were hoping to take this back to our room but unfortunately the Bellagio did not have a fridge in our room to store our leftovers.   I can't recall the final price of our lunch but remember thinking it was pretty expensive for what it was. If you're looking for something other than bar food, I MIGHT recommend it if you can't find anywhere else to go. And with the millions of options on the strip, I'm sure you could find a better place than this.

vh-UANCeqh-U6g0ye6bG_g.text: Not good.   Service was sloooooowwwwwwww. I mean, it wasn't even busy crowded. Waiter seemed like he forgot our table of 4's ordered appetizer of shu mai, and to close out the bill.   Shu mai was a solid 3, at best. Everything was tasteless.   Other server kept insisting on giving ALL our ordered hot steaming pho, congee, noodle soups on one person to hand out to everyone. I mean, come on?! What kind of service is this?   Only positive thing about this place is that they're open at 3am.  HUGE disappointment -_-

HnEmiPKcyin825wzd0aUyw.text: Maybe people hyped this place up too much for me because I was expecting FANTASTIC flavors and for around $14 bucks a bowl, it better be worth it.  Especially staying at Venetian and every night (morning) I would make it back to the hotel I wanted soup and we would keep missing Noodle Asia by an hour :/  Hungover, it should taste even better but it did not.  Ordered the beef noodle soup- I mean, afterall it is Mama Wu's specialty.  It came out piping hot which was great but then after the temperature subsided the unpleasant saltiness slapped me in the face.  That's all I could taste after that.  Four of us ordered that and felt the same way.

JXhUOY1OCx2_KzFN7f13rA.text: This was our last meal before heading out to the airport.  We wanted something cheap...or at least what we thought was cheap.  Lunch ended up costing us $32 w/ tip and only waters for bevs.  My friend and I ordered the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup and Dan Dan Noodles.  The beef noodles soup was perfect for my friend who was nursing a cold.  It was a great balance of spiciness, heat, and flavor.  The meat was pretty good too, just kinda fatty.  I expected more from the Dan Dan Noodles.  It was just a cold monotonous flavor of peanut butter and minced meat. Guess, I'll have to try different items next time I'm in The Venetian and wanna give this a try.

H8WgdNEYIjunwXtgv_AJvg.text: The restaurant was busy but we didn't have to wait at 7:00pm.  The food came out less than five minutes after we ordered.  Our meal included:  -One cup of Won Ton soup: it came with four pieces of plump shrimp and pork filing with two small bok choys. Although the broth was just salty enough, I believed that MSG was used based on the aftertaste.  -Cantonese curry beef stew: The portion was big. The beef was tender. The gravy with green and red peppers was quite spicy.    The prices were reasonable by Las Vegas Strip standards. Overall, the food was average.

_r1doaibfUfhpz-RvNlu_Q.text: I asked if they would alter a noodle dish to make it vegetarian and they agreed. When the food arrived it still contained meat so I brought this to their attention, but I never complained. As soon as my dish went back to the kitchen the manager came out and apologized. She assured me they would make it fresh just the way I wanted and she'd take it off my bill. Above and beyond, by far.

hm5SREgpx0HVRhhZ5RE_DA.text: Based on what you are getting for the price, it's definitely not worth it, but due to the limited selection of Asian cuisine in Las Vegas, this will do...for now.  At the convenience of being inside Venetian, I really can't complain, but $13 for a bowl of beef porridge is a little ridiculous. I must admit, from the menu items I have tried, they are all pretty decent except for the soup, especially the Egg Flower Soup. The soup tasted worse than the imitation Egg Flower Soup at a Chinese buffet. I was a big fan of the Sze-Chuan Beef Noodle and the Ba Bao noodles though, just not the price tag. But again, we are in Vegas, so I can't really complain.   For the most part, Noodle Asia satisfies my craving for Asian noodles while in Vegas, especially after a night of partying, and I am thankful for it's existence.

Erk2t5bPMoi_LywOInYQ2w.text: Friendly service, and fair food price for Las Vegas. Food tastes really not that great, you can get better tasting food in Chinatown. We ordered 4 things, 1 thing was sold out and another thing never made it to our table.

t2cez09XFFhNT6PTxd0wSA.text: 3.5 Stars. Noodle Asia is located at the Venetian Hotel, close to the Race & Sports Book. We ordered the Mongolian Beef & Orange Chicken. The atmosphere and staff were nice.  However, the rice dishes were no better than Panda Express. We didn't like the quality of meat in the Orange Chicken. Mongolian Beef was decent but seemed to have more onions than meat. Each menu item with tax was around $20. Next time we might try their soup or noodle dishes instead.

5VaLNSS5NX5zapzByqEzcA.text: Consistently good Asian noodles cooked up fresh and delicious. Fast service and a choice for nearly anyone's taste  My personal choices are red won ton for appetizer. And Singapore Mei fen for main course.

GywhtGmU0dC_0MVQdiPBLw.text: Food was decent but service was absolutely awful. When your entree comes before the soup and appetizers....that's a problem. Seems the waiter didn't care when it was brought to his attention.

rYJxoFcCjCqAKG9VXxcpRw.text: You'll get good service if you're Chinese.  We were seated and ordered waters and various drinks.  After 5 minutes, we flagged down a waitress to ask about our water.  After another 5 minutes, we got the hostess' attention.  It still took another 5 minutes before the drinks appeared.  15 minutes for water?  That's bad.  We then ordered our food.  Another 15 minutes go by.  Two separate groups of Chinese guests are seated in the interim (including one group of 12+). They order and receive their all of their food before anything of ours comes out.  They are literally being served at light speed.  We are still sitting at an empty table.  That's very bad.  So we finally get our food after about 35 minutes of waiting and watching everyone around us, including those who came afterwards, get their food first.  I can't speak for what anyone else ordered, but the orange chicken ($19) was atrocious.  Watery, lukewarm, and not flavorful at all.  The "jasmine rice" was badly overcooked white rice.  The spring rolls were terrible.  If the food were just mediocre and overpriced, I'd give the place 2 or 3 stars for convenience alone (it's in the middle of the casino) but I really was not impressed with how horrible the service was.  It wasn't busy or late at night; there were no extraneous circumstances.  They just decided that they would serve everyone else (who just so happened to be Chinese) first, and keep us waiting.    So now, I will decide to never eat here again.

Vwh_a15w8i2c1hkHYJbthw.text: Great late night eat at Asian Noodle. I was craving soup, and the cup of Shrimp Won Ton Soup was just right! My boyfriend had the chicken fried rice and I also ordered the chicken lettuce wraps. It wasn't too oily,  which is expected with Chinese food, and since we ate light that night, we had enough for leftovers. The leftovers made a nice yummy quick meal the following day.

tUiC5FjCH0PxNZKLODK5PQ.text: Whatever you do DO NOT EAT HERE!! My husband and I ate here on 2/5/17 after the Super Bowl and we both got the worst food poisoning of our lives. We both ordered dim sum for appetizers and the Wonton Noodle for our main meal. To be fair I think it was the dim sum not the noodles that got us sick, but regardless I would advise against ever eating here. We were supposed to fly out the following day but we got so sick that we had to reschedule our flights for the next day and had to stay an additional day at the Venetian costing us over $400 total. In case you don't believe me we even filed a formal complaint with the hotel for future records. If I could give this place zero stars I would. BEWARE OF THIS PLACE!! STAY AWAY!!

hxMmzjLa1MVX1u6m9GrTlw.text: By looking at the pics of my Mom chowing down on her delectable Chinese cuisine, you can imagine my Mom didn't talk too much!  HAH!  Please take a peek at the pics I took with my Nokia 6260 camera phone of my Mom and Noodle Asia's cuisine.

ZwW2qJS5rURyPQyEYFMy7g.text: Legit Chinese inside a casino in Vegas? What?   Yes, it does exist. It may be pricier than heading to Chinatown, but its IN the strip so if you are just visiting Vegas its a good option.   I'm pretty sure someone on management just hired the people from their favorite Chinese restaurant to run this place because the English was sketchy and the food was legit.   Unfortunately it was a little hard to determine what was actually vegetarian so I just ended up with a very simple noodle dish.. but all my meat eating friends left very happy.

SmFF1TYDuKqDiar3Bq7iKQ.text: Love this place at the Venetian hotel!!!  Szechwan Beef is the bomb...simmered in blend of spices, a mama wu specialty and next to the sport betting to watch all the football games.  I keeping coming back for more even though I stay at the Monte Carlo. lol

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Beef Bowl at the Noodle Asia in Venetian Las Vegas

fw_WNiDjRBxRFWTy2pVNwQ.text: It wasn't the best we've ever had, nor was it the worst we've ever had. Nothing stood out as being above average. Our favorite things there were the kimchi and the chicken wraps, but those are hard to mess up, so thats not saying much. The speed of the servers and the kitchen staff made this place a convenient lunch location during conference days, but other than that, 'meh' is the perfect description for Noodle Asia.

eBKGBfMNHRZESuJcSsHU8g.text: Ok. I just simply gave up and ate here at Panda Express, this chain is majorly placed on every corner and crack on the vegas strip. Everywhere u turned you saw one, just becomes annoying to see so i just gave up and tried it for lunch. Good thing i did cause the food was quite yummy i must admit, thanks for stuffing Panda Express down my throat.

kPFylksH73h5VDzvkz6Ykg.text: Let me just take a quick break from my meal and write this review.  I'm here for CES and my company has a suite in the Venetian. I'm not feeling too well and the weather doesn't make it any better. I was in deep need of soup.  I started to think of where I could possibly walk to on the strip that had noodle soup and luckily enough -- I saw the Venetian map where someone already pulled up the restaurant options, and low and behold: Noodle Asia!   I could not have been anymore happier than in that moment.  Upon arriving, right on their stand was their special for the day "Convention Special" featuring 8 curry fish balls, won ton noodle soup AND Vietnamese coffee.  I was like "ok, now I'm more sold and more in love".  Now about the food: BEST WON TONS I'VE EVER HAD. EVER. Even the noodles were amazing and I'm not usually a fan of yellow noodles. Broth was good too, but as usual I had to add chili paste to it -- only because I love spicy -- it could have been a great soup without it.  I'm a big Vietnamese coffee fan and this I loved too!   Now I don't have much to say about the curry fish balls only because I'm actually not a fan personally of curry fish balls. Curry alone -- I love. Fish balls alone -- I love. But I just can't get the two to go well in my mout together.  Anyways -- great portions. They have a bar so people eating by themselves can be seated quickly. I'm super stuffed.  Now I must leave because I'm done eating and the line is getting long.

YFl2neH18UxPycm-5NLC7w.text: Been here a few times and their dim sum never disappoints. It's like a ritual for us to come here always on the day that we are leaving and partake in the amazing noodles and appetizers. I was just craving the place today - need a Vegas dose soon...

-KqQFL0ToPJzGGZKpNFWRQ.text: I have been coming here several years and have found this place, aside from its location convenience inside Venetian, had always offered pretty good Cantonese noodle dishes.  But, since their renovation a couple of years ago, the quality seemed a bit off.  For starters, my old favorite, red wonton, has consistently been bland, chewy, and sometimes even on the cold side where the wontons are actually lumpy.  Other dishes such as spicy Ying-Nan noodles are inconsistent, ranging from missing ground beef, to scallions, to the chilly.  My latest visit, this past weekend, was a HUGE disappointment.  My Young-Chow fried rice was wet, sticky, lacking the distinct wok flavor this particular dish is known for.  The shrimps also seemed "off", with a squishy bite.  There were literally six diced char siu (I counted).  No scallions, and hardly any presence of eggs.  Most of all, it was just flat and flavorless.   It really is too bad.  This was once my favorite noodle place where I have recommended many friends, colleagues and families whenever they visit Venetian.

azTgU2GX_kM5dur-nmxxGw.text: Service was ok. I had to ask for water a couple of times. Food was tasty. I ordered the beef noodle soup. The noodles were very tasty n so was the broth. The beef was pretty tender too.  If service was better, I'd give the restaurant a 4 star.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0wIu6vYKNEKo8tqQicdC_w.text: Enjoyed my first visit. Cozy restaurant and tasted authentic. Service and food good.  Crab Rangoons 4/5 - very good though the color of filling was different than what I'm use to  Pot Stickers 3.5/5 - crispy, pork dumpling. A bit doughy than I'm use to  Chinese Sausage Fried Rice 4/5 - very tasty and generous portion  Siu Jiu Beef 4/5 - crispy pan fried noodles with beef, peppers, and onions in black bean sauce. Very good.   Want to try the wings, congee, and seafood pan fried noodles next time

KJTN05VX8UVneK1xxfvA_Q.text: We arrived on the run. Literally trying to get fed and go catch the Niners game at 1:25. The line was about a 45 minutes deep and we just didn't have the patience for all that. I tapped the hostess on the shoulder, just as the people in the front of the line turned to look at their Iphones and asked her if we could sit at the empty counter. She must have witnessed the fire in my eyes cause we were seated moments later.   Wontons were solid!! Served in a bowl with a lot A LOT of sauce, they were moist, delicious and were gone in moments.   I ordered up the pan fried noodles and beef and that's my mistake. It appears as though they make noodles in house and I should have order Pho! I saw a few bowls hit the counter for service and knew I made a terrible mistake.  My pan fried noodles and beef were pretty good. The Mongolian Beef, ordered by my bride-to-be was much tastier. She loved my dish, I loved hers. That's a huge plus right there.   For the cost, it's a solid value spot. Not a dive, not fancy pants.   They are right next to the sports book and the entire building is one giant window. So, if you choose a table correctly, you can enjoy some food and a game at the same time.

-TdXyB0tdIQYYJSjby9xyA.text: My husband has visited Noodle Asia for the last 10 years during his annual conference in Vegas. Today, I got to experience his description of "Oooo, it's so good!" noodle shop for the first time. This place is a fairly reasonably priced Cantonese/Chinese quick eats! Everything is done simple, but well. Portions are nice, quality of food is excellent, ingredients are True to its price point. Most importantly, very yummy, unpretentious authentic local street food cooking in the beautiful Venetian Hotel.  Great place for lunch or a quick bite. Not a formal sit down. Happy Eating!

9tENfQA5a99xR_-G6YnLLA.text: Ah Noodle House.  I had such high hopes for you. The pictures of the food looked so good.   The descriptions of the food promised savory asIan goodness. But no. This review is based on the following dishes:  Kung pow chicken, orange chicken, night kitchen fried rice, and stir fry vegetables. Of the list, the orange chicken and vegetables were the best but still average. The fried rice was the most disappointing. The beef was very rare (red color) and flavorless. The dish shows a picture of a chile but there was no flavor. Not spicy at all. The peppers in it looked like jalapenos but tasted like bell pepper. Kung pow was ok only. Very few veggies almost all chicken and peanuts.   I would have been happier at Panda Express.

QAvdO0LAyE1ItUGBFN4inw.text: Came here because I saw on the menu they had some dishes with some Chinese BBQ deli and I was like oh yeah!  There really was not a whole lot of people when I came, so got sat down at a table right away.  The ladies that worked there were very nice.  I decided on getting the bbq pork and roast duck over rice which sticker shocked me at $15.  OUCH!  The food came in 3 minutes.  I am not even joking with you, it literally came out in 3 minutes.  I sent a text out, and the food was there.  Also ordered a Vietnamese Iced coffee.  The food was not impressive.  The roast duck pieces had nothing but skin on them.  Absolutely no meat.  Maybe they saw that I was an Asian guy and they felt that I had enough roast duck in my lifetime and know how it taste like so they are saving it for those that might not have tried it before.  COMPLETELY understand (not really)!  The bbq pork was BRIGHT pinkish/red which almost blinded me.  I think they glazed it intensely, which actually was not too bad.  The rice was eh...rice.  The coffee was not as strong as I'm accustomed to, but was pretty good.  All and all, not worth the 23 dollars total.  Maybe if you look like you've got money, they'll give you the duck with the meat on it though.  Good luck.

YXu_EdbIfZiYl59B_uTDFQ.text: Authentic Chinese Food.  and  both taste good. Good place for people living in Venetian.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3hrKC66xy0pQryXkded-Sg.text: I've been here a couple of times in the past and somehow found myself here again with my group of girls celebrating our friend's bachelorette, lol. It's not that this place is amazing, but they serve decent Asian food...so when a bunch of Asian girls are craving something fast and something Asian, this was the answer to our prayer.

Yo83-WUThgUATBALjaBXsw.text: It's a "OK" place for Chinese food since their price is a bit on the high size for me. But they do have large menu selection so you can always find something for you. I don't quite like the location which is next to slot machines and people do smoke in there. Can be noisy too.

xS0Yv5nOYt6aey5s8ztTgw.text: I have always been skeptical to try new things. Especially when it comes to Asian food. When I was little I would hate to try something that looked disgusting. Even while in the Military, when I was stationed in Okinawa, Japan, I would try only the stuff I was used to and knew.  When I started working as a Technical Sales Engineer that requires traveling to a lot of places and sometimes going to restaurants that aren't really my style. One of them being Asian food. I have learned to adapt to the Asian food that I come across.  When I am traveling to Las Vegas for work there is always one restaurant that I try to make time to visit. Noodle Asia Restaurant is one of my favorite places to eat. Above, is one of the first meals I tried here because again, I was afraid to try anything I wasn't used to. I figured, "How can I go wrong with Kung Pao Chicken?" They serve you a lot of chicken and peanuts. (Food Allergy Folks Beware!)  I have gotten used to eating some of the other items on the menu but Kung Pao Chicken is still one of my favorites.

n_Arwax0o2XGU_cz1nSPCQ.text: The Kimchi is not real Korean kimchi, but it was ok I ordered Sichuan beef noodle soup, it should be spicy but it's nothing~ the noodle is good but I don't like the soup

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VHmdN9mQDQKSN8JpCgijNQ.text: Had the Shrimp Fried Rice. Not good at all. Absolutely bland. It was mushy white rice with boiled soft shrimp. It seemed as if they ran out of all the ingredients that should be in it: salt, pepper, soy sauce, ginger, sesame seed oil, egg, and any type of vegetable (scallions, carrots, peas, bean sprouts). I don't which one, just pick one or two...Even yet, make up your own and add it. I don't care.  It needed something other than shrimp & rice and water to boil it in.

lDu0Zg-ow3nVSZzaabMBgg.text: Surprisingly the most authentic and delicious bowl of Szechuan beef noodles found on the strip or dare I say even say it, Vegas.   Service was super speedy and typically Asian, considering we arrived fifteen minutes till closing. We were seated, served and ready to check out by 3:15am.   Other menu items didn't leave as high of praise from the rest of our party, however the Szechuan beef definitely hit the spot when all you need is a hot bowl of soup to get you back on your feet. Just be prepared to pay double in price plus the cab  fare over.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Sw9UIazZSeVyHbjjrjS8og.text: I ordered the chicken noodles and hot and sour soup.  The food is okay.  I liked that fact that you can see the t.v. thru the big glass windows into the gambling area.  Parts of the restaurant has open windows.  Being that the restaurant is right next to the gambling area you end up smelling cigarette smoke while eating.  If smoke doesn't bother you than you will be ok. I like the Hong Kong Cafe better which is located at The Palazzo.

h9n41gCWIQngPaqnv6B01Q.text: Is it overpriced? Yes.  Is it the best Chinese food I've had? No.  BUT it is the best Chinese food on the strip in Las Vegas and hence the generous 4 stars on Yelp.  Noodle Asia has always hit the spot when I'm in Las Vegas and craving Chinese food.  I only wish they would open a tad bit later to let me wander in drunk fulfilling the craving for a hot bowl of won ton noodle soup.  For those thinking the high review is because of eating under influence that is not True.  I've been here drunk, sober, and hung over and all three circumstances Asia Noodle has always been good to me.  I even try to stay inside the Venetian or Palazzo just so I don't have to go outside and face the elements to get to my beloved Asia Noodle.  Won Ton Noodle Soup (with and without BBQ pork), Night Market Fried Rice, Hot and Sour Soup, and the BBQ Combination Plate are my standard fare here.  On a side note, Asia Noodle recently got a facelift and looks a lot fancier than it did before.  For you sports fan nuts out there, they even have bar seating that faces the Cantor's sports book so you don't have to unglue your eyes from the game while eating.

Azr7rmEgWVsKfF8GhgAXUQ.text: shiu mai was terrible, not hot & lacked any flavor.  Spicy chicken wings were not spicy at all. Servers were unattentive & literally running around like chickens with their heads cut off. I would not recommend. Much better restaurant  (& prices) elsewhere.

3fpWQrY_xTuHdKGs_hd0Pw.text: Service was friendly and fast. Food was pretty terrible and overpriced. Disappointing to say the least.

u_DH2DTpDh3vkdOcEjFXjg.text: Such good noodle soup and dim sum! I asked the waitress for a recommendation and when I said "spicy" she recommended the schezwan beef noodle soup which was amazing!  The pot stickers and spring rolls were also very good.  Definitely will return!

D7mTP6blliS7zwDHj5I2Aw.text: Still really liked the flavor to my Szechuan beef noodle soup with it's hint of spice. My boyfriends pho on the otherhand tasted a bit off but I couldn't pick out what it was. My noodles were different from the first time I had it. I had flat rice noodles last time and this time they were regular noodles. Will definitely be back when I'm back in Vegas :) pretty tasty Asian food for an Americanized area.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pho special
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodle soup

qGOF5WLD2LNViaB_-4PqPQ.text: This is what I expect from a Chinese restaurant nothing over the top but yummy filling food. I went here with 6 people and 5 of us ordered different dishes. Everyone was pleased with their meals and satisfied by the end. I ordered the bbq pork noodle soup and it was great (a little salty) it brought back memories of my local restaurant back home. I would eat here again when I'm in Vegas.  It is fully wheelchair accessible

OHGNJoh9hBnWslNjobjS6Q.text: We like this place. Everything is pretty good and they're open till late. We especially like their Spicy Beef Noodle. If you like Chinese food, you can't go wrong here.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3CtYPZLR4vP7qW4d8FzJDw.text: I was hungry for some authentic Asian food while staying at the very expensive Venetian hotel.  It's hard to find good Asian food at an high end hotel but this place here is pretty good and authentic.  I ordered the bbq pork and chow mein.  It was good and big portions too. I will come again.

anOf3Zg7UERXq95RcUgufg.text: This place really hit the spot. Admittedly, free food always seems to taste better (thanks for the comp, Venetian), but at least the food wasn't too shabby. It was around 11:30pm, and we ordered enough food to serve a family of 4. Shamefully, it was just the wife and myself.   It shouldn't be a surprise that the prices here are sky high, but you just have to take one glance around and realize that the restaurant is inside the Venetian hotel on the Strip. You might do a double-take and see that yes, it's around $10-$13 for porridge, or $10 for wonton soup. Basically, whatever prices you're used to, just multiply by 2 for this place.  We ordered a wide assortment of dishes:  Seafood crispy pan fried noodles Wonton soup Seafood rice porridge Vegetable spring rolls Soy milk  I honestly thought everything was comparable to what I've had at like a Sam Woo cafe or something like that. Just double the price. Just good 'ol Chinese comfort food. Our total bill was $50. Pretty shocking, I know. Would I eat here if the food wasn't comp'd? Not a million years. But it's good know, I have options after a day at the blackjack tables at the Venetian/Palazzo.
