A lovely dish with some onions and peppers and good flavor. They have a large menu and I'd relish the chance to go back and try any number of other dishes that looked appealing.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SC_-GOQLK2qPWkaWoxpi-g.text: Can you even call this Chinese food? This place is an abomination with high prices and mediocre Chinese food. I only came here out of a craving and was incredibly disappointed about everything.  The prices here are SO overpriced. I guess that's what you get for eating at a casino but it was ridiculous. The "combination stir fried noodles" were $16.95!! It just seemed like they threw together some noodles and soy sauce. 6 pieces of shu mai was a whopping $9.95! The service was slow and didn't pay us any attention.   All of the food was very cheap and seemed like they just threw it together or heated it up right there. Definitely not worth the price. There's much better Chinese food out there. Trust me.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. shu mai ($9.95)
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. combination stir fried noodles ($16.95)

CuPcHBC2pm9dVKyCaVTxcg.text: This is my all-time favorite restaurant in all of Las Vegas to get my Singapore noodle craving fulfilled. Being a Vegas resident, I rather not make the trek across town just to eat at restaurants in the casinos, but I will make an exception for Noodle Asia when the craving gets real.  They are located inside of the Venetian on the Strip. It is tucked away in the corner, right next to their Race & Sports Book. The Venetian hosts a variety of conventions throughout the year so beware of looooong lines and wait times when there's a convention in town.   Their Singapore noodles (listed as Singapore Mei Fan on their menu) is very possibly the best I have ever had in any restaurant in North America. I love the atmosphere, being right next to the sports bar during football season and the service, while not seemingly friendly at times, is fast and efficient.  Some people complain about the prices. Yes, it's obviously going to be pricier than your typical Chinatown meal deal, but come on-- what do you expect from a restaurant on the Strip?

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Singapore (Mei Fan) Noodles - stir fried curry flavored rice vermicelli dish w/shrimp, charsui, bell peppers and onions

Gjl6G6ml4lJ3fzSU4nFT6Q.text: The main draw of this place is that it is open late and the food is of acceptable quality, everything else about it would be normally a big pass. My friends and I came here after a clubbing night though so the food was much needed, even if the service was slow.  We ordered the beef chow fun noodles and the duck noodle soup (they ran out of pork so we just had duck noodle). The beef noodles were actually pretty good tasting, though a bit expensive at around $15 for it, but it wasn't like we cared much at this hour.  The duck noodle soup wasn't too bad either. It was pretty standard though, and there was not all that much special about it, but I guess it hit the spot and took care of what it needed to.  Overall if I was staying at the Venetian and desperate for Asian food I'd probably come here out of sheer laziness, but it wouldn't be a place I'd make my way out of to go to.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7Q3LzL15fvNera2-2fOaLA.text: My first meal in Las Vegas got to be noodles!  No, they aren't hand pulled and no it's not super authentic, but it was insanely good.  I wouldn't go with the crispy noodles, I'd go with the soft ones, but the crispy ones are really great for some texture.   The soup is more cost effective if you get a big bowl, so I'd recommend doing that.  One cup isn't enough anyway, that's also perfect to wash down whatever else you get.  They do have bottles of wine which is nice, but there are some killer cocktails as well.  Service was kind and attentive, and everything came out quickly despite it being packed.   It's less expensive than other options in the Venetian, but doesn't skimp on quality.  Definitely a good choice

_YZ1WlYMYcKSJpV7EX__MA.text: We were looking for Pho and came across this place on yelp. It was between Noodle Asia or Beijing Noodles No 9.  We decided to go to Noodle Asia Because of the review and more rates.  This restaurant is located in Venetian.  They are very busy during brunch-Lunch time.  Good service but to busy to call a server.  Pro: Fast preparing the food. Closes at 3AM! Con: to busy to ask for a fork. Advice: Order everything at once, because you won't see your server until your done with your food.  Food Pro: Their Shrimp Dim Sum was amazing. Also recommend Pork & Duck with rice. Con: I cant say this is bad but by demand we ordered their Beef Noodles soup. I really didn't think it was amazing nor tasty. It was actually very salty. It might have been just that day but I didn't think it was great compare to what other Yelpers inputted. also we tired their Milk Bubble tea..... ill say 5/10. We got it as soon as we ordered it, had barely ice in it and wasn't cold.  Overall: Not what I expected it to be but they had some good dish. Their Dim sum is a must for sure.!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp dim sum
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork and duck with rice
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VaRqjx5EijH84GcldQSMQQ.text: This is one of my favorite restaurants in Las Vegas. Food is always good , service is fantastic and the waitress will always come and check on you no matter how busy they are. Throughout my dinner tonight i was asked 3 times. :)   The portion is huge too. Don't be afraid of the price. It's not like that one restaurant in Mandalay Bay.  If you crave for Asian food, this is the place to be!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nAWRW18Yd7b5p6VtzvXDgQ.text: Casual dining restaurants on the Strip are typically: overpriced 20%+, serve decent food and the service is hit or miss...Noodle Asia meets the Strip's A-ok criteria in my book  Noodle Asia Service: When the capacity is about 75% full or less, the service has been consistently good.  Servers will follow up with your drinks and the kitchen will get you your food in a decent time.  Above 75% and you might run into issues as it doesn't appear that they are staffed appropriately.  Also, when a line forms outside the entrance you might want to go somewhere else if you don't want to sit at the counter  Noodle Asia Cuisine:  I've only ordered the noodle soups as I always seem to be on a time constraint when I dine here.  With that, the Szechwan beef is my current favorite.  It's Szechwan spicy were it doesn't burn them mouth but I'll start sweating as I dine. The classic Hong Kong Won Ton soup works if you're not into spicy.  The broth has good and better days but the volume of noodles and beef has always been plentiful  You can find noodle houses up Spring Mountain that offer better quality cuisine for cheaper.  However, if you're confined to the strip Noodle Asia is your best/only option which isn't a bad thing.  Keep your expectations with Noodle Asia (and life in general) realistic, and all can be well.  The location keeps me returning.  Enjoy...! =)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

smxbk4jUiOlsdX983XTpgg.text: Noodle Asia was closed the last time I came in May, and it was finally open this time around. SO GOOD! My friends and I got the beef noodle soup, wontons, dim sum, orange beef and shanghai noodles. Everything was really yummy and it was the type of Chinese food where I didn't leave feeling super heavy after. Great service as well. Will definitely come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

M3YrY2PmdO90Q31pN8_Jaw.text: Food was good. Slightly on the pricier side. However service was prompt They have a lot of selections to choose from. The ambience here is phenomenal as it takes you back to the roots. Would definitely come back if there was more availability of their lunch menu into their dinner menu. Staff was very pleasant to deal with and they even remembered us from last time which is great knowing you are being acknowledged.

HS8z2j_KATNSypJ4Nz8ihA.text: Recently went here on a trip to Vegas. Vegas has endless selection at every price point for any kind of food you desire. I had seen this off to a corner next to the sports book on a previous trip and figured I'd give it a try this time. The service was good everyone was polite. I didn't know what to expect based off the other reviews but it was a 5 star for me. The food came out quickly. The menu had many selections. The food itself was phenomenal, maybe the best noodles or at least top 3 I've ever had. I tried the dan dan noodles they were phenomenal, I also got the dumplings with shrimp which were just as  fantastic. With a drink, noodles, and appetizer my bill came to be about $29 which was fair considering the whole experience of food and service at a sit down place. Highly recommend for a quick noodle stop!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dan Dan Noodles

wKk7XNHz6CRQbkSZy8S1zQ.text: Beautiful rich red exterior will catch your eyes inside the Venetian near the hallway that leads to the Sands Expo.  Of course, going in I had low expectations seeing the reviews of which I do concur.    This place will do the job to satisfy hunger, but not necessarily your quest for great chinese food.  It hit the spot after 8 hours of walking/standing at a convention and I'm sure will do the same for those after long hours of gambling or drinking.    The service was prompt, food delivered fast.  I love open kitchens and you can see the hustle going on here as that wok churns and every cook doing their thang.    Nothing bad to mention here, nothing great either.  Mainly great for being super convenient and fast when you need it.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

IBrR1tomSMAqQB9d5HqkhQ.text: Very good Asian food without breaking the bank... Well, not too much anyway...  On our last night we were looking for something a little simpler than the fancy restaurants that dwell within the depths of every strip casino resort but didn't want to wallow in a buffet or fast food. Noodle Asia was a good choice.  The only problem is finding the place to begin with... Which seems to be a bit of a theme in Vegas... You typically can't get to anything without passing a phalanx of slot machines (sometimes twice if you get turned around.) I'll make this so much easier than it was for us as we went through pretty much all of the Venetian. There is a bridge over Las Vegas Blvd from the Mirage / Treasure Island side that goes directly into the Venetian. Go down the escalator, straight through the sliding glass doors and there it is, right next to the sports book. Bright red. You can't miss it. The worst is over!  The restaurant is open on to the casino so great for people watching... And a decent view of the sports book TV's if you are so inclined (can't hear them though which is a  good thing.) Nicely decorated in a minimalist way that keeps it several steps above the buffets and quick bite places without the glitz if the much more expensive restaurants.  Service was efficient and polite. Not a real stand out but nothing at all to complain about.  The food was above average but not quite as good as my favorite local places back home (better than PF Chang's for a more universal reference.) I started with the lettuce wraps... Delicious! Large cups of lettuce leaf that were very easy to fill and a fantastic brown sauce. I loved them. My entree was Mongolian beef... Very good but didn't blow me away. I would try something else next time. They do bring a little pot of Asian chili sauce  to the table which definitely improved my beef... But beware... It is spicy... And not the wussy kind of spicy that old ladies complain about when the get fast food Mexican... Clear up your allergies spicy. Yum!  Prices were decent for a casino resort restaurant... $15 - 27 for most entrees. Appetizers were a little pricy but definitely worth it.  This place won't be the culinary highlight of your trip but it is a nice place for a relaxed dinner, reasonable prices and good food.

RUvDUjP2hHqVSk8vGnxQKA.text: This is a 3.5 star review, but not quite 4.  I had dinner at Noodle Asia on a Friday night around 10:30.  It was busy, but there were a few open tables.  I know from previous experience there can be quite a line for this place, but they usually get through it decently quick.  Our server immediately arrived to take our drink order.  They have the usual suspects for Asian beers as well as a small wine and cocktail list.  I went with Asahi and the server was fairly quick with the refills.  To start we went with the seared shrimp chive dumplings and Har Gow, which are steamed shrimp dumplings.  The appetizers came out fairly quickly, definitely under 10 minutes.  The Har Gow was good but the winner in my estimation was the shrimp chive dumplings.  They have a nice crispy exterior and really strong chive flavor.  If you do not like chives do not order this dish, as it is definitely chive-forward.  I love chives and not surprisingly I loved this dish.  For my entree I had the Pho Special Prime which includes rare ribeye, brisket, tripe, and meatballs.  The broth was good but it lacked the depth of flavor I have had at many pho places.  The brisket and ribeye were good, the trip was not as good but certainly not bad, but the meatballs were a miss for me.  The texture was very hard as if they had been overworked.  I would get the pho again but I would request extra brisket instead of meatballs.  I did have to pull a couple of pieces of meat out of the soup in order to cut them on a plate.  They were too large to eat in one bite.  I would order the dumplings again for sure and would try the pho, provided I can get the meatballs substituted.  This is a more than solid joint if you are at the poker room or sportsbook and need a quick bite.  I will likely return.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pho special.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp chive appetizer. Really good.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dQERp7boanEqCx-Gwg32Yw.text: Noodle Asia is located in the Venetian Hotel inside the Casino area. All signs point to a very good experience. Traditional and limited menu items, large crowd of Asians, and no frills decor.   I pick this place mainly because I wanted some soup to warm up my soul. So I got an order of shrimp Har Gow and a bowl of Hong Kong Wonton Soup. It was very reasonable for a Vegas Strip markup at less than 20 for the full meal.   The cons: service was spotty and took at least 10+ mins before a waitress even asked me what I wanted to drink. Then my main dish came out before my appetizer. This caused a weird start because I started to finish my soup half way, but then my Har Gow came and I stopped eating my soup to eat those too to avoid it getting cold. So timing is clearly of no importance, but it looks like that's the case with all the patrons that all the food comes out at once.   On the other hand, the soup was great and the Har Gow was flavorful and fresh. I can admire the quality of the broth and it tasted better than instant like some reviewers were saying.   Overall, did it change my life? Nah...but it's not a bad place to go for some simple and decently priced Chinese food in the strip!

NQ9sKbc-ErIjsPZ1Xpk0Cw.text: This is advertised as generally Asian type food, but everything on the menu looked to be only Chinese, which was ok. This restaurant is very casual and sits just outside the sports book at the Venetian hotel. I had potstickers which were ok, but I've had better. This place is very noisy but the atmosphere did remind me of places I've been to in Asia, so it felt authentic.  Good place for a fast and inexpensive Chinese meal.

nSkcQNKqViDhqMrH1qNp2g.text: It's okay. Pretty average Chinese food. Expensive as hell. $45 for what would cost $12 at my favorite place (spring roll, lo mein, hot and sour soup. But it's Vegas so whatever.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp stir fry with noodles

Vc2M4zdKjl1ed_5pMiipmA.text: A friend recommended this place!  My god it has to be one of the best restaurants we have been to while in vegas, and we have been to quiet a few.  Service was prompt, food was great, pricing is good, long line but wait wasnt but 5/10 minutes max.  Will def be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wyqOxy8icGIzpUIWe2iTag.text: Taste good but not great. The taste is much close to hongkong resturant. I ordered dandan noodle and felt disappointed.But I like the vinegar pepper soup.

90Xj4VVvV8YvPhTijh5KOg.text: Food was great! We ordered shrimp fried rice which was extremely good! Only downfall of the place is the service is slow but if you're in the mood for a moderately priced meal this is the place!

OnVhm2NlAAjHACoIh-69yg.text: I would rate this place as 3 1/2 stars.  Noodle Asia is located in the Venetian's casino, and the place is open late. Most of the customers and workers were Chinese, and the food was pretty good. My favorite was the wonton noodle soup, with big wontons and some bok choy. At around 12.00 for a large bowl, it is pretty reasonable for a restaurant in the casino. Definitely try this place fo something quick and good while gambling.

YV9Z52iVPD7IBS4qleeyIg.text: This is the go-to place for the best hangover food.  The servers are not the most friendly, but I'm willing to forgo their services because their food is AH-MAZ-ING~~!!!    Our order:  Won Ton Soup - GOOD  Miso Soup - Ok.  I thought the miso soup would be a small bowl but I was mistaken (I ordered miso soup AND Beef Congee).  It was a gigantic bowl.  It's pretty much an entree in itself.  Red Won Tons - DELICIOUS  Siu Mai (6) - It's ok.  I've had better (esp at Elite.  See review for Elite).  Beef Congee - The Congee is probably the BEST congee I've ever had in my entire life.  I've had congee from pretty much every Chinese restaurant and even ventured into New York's Chinatown to the highly acclaimed Congee Village).  The porridge is cooked perfectly and not watery or too thick.  It was PERFECT.    Fish Filet Congee  Pork and Special Preserved Egg Congee   I will go back to Noodle Asia just for the congee.  It's a God-send.  I guarantee it.

DyDLX-x42GkWry8fQoe0PA.text: The worst Asian food i have ever had. Don't spend your money here. Beef was like plastic and seafood was not fresh.

HUUVCmMJdLpo8nG0XLq72A.text: Stopped in for lunch, excellent service, friendly staff, and the food was delicious! Super authentic and flavorful, very high qualify food. Would recommend to anyone looking for that Asian fix. I, myself had the combination fried rice. Chicken, pork, and seafood all flavored perfectly. Nothing too overpowering, it all just went together perfectly. Also ordered a side of kimchi and it was delicious!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0g4sbKJPknRkqzPmDZC_cA.text: The prices were high for very ordinary Asian food...had a lot better at some little takeout place.  I had the orange chicken, which had no flavor whatsoever and was overcooked leaving it chewy.  My husband had Mongolian Beef.  It too had very little flavor and was not anything like many of the other Mongolian Beef he'd had.  Service was OK - my husband's food came out a good 8-10 minutes before mine.  The bill was $72.00, including tip.  I would not eat there again.

wyE5IjCN4JL1oHVPg3yRdg.text: Listen to a real Asian, originally from Taiwan, looking for Chinese food in Vegas.  This place is legit, and the best non-Japanese Asian bite you will find on the Strip.    First off, the Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup here is fantastic.  Great and relatively fantastic.  If you are craving authentic Chinese Beef Noodle Soup, it won't get better than this in Vegas.    The Singaporean pan fried noodles were also great.  Well spiced and flavored, and like the noodles in the Beef Noodle Soup, well cooked and perfectly al dente.    Highly recommended place, especially for you Cantonese and Taiwanese tastes.  The style of cooking here will accommodate both types of tongue.    Oh, and they are open until late.  Highly recommended.

ky0P0OHGkYT8eJ-okIJEwg.text: Fairly authentic Chinese noodle shop inside the Venetian. Very casual and not terribly crowded when we showed up for lunch on a Friday. Seated quickly and ordered and the food was out before we knew it. Based on what I observed, food can be a bit hit or miss depending on what you like and order. For instance the Shanghai noodles I ordered had a piddly amount of shredded pork in it but plenty of noodles. Meanwhile others at my table had ordered a bbq plate, kung pao chicken and shrimp noodles and all had quite a bit more meat in it. Service was pretty good and did I mention quick?

BJaE6F7vQLtTm8L5nrwEbA.text: We had the roasted duck and it did not disappoint! For $9 a plate at the venetian, I thought it was quite a steal! The duck was very well cooked and had none of the raw, red taste (which I dislike). I would come back here just for the duck again!   We had the dan dan noodles - peanut sauce and minced pork. The sauce was great but the noodles was a tad bit overcooked. Nonetheless, a decently priced meal for the location.   Efficient service, considering the restaurant was packed. I think they cannot afford not to be as volume is key to their survival. If you don't want fast-food and want to spare your pockets a pinch... this would be a perfect choice for a fussy-free meal.

xqDaQwBrSSK4IsDT29LRwg.text: Tried the szechuan beef noodle soup and hong kong style shrimp won ton noodle soup.  Both were good.

6fM_Q4TwaEbSQgqSgynuPw.text: I don't know why everyone is complaining about Noodle Asia being overpriced.  What in Vegas isn't overpriced?  Get real people!!  If you want to eat regular priced food, go to McDonald's or Burger King.  Don't eat at any restaurant inside a casino...  The food here is the best Chinese in town.  It's authentic Chinese, not the fake, greasy, and nasty Panda Express.  It has real authentic flavors and all the chefs in the kitchen are actually Chinese, so you know the food is good and for real here.  Even the hot sauce in the white container on the table is good, and I see many Venetian guests order takeout and probably bring it back to their rooms to eat.  That's how good the food is here.  Service is alright so there's really nothing to complain about here.  For Vegas, this place is definitely 5 stars.    For all you haters bickering about the price, don't complain about the price ... grow up and man up if you want to eat a restaurant in Vegas.  Jeez.

CJabfPH4dn3G1kaKlcW31w.text: Came here late at night. the food is reasonably priced (especially for Vegas) and it tasted delicious! Any of the soup noodle bowls looked good. I got one of the beef soup bowls and it was yummy!  I love the location and I love how they are open late and there is plenty of seating. sorry for using too many "ands" in a sentence.

M2J4xBDxKs2D6po8MMsxdw.text: Horrible restaurant service. Tofu is very bland and silken. The server rushed throughout our visit and never said hi. After I asked him to change the dish twice (because the tofu was not enjoyable) I ordered vegetable fried rice that was also bland. I needed to put both hot sauce and soy sauce in to give it flavor. My friend ordered mushroom soup and she also had a bad experience.  Not very affordable. The cost is not worth the food or service.

oN3ra1zQHbcZJEBJY04Rig.text: I liked this place for their quick service and for one of their dish which i will give 5 star. Schezuan beef noodle soup was excellent. Super tasty and freshly served. Also tried their Night market fried rice which was so so. very tangy and sticky but it was average. It was inside a casino and had a little trouble finding it first. Busy place.

F8s16SLsPhMum0iQDBODag.text: My family has been coming here for years whenever we are in Vegas. This place will give you a quick Asian fix if you need it and don't feel like driving to the Chinatown area.  I like the fried rice and BBQ pork and roast duck noodle soup. Decently authentic with typical Chinese restaurant status service and tourist Las Vegas prices.   Check it out if you're looking for an Asian place around this side of town.

vzpYXnLHg08JJWvSqCNFeA.text: We just arrived at Las Vegas and only ate Del Taco before we came. So we were definitely hungry! On top of that, we had to get ready for Tao Nightclub, so even more hungry! We found this place in The Venetian and next to Tao Nightclub, so we decided to try it out. The restaurant looked very nice and chic, but then again it had to be, located in The Venetian remember?!  What we ordered: 1. Black pepper beef udon-The beef was very fresh and the udon was made just right. However, it was a bit oily for my liking, but I was way too hungry, so I finished this whole plate! Lol! 2. Seafood mix udon-This was not a good dish at all...The seafood didn't taste that fresh. The flavor was bland and not very satisfying.  3. Tea-Watered down...Need to put more leaves in it to make sure the tea has flavor.  The service here was good, four stars.  Overall, I wouldn't recommend coming here for Chinese food, should have went to Chinatown. =(

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Pepper Beef Udon
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood Mix Udon

Y5YDJJefODlxr55uPgQJeQ.text: This place actually has a legit Beef Noodle Soup. It was better than many local Chinese restaurants in more ethnic neighborhoods of California.

_TkdAHtEAipzyL3I29IcRQ.text: Surprisingly authentic Chinese cuisine, very reasonably priced, swift service. Servers, clientele and kitchen are Chinese...this is usually a good sign. Great spot to grab a quick snack.  Wanted something light and had the wonton soup, which was perfectly light and refreshing. Comes in both cup and bowl. They also serve traditional bone-in chicken soup with ginger - would try this next.  Has a few classic dimsum selections if you're craving a quick snack (ha gao, shiu mai, pot stickers, spring rolls). Tried the shrimp & chive pan-fried dumplings, which were excellent.  Was unimpressed with the Five Spice Tofu - was told the tofu was braised, but it's actually fried and bland without the XO chili sauce on top.  Service was pleasant and professional, servers also speak Chinese.  NOTE: Hard-to-find - stumbled upon the cafe randomly while walking through the casino floor - it is hidden in the back corner of the Venetian casino floor by the betting screens.

4RikhunN-DPGnRhHVZ1Eag.text: A perfect little quick spot to recharge. I've been going to this fast, delicious noodle restaurant since The Venetian opened and it's never failed me.   The location is perfect, steps off the casino floor next to the sports book. You don't have to go to far from the action and if you've got the right table, you can watch the games on the sportsbook screens.   My hands down favorite is the spicy beef udon (the dish, not soup). It's perfectly seasoned to give a kick but not overpowering.   Even if I'm not staying at the Venetian, I make it a point to stop by at least once (sometimes twice) to eat here. Love that it's open 'til 3am.

K0M_PEAxgsZf4tzEQ0t4eQ.text: Been here several times and have had a decent experience.  The price of the food is reasonable, service is relatively quick, and location and hours of operation are convenient.  Recommended:  Wonton noodle soup, the spicy jumbo shrimp lai fun dish, and pan-fried pot stickers (the pot stickers are especially delicious late-night and hard-partying).

mw0SZtBrFsBNFxC6WFJapw.text: If you're desperate for food or got a major case of the munchies after a night of heavy drinking, I can understand how you would love this place.  Otherwise, there isn't much to love here. The budget conscious won't like the price tag and the health conscious won't like the...fat...lard...that ridiculously thick fatty sauce that they put on my crunchy noodles with seafood.  They do have crunchy noodles which you can't get at just any chinese restaurant, but they spoil the crunchiness by drenching them in so much sauce that they get soggy.  Get ready for a debilitating food coma after you done. Food came out quickly and the service was very prompt and to the point which I liked.  The crunchy noodles were good, the stuff on top that made the noodles not crunchy was pretty nasty.

-Fotd1r2FZpQ9pOgEBVnaA.text: MSG ALERT!  The Beef Szechwan noodles were good but at $13.95 a pop? I know, it's the Venetian, it's Vegas, blah blah. Forgiven.  It's just that I'm used to getting it for $4.50 at home, so the price threw me off a bit.   The Red Wontons tasted exceptional: boiled pork wontons soaking in a soy sauce/vinegar/sesame oil/red chili oil/ garlic concoction. They were in fact so good, we devoured them in 3 seconds and promptly ordered another serving.  The thing is, MSG in large quantities is detrimental to my looks. I bloat, retain water, get headaches and puffy eyes, not to mention a general feeling of listlessness throughout the remainder of the day. After thoroughly slurping up the entire contents of my meal, I had all of the above symptoms. And since I hadn't eaten for 3 days as I was trying to be cute and skinny in my new bikini for Tao Beach, I can safely assume this place was the culprit.  Noodle Asia sabotaged my game.

vwJfjb5GBw_FxSA__vAniw.text: The noodles may be good but the kung pao chicken was a total dud. Wildly expensive at $18.95 and not nearly as good as airport fast-food Chinese. The dish was sweet (not spicy) and gloopy. The chicken had no saute marks. I think it was boiled.

Mx6u141ffIilo6chcY6l3g.text: My 2nd time eating here and I would say some dishes taste better than others.  Fujian style fried rice is good.  Their noodle soups are just ok.  I would dine here when I don't feel like making a trip to LV Chinatown or buffets wear me out.  A bit expensive and small portions!

BxclH8rDZmapIwbPMzqx6g.text: $100 dollars for 6 people at a Chinese Congee and Noodle restaurant. WOW Seriously charge more! What a RIP this place is, but it's Vegas, and why would you want to take a taxi to Asia town to get some good chinese food, when you're half drunk.   Some of the stuff is pretty good, but some other dishes please send back to the kitchen. YUCK. Don't order the congee, the pot stickers, or the egg rolls. Please order the Shanghai noodles, the rice cakes, ho fun, or chow mein. Those will do wonders if you're home sick for some old fashion Chinese noodle dishes! I mean its no 5 star Chinese restaurants like we have in the SF bay area, but this will do.

O4wuuydN4Bn8vbCLOqUoXg.text: My partner and I went to Noodle Asia the day we arrived in Las Vegas.  We checked into the Venetian around lunchtime, so by the time we were settled in our room we were quite hungry.  I had looked at the dining book in the room and I saw that Noodle Asia had vegetarian dishes, so we decided to go there.  There was an extremely long wait to get seated - and there were only three parties ahead of ours (one of which had 6 people, the others were couples).  It also took a very long time to get anything to drink and to have our order taken; this was at lunchtime so perhaps they were understaffed.  Fortunately the food arrived quickly after we ordered it, and when we were ready to leave, my doggie bag was brought quickly.  I was quite disappointed in the food, however.  When a restaurant is specifically advertised as having multiple vegetarian dishes, I expect them to be either marked with an icon or in their own section - but here, I had to ask the hostess to explain what dishes on the menu were vegetarian.  There were not many of them, although she claimed that a few could be "made vegetarian" by leaving out meat.  (I am always skeptical of this, because very often they use beef broth anyway.)  I ordered the Buddha's Feast noodles and my partner ordered the Shanghai Noodles; hers were much better than mine.  The atmosphere at Noodle Asia is not good at all.  It's mostly sheltered from the casino, but wide-open to the sports book.  I did not enjoy staring at 87 TV's showing all kinds of sports while I ate.  If you are already at the Venetian and craving Asian food, but you can't afford Tao, then Noodle Asia is not too bad.  But otherwise, I'd stay far away from this restaurant.

3_uwXqbXB1wrMXi3c0AuyQ.text: Arrived outside Noodle Asia... line outside could be a good thing?  It moved quickly too, which was nice.    Tried to order a few things family style...  Hot & Sour Soup - Neither hot (spicy) nor sour. Seafood Soft Noodle - this didn't taste like anything, except maybe for oil. Cantonese Sausage Fried Rice - best entree, but more sausage/egg/veggies would have been nice. Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce - Not bad. Siu Mai - Nope!  All out. Har Gow - Nope!  All out of this too.  Ugh.  Nothing was terrible, but nothing was that good either.  I went here since I couldn't face Grand Lux for the third time in as many days...  but afterwards I wished I had.

sWm-cYYBvmZkI74BKp_NbQ.text: I have eaten here many times and they deserve a review!  These are the beat noodles in Vegas.  I get the soft noodles with chicken and it is always fantastic!  The service is great but the ambience is less then desirable. It isn't a date place but a great lunch or late night snack.

uYBPu8Kmb1fWIlKkfHbbDQ.text: I've only been to 3 noodle places in Vegas, but Noodle Asia has been the best so far.  The others I've tried are Noodles at Bellagio and Beijing Noodle #9 at Caesars.  It seems like we always go here on a late Friday night after coming from the airport.  The dishes I've had have all been really good.  The noodles in the Szechwan Beef are amazing..  really fresh.  The Chicken Stir-Fried Soft Noodles are pretty good.  Probably my favorite is the Buddha Feast Pan-Toasted Noodles.  My gf gets it all the time cuz it's vegetarian, but you can add meat (I like mine with chicken..  it comes out to be the same price as the Chicken Stir-Fried Soft Noodles).  Every time I get something other than that, I end up wishing I'd just gotten it instead.  Noodles at Bellagio also has pan-toasted noodles.  I think they call it Hong Kong style noodles, or Cantonese noodles, or something like that.  I don't know whether it was a fluke, but contrary to Noodle Asia's, they were gross.  Extremely salty.  Like salty enough for your mouth to feel like it's getting too much salt, and for you to wonder whether your blood pressure will be adversely affected by it.  blech.  Back to Noodle Asia.  They run a tight ship.  Service is prompt and good.  You can see them cooking your food.  The food is good.  It might seem a little pricey for what it is, but it's worth it I think.  All around an excellent place.

1lc_xIoDuX7bZKld9uoIYQ.text: Authentic chinese food at the strip. Reasonably priced, i can actually say that it is very affordable considering it is inside the Venetian casino. The shumai, siomai or simply pork dumplings, it is just so delicious. I had to order 2 every time cause it is jusy so damn good. The fried rice is a good portion, i can say it is good for 2 people. My husband had the beef brisket soup noodle and it is just like being in China. This place is one place u would always come back to. One day, we ate there twice. For lunch and dinner, just can't get enough of Noodle Asia, and oh did i mention that service is fast. They have about 5 or 6 cooks in the cooking station and they make it right away so it is yummy and hot when served!

dkiyIIcOvm9ZlKUCLqyrLw.text: FOOK GEEN CHOW FAN. (Fried rice, crack sauce, mushrooms, veggies, shrimp, and more good shit. CANNOT GO WRONG! It's off the menu but we get this EVERY time we go to vegas. Best hangover food you can get. & it's location is awesome!

GnadQfZK0r3akcQUIogVSg.text: Can't argue with 3am and i can get food  So great.  My recent staples are  Spicy beef noodle soup  Fried rice seafood.  Stir fry string bean Pan toasted noodle with mix seafood. Yum.

XpdTnR2lieHToBXtJhcEGQ.text: This was our first meal in Vegas when we checked into our suite at the Venetian. Disappointed!! :( It tasted worse than Panda Express. Hahah The kitchen and set up of the restaurant looked like a buffet but when you come in, they seat you and take your order. It was really typical "Asian" service at a mom/pop shop that you would find in China town; it was crap. But in Chinatown, at least food is good. Here, food was crap, but at least it wasn't expensive for Vegas. A pro is that the restaurant is open late ... but still, even if I get the late night munchies, I wouldn't come here again.

s1zLnwaQ6KuVVt4AFM-jHQ.text: I used to work a booth at the ASD trade show at the Sands Convention Center two weeks out of the year. My company would order take out for lunch from here almost everyday. It's just your ordinary overpriced Chinese food. Nothing tastes great, but nothing tastes horrible. It sure beats eating old hot dogs from the convention center.

HpFAnoILKxI8-p_lliiWPA.text: Food was delicious. We had pot stickers, crab rangoons, and beef noodles. Service was good but was a long wait for food to be cooked.

VxybSQep4N-PP0MdCP9wlw.text: This is very average cuisine but good for a quick bite of comfort food. Being that I was told that Kevin Wu, the proprietor of the original Royal Star Dim Sum seafood restaurant in the Venetian, was the creator of Noodle Asia, I got excited being that for more than half a decade, I frequented Royal Star in both Santa Monica as well as in the Venetian before it closed its doors. NO DIM SUM. PHOOEY. But alas, when I arrived, there was barely any Dim Sum available. It seems that nothing more is available other than rice & noodle dishes. I'm not even going to go through any of the dishes I've ordered over the visits I've had there because... well, you're not really gonna go here for the food. You're gonna go here if you want something of reasonable quality QUICKLY and at a good price. GREAT FOR GRINDERS: Here's the menu: venetian.com/uploadedFil... I would describe the cuisine here as more "filling" that "delicious". If you're in the Venetian Poker Room and need to carb up quickly, this is a great place to get served quickly, shovel down some food that's very edible, pay the bill, and get back to the next sit-and-go. RELATIVELY CHEAP: And if you're on a budget or you're a cheap assed Blackjack player, Noodle Asia is likely a great place to get filled up on reasonably priced food - relative to typical Vegas restaurants in a 4-star hotel. ...But for an amazing gastronomical experience, the dim sum are way, way, WAY tastier & better presented at Woo (at the Palazzo), albeit at prices 3x more expensive. CONCLUSION: Average food in good quantity at prices to match. 3-Stars.

FsseKi1QUml9bbvrasrJEw.text: We skipped out on dinner to hit up XS so by the time we came here to eat late night we were starved. We got seated right away and the food came FAST!  We were all trying to figure out if it was just we were so hungry or the food was really good. Now that I think about it, the food was probably just soso but decent for late night.  I got the wonton noodle soup, and we shared a bbq small plate. The bbq meats were decent. Wontons and noodle were not the best, but it was great comfort food for late night.  Considering some of the other noodle bars in vegas this place is good because it opens later 3am, I also really like Noodles @ Bellagio but it closes early.

-s-1kPMHcBzBWVDKDPtw0Q.text: Food lacked in flavor...however, the presentation was decent and the quality was good. I wouldn't come back though...it's pricey and I think I prefer cheap sloppy fake "Chinese food" from Panda express or your local wok anyways.

51rv_mj2hWsjTeB7_XUfyA.text: Everything we ordered was amazing! Orange chicken, Mongolian chicken and chicken fried rice was one of the best Chinese meals we've had. Defiantly a place you want to go if you're craving Chinese.

BcQvPUL49YTdvw9I7Ou1qA.text: Will people stop bitchin' how overpriced the food is here! Your at the Venetian ( not the palace station) and on the strip so what do you expect to pay for fast Asian food? Or you can spend money on a cab and your time to go to Chinatown.  We had the won ton noodle soup and the tu lan ( chicken w/ veggies & gravy) noodle soup and they were fine. They satisfied our craving for Chinese. Service was fast and friendly. If you are sensitive to msg they definitely use it liberally. For the convenience, this place is worth going to if u want quick Chinese.

4zNbEmpx8kVK8kXHCI6Fmw.text: Came here when I was at a conference here. It was a delight to find this place at the hotel. Food is authentic and tasty, and being  right in the hotel is such a convenience! It's been difficult to find quick, authentic Chinese food at Vegas short of heading out to Chinatown. Now I've found this place I'll definitely come back when I crave Chinese food in Vegas!

KLxM355RX4zg2AQnc4mzFw.text: Many come to Vegas for the clubs, the casinos, the "naughty naughty" cards off the strip, the palpable indoor cigarette smoke, the shows, or the decriminalized public intoxication and/or prostitution. I come for the Niu Rou Mien at Noodle Asia. Yes, you heard me. I come to Vegas for a hot steamy bowl of chewy noodles, tender chunks of beef, and a deep, dark, bold, spicy broth.   While yes, at $13.95 for a bowl of Taiwanese soup is quite steep and may leave many wondering where the "happy ending" went; but, rest assured, the happy ending came. And yes, it came without ribbons. It came without tags. It came without packages, boxes or bags. What if Niu Rou Mien, perhaps, means a little bit more?   In addition, the Red Won Tons tossed in Szechwan Hung Yao chili and garlic sauce are really good too.   A bowl of Niu Rou Mien is how I do Vegas... and, how the Grinch does Christmas!

D78Fm-wxGI8n-8gQjyXPIA.text: This was a great gem in the Venetian! I was craving Chinese food and this place ought to relieve that crave.  - Schezuan Beef Noodle in Soup - the soup was good but it was oily. However, the flavor was just too great. YuMM. I finished it all.   - Potstickers - these ones had extremely think skin and they weren't as crunchy or crispy as expected.  - Shanghai Fried Noodle - a little too oily and no life to this.   - Fish Balls & Prawns with Rice Noodle in Soup - This was pretty good. The rice noodle was chewy. They added like that x.o. sauce and dried shirmp on top of the noodles. The prawns were juicy and delicious; however, the soup was a little bit oily.  - Fuk Chow Fried Rice - this was delicious. The "gravy" sauce with the sauteed vegetables made a perfect complimentary to the smell of the rice. Must eat this again.  - Hot and Sour Soup - this was quite interesting. It was less murky than other hot and sour soups but had pepper sprinkled and for the first time, it had pickled cabbage in it. Yummy.  I'm definitely a fan of this place.

0S0p_BcCZAZgFfSBXLHxzg.text: Great Chinese food (non-chinese food eater), well priced, not greasy, tasty, authentic (from what I'm told), casual.  It was perfect before a night of gambling and trouble.  I didn't expect it to be as good as it was.  A pleasant surprise.

1lCu--ONeT5ABi70b3WSNQ.text: Really great food! I visited a few years ago and have been looking forward to coming back ever since.  The potstickers are delicious and come with a very tasty soy based sauce. I tried the stir fried soft noodles w/ shrimp, as well as sampling my friend's noodle soup. Both were great! My meal could have used a little less oil, but it was certainly delicious.  Service was passable. It took a while to get refills and we had a few drink order mistakes. Paying for our meal took way too long, but the food made up for it. I'll certainly go back.

NeUQxnf0j4moyID6t3pT_g.text: Service was fast and the food come out quickly, but the food is not very tasty and the prices are ceiling high. If I wasn't too hungry, i wouldn't eat here.

RMLPIUfFWCOp-IT9YnvaYA.text: This place services tasty dim sum until 3am.  The bartender at the sports book next door agreed with me that Noodle Asia is the best restaurant at The Venetian.  The shu mai and har gow are fantastic.  I usually get a beef dish over rice (can't think of the name) that is my favorite.  The service is very fast.  I have eaten here at least 10 times and never had a sub-par experience so I would have to say they are very consistent.  The only thing they have done consistently that I have laughed about is that they always forget to give me a pen to sign the check with.  When I ask for a pen, they always say "not again".  Oh well.  I am never in a hurry near 3am.

hNk0KTFmzKphHRZ0271HQw.text: 3.5 stars. All I got was a cup of wonton soup because I needed breakfast. It was pretty good and larger than I expected for the price! Service was also very fast, especially since I was just by myself. I was seated very promptly at the bar.

qMKpA2cNNStFZbxDsqkUsQ.text: I really want to give this place four stars because it is so damn satisfying to have greasy Chinese comfort food while you're drunk and Noodle Asia totally hits the spot, but I won't just because the food is so overpriced.  Yeah I know it's Vegas blah blah blah, but still!  Food like this is dirt cheap normally.  Anyway, the chinese sausage fried rice... Y-U-M.  They give you A LOT too.  I have also tried the BBQ Pork/Duck with rice dish and it was just alright.  Spring for the chinese sausage fried rice though!

WcU8rzGRtwqDrywPh4SlWQ.text: During a fun filled bachelorette weekend of partying, my friend & I left the club early just to try this place out right before they closed at 2am. Thankfully we made it and it was worth running in heels for. We ordered the duck noodle soup. I'm not kidding you, the broth is god sent and amazing and the noodles were delectable! It was worth the $13 price tag. The bowl was large enough to share between us two girls and left us wanting more. The cool thing was that we weren't even drunk to have to enjoy some delicious comfort food!

e4lflBM7BaMi_lL3anyXPA.text: Everything I've tried at Noodle Asia has tasted so good!  My favorites:  Wonton soup - super simple with just wonton and some bok choy, but still super tasty! The broth is really good!  Shumai - probably the best I've ever had. Since having shumai here, nowhere else's has compared.  Mongolian beef - lots of flavor! And just enough spiciness.  Those are my favorites, but as I said earlier, everything I've had here is really tasty. It's nice that it's open late, too. Service is mediocre at best, but for this place, the good food outweighs the service.

AK9E1C-Ap7Vljt3x9LFI_A.text: We ate here around 2am after a late night out at the clubs - while in Vegas for a business conference  - and it was outstanding.  I had the Mongolian Beef and my two colleagues had other relatively common Chinese dishes, and all were excellent.  Still can't believe there was that high a quality of Chinese available in the middle of the night, right next to the sport book at the Venetian where I was staying, but hey ... it is Vegas.  Would definitely go again.

HqYV5N_DjyNkJ-P_FdEmiA.text: eh its okay here.   i like their crab rangoon. and the fried rice was decent but i had to ask for some like sweet sauce to give it flavor.   pros- fast service  cons- not that much taste to the food, a little overpriced but i guess its vegas. my friend found a hair in her PHO but they did take it off the bill one of my shrimp was "properly" cleaned out which is totally gross.  i would just come back for their crab rangoon.

TDMvm3nRpJA6EzgYbMn5lw.text: shanghai stir-fried noodel was good long line others were just okay service was only 2 stars

HSN8BzqD9K75W83XcSpwbQ.text: If you're in Vegas and needle some decent asian food, then Noodle Asia is the place to go.  It's not the best Asian food I've had, but it's fast, relatively cheap (for Vegas) and it's convenient if you're staying at the Venetian.  The bbq pork & duck noodle soup is pretty bomb.  And I've tried a few of the other noodle dishes & rice dishes...a great place to come the next morning for a "hangover" cure.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef over rice topped w/ an over easy egg.

6pu3WtZm_nix80XNS3knpg.text: Was expecting this place to be excellent since it is at the Venetian and had a long line.  Was very disappointed with the food.  Ordered Kun Pao Chicken for $19.95 and it was all salt and msg.  Also had the Chicken Fried Rice that had fatty chicken in it.  Way overpriced for poor quality of food.  The good:  Service was fast and efficient.

tdmf2EPTQ11zUUBwsTFNEw.text: The one & only thing you need to know about this place: BEST PORRIDGE EVER. I love going here after hitting up the clubs or to cure the hangover the next day. So amazing.

sQZNKMPn_gL_qgGjAv08vQ.text: I love the Szechuan beef noodle soup! Very tasty!! Every time I visit vegas I eat here!!

Seiqxwhzy1fdu_r3GHmv7g.text: Service was ok. I got the beef fried rice and the beef was very chewy. The fried rice wasn't that great either. Would not recommend this place and will not return.

nrE7Nsmg3hihCW0VyF1HEg.text: Located in The Venetian Hotel. We ordered the shrimp fried rice, won ton soup and the half & half bbq pork and roasted duck. The quality of each dish confuses me. The fried rice was okay, nothing too amazing. The half & half dish was a completely different story. Shitshow on a dish is putting it very gently - the duck had no meat and was boney, the pork was chewy and everything was overseasoned and salty. The thing that changed it around was the wonton soup, which was perfectly seasoned, refreshing and the dumplings had the perfect ratio of filling and wrapper. Service was quick and straightforward, which I also like.

UJdoKxy_fod47tGoqOgG8Q.text: Dam Dam noodles and shrimp fried rice are very good and plentiful. Other guests has great meals also.

WZqkIFPRL7yaqkXPgHDxbw.text: Delicious food and good service.   I got minced chicken lettuce cups, crab rangoons, and pho. The pho was absolutely delicious, but $17.50. The lettuce cups were delicious as well at $13.95 and the crab rangoons were good as well at $9.95.   I had a great experience here and even though it's a little expensive may come back for the pho!

YlA0GV6ePQLU7C_InFfVnw.text: This place isn't anything super special. It's expensive because it's inside of the Venetian.   If you're like me and crave crispy noodles all the time come here for their crispy noodles it was delicious, but it's hard to fail at crispy noodles.  Their side of rice costs literally $2 that's insane ping pang pong is way better and much more affordable and located minutes from here off the strip.  If you do come here avoid the hot and sour soup. It's super sour like they over added something.

2HN5Hth4LJGf3PR5r_FFcw.text: Highly recommend. Food was delicious and the team work to execute things is extraordinary. I was very impressed with the service. I will be back!

3BBxfINlECowpr7qHwjEBg.text: Ordered pork congee (rice porridge) they took forever to serve it to us. The porridge tasted plain and barely had any pork. I should've just ordered a plain congee if that was the case...

5I24fwWCpcMUI2EE3ws1LQ.text: Hot and sour soup is to die for and cures the Vegas day after head and tummy blues.  Drop a little shrimp and fried rice and cures it all.   A nice app is Shiu Mai which is a great dumpling filled with goodness.   Shrimp friend rice and shrimp noodles are never a bad choice.   Must do if u enjoy great Asian Noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp fried rice
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soft noodle shrimp stir fry!
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hot and sour soup

jJ_EB_d3SCyr_uC_ELuDPw.text: The intoxicating smell of Asian food was what drew us straight into this place inside the casino.   After we ordered our food, most of it came out fast expect the main dish which the waitress forgot and then later brought out after we asked for it. Food was mediocre at best and they have a few gluten free options but not many.   Most of it was bland and seemed like a to go style Chinese restaurant. About an hour after we left the restaurant, both my husband and I got sick and felt sooo sick to our stomachs.   What a bummer because we had another dinner to attend and it totally messed up our stomachs for it.   If you are in a rush and need something quick after a night of being intoxicated then this mood may be appetizing but if you are sober and looking for good Chinese food...this food is not it.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic sautéed vegetables
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UEEyn6C9B2kfCYNxCv_8jA.text: This is my absolute favorite place! Anyone that doesn't give this place 5 stars is insane. The Spicy Ying Nan Noodle Soup is hands down something that I have not been able to replicate, but it is a goal for 2018. :) My first and last stop in Vegas!

t75Q8Tvu33sGP14B9-hXfQ.text: Just okay -- certainly nothing to write home about. We went in person to place a carryout order of combo fried rice, combo lo mein and potstickers. If you're expecting a smile from any of their staff, don't hold your breath. Vegas is full of restaurants which means tons of options for customers to choose from -- so, service needs to set you apart. In this case, their unfriendly customer service took their star rating down by two. The reason for losing the third star was the food; the combo lo mein/noodles were prepared with lots of green peppers which is a huge negative given: 1) the menu description made no mention of the entree having green peppers, and 2) our palates despise green peppers. Also, for the price ($16.95 per entree), there should've been much more seafood, chicken and bbq pork. So, pretty much an expensive disappointment all around.

7sryQX2ZBuKQt5K4_qm4BQ.text: So many bones in the duck...yuck!  Overall a miss on every level.  I wont be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rm606jE7AdOOklvnjhfBJA.text: I don't ever rave about beef noodle soup because it's not really my kinda thing, but I had to try for myself when my co-worker said that this was one of the best beef noodle soups he's ever had.  He even compared it to the ones in Taiwan!  I had to try for myself.  And boy was he right.  Who would've even thought that it would be in Vegas that I discover my love for beef noodle soup?!  In the Venetian too of all places?!?!  The Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup (btw - it's not spicy in case you're wondering) is a clear winner, with a super flavorful broth and noodles that are soft and not overly chewy.  The beef itself is cooked so perfectly that it's so tender!  Just this one time visit has had me wanting to come back for more.  It is now a forever staple for every visit to come, and it is not only delicious, but also absolutely heavenly after a night of too much drinking.  It's authentic and the place is clean too!  I also had the pho and shrimp chive dumplings, both of which were also good, but nothing compared to the beef noodle soup.  I'd recommend them if you don't want beef noodle soup, but if it was one thing I'd have to call out and get... you know my answer.  The Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup.  No doubt about it.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp and chive dumplings
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodle soup

P-6vfP9i4joLS3el2lmM-Q.text: Service for food- not bad, not great. The food was fairly quick to come out, and everything was correct, but the servers bringing your food may not necessarily call it the same thing as what you said when ordering, so beware of confusion unless you know your meal.   Food- not bad, not great. Average food, but filling and pleasant at 2am. At any other time probably not great.   Other pros: open late. No crowded.   Other cons: if something goes wrong, they probably won't tell you. You'll just sit there until they figure it. Be it the bill, or an order, or forgetting something, like your tea pot. Service is not their strong point.

mMQVI4A63EH8gp5mKQ9Y8w.text: Highly recommend people to check it out if you're staying at Venetian and Palazzo. This place is surprisingly authentic, however, very pricey since it is situated inside the hotel.  Service is great, sometimes there's a line, you'll get seated faster with a smaller party.   I love the beef noodle soup they have. The broth is flavorful with a kick, the noodle is chewy, and the beef is tender. Their fried chicken wings are A+++. It is crispy and juicy, I could not stop eating them.   They also open till 3am so it's perfect for after clubbing comfort food if you don't want to go far. Will be back for more of those noods!

U46H9GwxbWHapmCIXrgw0Q.text: Amazing har gow! Delicious! Pricey great that they're  open late and really delicious dim sum! It is not in steam carts it's off the menu.Nice place to have in the casino, really good food though shrimp and chive dumplings were also great had to do double. It's a little small inside and reminds me of a diner or small Chinese cafe.

cXn9_wlFrf01T33Tp6jdig.text: Okay...I'm giving this place 4 stars.  BUT there are some serious issues that would probably make me put fewer if this were just a run of the mill random chinese restaurant.  First, this place offers a mix of authentic and american style chinese dishes.  My two favorite things on their menu are their hot and spicy tripe (traditional szechuan dish) and their scallop (conpoy) congee.  Pretty much, these two dishes are the reason why I come to this place.  MAJOR upside.  Downside...the last THREE times I have been to this restaurant they have not been able to serve my two favorite dishes.  They claim to be out of scallops and tripe...which is possible, but I suspect they removed them from the menu and just haven't updated yet.    This place is located in a busy casino (Venetian, Las Vegas Strip).  If you like that then good...if you don't then don't come here.  It is loud, busy if you come at a typical service hour, and hectic.  Personally, I don't mind any of that and its the perfect late night snack place.  I've ended lots of nights with a spicy dish of tripe and joy at this location.  Service is rushed and somewhat unprofessional.  I personally feel like I might be mistreated here because I am not chinese.  Staff always question me if I order an authentic dish like I'm a two year old...even though I've been coming here for years.   Its True that it is somewhat pricey for this type of chinese food, but you are in a major casino.  you're going to pay a premium for anything you buy at the venetian.  if you want a more typical authentic chinese experience you should definitely check out some of the spots in Chinatown.  Totally different energy than on the strip.  I will be back here soon...and you people better have my tripe ready!!!!

LTUcM8pAy4QQOqBI7gVXpA.text: Food is always quick and delicious here. We always stop here for a meal when in Vegas. Staff is courteous and food comes out fast!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shanghai rice cakes - super yummy!

smTP5YRwc44RkI_cgHyBcg.text: Yang Chou Fried Rice was decent and came in a surprisingly large portion with plenty of shrimp!  Now that is value for a restaurant inside a Las Vegas strip hotel!!  Vegetarian Pan Toasted Noodles was not good.  The Chinese name is Lo Han Chay stir fried noodles.  Thus, my expectation was Chinese vegetables, shitake mushrooms, maybe some wheat gluten (vegetarian meat).  What I got was canned chop suey vegetables (water chestnut, canned mushrooms) over noodles.  But the portion was large.

ALmFrewEiSepnwBPeyA7RQ.text: Noodle Asia is located inside the Venetian hotel casino, right next to the sports booking area.  If you stay in the Venetian and are craving Chinese food, this is surprisingly one of the best restaurants that you'll find. If you want to venture out into that Chinatown plaza off the strip for better options, that's totally up to you! Since I prefer to stay around the area, this is the best value and quality that you'll get in any Vegas casino restaurant.   Depending on what time you go (lunch or dinner), you'll encounter a bit of a wait. There is enough seating to go around, and the wait staff do their best to assure that you won't wait too long.   Whenever I come here, I like to go all out, so I order two bowls of their Won Ton and Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup. Sometimes, I'll even come back twice in one day and order different menu items. I would recommend you try the Red Won Ton appetizers, Bbq Pork And Roasted Duck Rice Plate, and/or Mongolian Beef with Chinese Broccoli. I was quite impressed that the food tastes like what you'll find at Monterey Park. This is definitely my go-to place for Chinese food in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wonton Noodle Soup and the Shanghai beef from Noodle Asia

mmj_e6nQ-eJtl79QGN2dBA.text: Noodle Asia in the Venetian Hotel is, yes, expensive but oh so good!  We ordered Crab Rangoon with a sweet sauce, Beef Chow Fun, BBQ Duck & BBQ Pork with Rice and Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce.  All delicious!  This restaurant does not take reservations so expect line-ups during rush hour meal times.

rFZtauyQOZMmxnI_oxau4A.text: This Chinese restaurant is located inside the Venetian hotel next to the casinos.  We ordered the Szechwan beef noodles, the red wonton, the Mongolian beef and the beef crispy noodles. All the dishes were super delicious and very authentic (southern China). The Szechwan beef were soft and tender and the noodles were chewy. The stir fries were well flavored and cooked to the perfect condition. The red wontons were excellently spiced. The crispy noodle was something quite different.   The portions were massive and great value for money.   Their buba tea was yummy as well.  The waitress was friendly and certainly very helpful and provided us some good recommendations.  My top 3 favorite restaurant in California  Would definitely revisit! Highly recommend to everyone!!  Taste: 10/10 Presentation: 7.5/10 Service: 10/10 Ambience: 7.5/10 Value for money: 10/10  $25 per person (excl alcohol)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef crispy noodle
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red Won Tons and Mongolian beef
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechwan beef

49jZAeCeBloWpbmspiXJbQ.text: Was looking for pho past midnight (trying to cure my mild hangover) and found this place, but ended up seeing a bunch of stuff on the menu that I wanted instead!   Got a small hot n sour soup and a large egg flower soup (because I couldn't choose just one) but could have done without the hot n sour. It wasn't the best I've had but it was good! LOVED the egg flower soup. Was savory, not salty at all, and got rid of my headache. Har gow was amazing. I kept raving about it as I was eating it. It was like a little pillow of shrimp every time I ate it. The green beans also had a nice blend of garlic and basil.   Service was good too. Yum! Thanks Noodle Asia.

XoA6dEaxLQjSjGSyya4b_A.text: Came here on a late night, we were all hungry and didnt want to leave our hotel. Its conveniently located near The Venetian which is not too long of a walk from The Palazzo where we stayed.  We received $25 credit voucher upon checking in and decided to use it on the day we visited.  We walked in around 11:30 PM and this restaurant was full. All customers dining in seem to be all Chinese as they spoke their language. We sat down after waiting a couple minutes and looked at the menu. I was a bit unpleasant because the host and the servers all just started speaking Chinese to us. We clearly told them we are not Chinese and that we cannot speak the language but even after then, they kept wanting to communicate with us in CHINESE that I cant even understand.  We ordered Mapo Tofu, Dan Dan Mian (DDM)and Vegetable Noodle Soup. I didnt get to try the noodle because it didnt look too appetizing. My DDM was pretty good. It wasnt too bad as someone else has shared in his or her review. For the price, it did its job. Mapo Tofu was savory and the texture of soft tofu was very pleasing. It has that firey flavor that you cant ever have cooking it at home. Portion was very very large. Overall, our meal was satisfying.  We asked for a check and got it after trying for I dont know how long but definitely long enough. We got some other table's check before we got ours and the server gave us a weird look when we said this isnt our check. I mean, you gave us the wrong check so why are you making US look bad?  Plus, our server kept talking to us in Chinese which I was very offended by because we have already told them earlier so many times. Obviously, we couldnt communicate. There was not even one person who could speak fluent English.  We tried to use our voucher and gave the server our room number. We waited for 10 minutes or more and she comes back saying she cant let us use this voucher because she couldnt verify our room number. We had 2 rooms reserved so gave them both of our numbers and she just couldnt do it for no reason.  Ended up just paying out of pocket and wasted our voucher. It was very frustrating and she didnt even try to put some effort into making it work. Of course, there was no apology in anyway for taking forever and making us wait for longer than you think you know.  Food was OK but because of lacking in customer service and professionalism, I doubt I will eat here again.

-yR0CUIKnSXCQlZ1wck1vQ.text: Noddles were hard, staff was unwelcoming, got water once and lady never came back to refill. Hard to believe since they're inside one of the nicest hotels in LV  Will Not  be back here not recommending this place.

VzcrvUGHtoFceBKFjqgOaQ.text: The last time I had Noodle Asia was yeaars ago. I guess I forgot to leave a yelp review. I remember thinking that it was pretty good. Pricey, but good. The good news is that after all these years, Noodle Asia still remains good.  My girlfriend and I came here on our first night in Vegas with a voracious appetite. We ordered...  Beef chow fun: They can definitely make a good beef chow fun here. There's nothing more comforting than a big fresh mountain of noodles, beef, and onions; all packing that signature wok hei flavor.  Black pepper beef udon: A flavorful dish with just enough sauce/gravy so that it isn't overpowering or dry. It was good, but this was my girlfriend's choice.  Thai fried rice: I'm a huge fan of fried rice, whereas my girlfriend isn't. I thought that the rice was good. I could taste the basil in it, but my girlfriend thought otherwise.  We also came back a second night. My friend got me and another friend kicked out of Encore Beach Club. I got back to the room around 2ish and wanted to eat something other than White Castle... so off to Noodle Asia we went.  Cantonese beef stew w/ rice: I'm not sure, but I feel like this is a pretty random item to order. I personally enjoy it because of the hearty cuts of tender beef, onions, bell pepper, and a nice thick gravy that pairs well with jasmine rice. The rice doesn't soak up the gravy so it's a nice balance between dry and saucy.  My girlfriend also ordered rice porridge. I personally thought it was really bland, so I only had a couple bites before I was over it.  Noodle Asia offers up some authentic Chinese food with average portions. I understand that the prices are high because they're on the strip. I just wish they gave a little more because of how pricey it is so I feel like I'm getting my money's worth. Thankfully the food is good! The other convenient part is that they're open until 3 which is perfect if you're in the mood for some comfort Chinese food after drinking and partying.

hwR-B_KDusWwBFNW5Kjo0w.text: I love this place in Las Vegas. I travel for business once a year to a convention at the sands expo and this place feeds me well.  For lunch I recommend having their veggie chicken soup. It leaves you satisfied but not heavy. For dinner everything is delicious. The service is good and fast. The place Is clean and the ingredients are fresh.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken and veggies noodle soup

bX68pmVWjAzKE_YGtBHcSA.text: The prices at Noodle Asia will likely make you do a double take if you're used to going to hole in the wall joints for your Asian food fix. However, their prices aren't bad compared to other casino restaurants, and their portions are very reasonable. The line here can be super long, so come early for dinner, or late for lunch if you want to avoid the rush. We came around 5:15pm on a Saturday and the line was already about a 20-30 minute wait for a party of 3. We tried: -Soy Sauce Chicken ($9.95, yelp.com/user_local_phot...): WOW, super flavorful and tender! This was bordering on the salty side when eaten by itself, but it was really good with rice- Recommended! -Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup ($14.95, yelp.com/user_local_phot...): Solid beef noodle soup, although I wish it were spicier. The noodles had a nice chew, and the broth was flavorful. They added a lot of beef to the soup, and it had a good mix of tendon and meat- recommended. -Hong Kong Won Ton Noodle Soup ($12.95): Solid, but nothing special. The soup was a bit bland, and I wouldn't pay this amount to order this again. -Chinese Broccoli w/Oyster Sauce ($12.95): Yum- the Chinese broccoli was very fresh and cooked perfectly, and still very crispy. I saw some other tables order the roast duck, and that looked really well done. Service is ok- the floor manager is really good, and knows what she's doing. However, they are pretty short staffed here so you'll need to flag servers down when needed. Make sure you ask for some of their hot sauce if you like spicy food! If craving Asian food on my next trip to Vegas, I would definitely come back to Noodle Asia!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup ($14.95)- 4/5 stars
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soy Sauce Chicken ($9.95)- 4.5/5 stars

Ldo0MVcwgkrL-_NOfY9Kxw.text: Best Bet in Vegas for late night cantonese style chinese cuisine... so good its always busy and has stood the test of time. Its a bit hidden just off the casino floor of Venetian Resort. I discovered it years ago by happenstance when I was in for a convention and ever since its become a go-to spot.   Its like a diner with prompt and friendly service. No reservation is necessary. Prices are reasonable and dishes are plentiful. Kitchen is in the open which always makes me happy. Seems to-go is also a popular option.

JK4AlUDZ9lVgpncZrCaXAg.text: Wasn't hopeful in finding any decent Chinese food inside a casino but this place is not bad. As expected there is a wait but the turnover is pretty quick so the wait is bearable.    Their porridge was okay and more on the thicker side. Their Beef Chow Fun was loaded with oil, but the taste was there. The Roast Duck and BBQ Pork Noodle was not bad. The BBQ Pork and Roast Duck was very good but the noodles was more on the over done.   Price wise, you can expect to pay a premium just because it's in a casino. If you must have Chinese food and don't want to head to Spring Mountain Blvd, this place will do for your quick fix.

5CX68UhDUsVThdxTaQAzLA.text: I was at the sports book in the Venetian.  My team was up by 20 points with 5 minutes to play, so started scrolling through Yelp ordered by distance.  Skipped over Noodle Asia, right at the top, because of the mediocre rating.   Scrolled through about 100 other places, either with 2 to 3 stars,  or,  if rated higher,  entrees were like $48.  Nothing sounded worth it, so went out to catch the bus.  But on the way to the restroom,  there was Noodle Asia,  packed with Chinese diners,  with bustle and flair,  and one of my fave dishes, pork & duck noodle soup, for $12.95.   This IS the Strip.  That IS a decent price on the Strip.  Didn't wait to get seated, just went to the bar seats facing the kitchen.  Ordered in two minutes, and three minutes later came the soup (they are all hustling SUPER fast and competent there).  The broth was tasty,  the noodles had great definition and were perfectly toothy,  and there were huge, plentiful hunks of succulent pork and duck.   Totally, totally enjoyable and worthwhile.   Paying the bill took seconds.  5 stars because:  so quick,  so tasty,  such a huge pile of delish pork & duck,  so efficient,  great atmosphere,  genuine feel - - and, also: location, location, location!  [The guy next to me had a chicken dish.   Loads and loads of lumps of chicken.  I felt sorry for him, but then again, I loathe chicken.  The other dishes I saw coming out also looked a bit simplistically meat-heavy.  But I was super happy with my noodle bowl.]

ILqt4x-tUsKFQb_F7za2hw.text: The food here is a little overpriced for the caliber of food that they serve. The flavor was pretty good but I found that their steak in their "chef's Special" Beef Medallions was extremely fatty and chewy. As if the chef didn't think the dish was special enough to trim off the parts that did not have good texture. Texture in this case definitely subtracted from the flavor. The sauce was delicious and it went very well with white rice.  The Chow mein noodle dish was excellent. The beef was thinly sliced, not fatty. It was not as good as the chinese food that I am familiar with in San Francisco's Chinatown, but I suspect that since many people may not really be accustomed to top shelf chinese cuisine, I am fairly certain that the cook(s) could care less.   The potstickers were out of this world as was their shrimp dim sum appetizer.  They are very busy here because it is in the middle of the Venetian Hotel. Therefore, they really may not care that much as I can see the wait staff were racing around non-stop. It was a nice experience, the staff were all very kind, clean and professional although a tad understaffed according to the anxious energy output and equally anxious non-verbal cues that they were indeed overwhelmed.   I am not sure overwhelmed staff pairs well with underwhelming food but I give them 4 stars altogether. I will give the benefit of the doubt along with a %20 tip but if I come here in the future, they will need to step up their game.

LQCACZRWhlwccbBQ6GYoTw.text: Noodle Asia used to be one of our favorite place to get won ton min on the strip inside Venetian Hotel over the years.   Today however it wasn't the same. The quality of the food has gone down a little. The noodles were clump together. It was still good but just wasn't top notch. Well, maybe it was one of those things in life. I hope to return and give it another try in the future.

p7L7W8acq1y-phr_Q5-fPw.text: What do you expect from a place with a simple name like noodle asia? I wasn't expecting much honestly.  But a few of my friends vouched hardcore that it was authentic.    So I gave them a shot.  We ordered a few appetizers, a congee, and a few other entrees.  I don't remember anything specifically, but everything was solid.    The service was actually fast and good.

jlbRWb4GQF-Wfg6wqVwtZQ.text: Now it's been many years since I first ate here with my ex.  That relationship didn't last but this restaurant is STILL here!!  And it's a decent place to eat at.  Now many people would ask, "Why not just go to Spring Mtn Rd?"  Well, you can.  But if you are tired or trying to save time, you may as well just eat here or the sister restaurant in Palazzo.  Because it'll take you 20 min to call the Uber to pick up and then $10 to get you to Chinatown.  So sometimes it's just easier to gulp down some noodles right in your hotel.  (btw the dry stir fried beef noodles is better at Hong Kong Cafe next door in Palazzo...)

wVA43V-7bQkYKRZ6MQ3H9Q.text: One of my favorite Asian places on the strip that's fairly priced and has quick service.  We came here for a quick "snack" and left satisfied as usual. We opted for the soy sauce chicken, bbq pork, yang chow fried rice, Shanghai noodles,  and shu mai. maize. Is came out pretty quick and everything was pretty tasty. The flavors were right on and was not heavy at all.  This place has always been consistent and still keeps it up.

vyYXYky94iHxxt8CWY_YDg.text: Call me crazy but I'm obsessed with their spicy ying nan noodles (sp?). Every time I visit Las Vegas I have to eat there. I rave about it all the time. I stumbled upon this restaurant back in 2011 when me and my friends stayed at Palazzo. I was hungry and wanted to eat so I went on my own wandering off to look for food #fatkidstatus because all of my friends were tired or drunk lol  the noodles just hit the spot and its been hitting the spot ever since.

Li8Vl5-Ba6hJythAUnwakg.text: Went to this place while my stay at Venetian! I had vegetable soup while I went for lunch and it was good - though it's bland so you need to add lot of chili and soya sauce if you like bit more flavored! I also went at this place in dinner! Food was good but service was  very bad - we ordered beer and the person who bought the beer just dumped it on the table without even keeping properly the beer in front of the person it belonged! Food though was fine!

ZICNAKWqXikisoglNw2iUw.text: Okay chinese food found in venetian hotel.  Order the beef lo-mein, pork and special preserved egg congee, pot stickers, cantonese style fried rice, szechwan beef noodle soup.  Prices are pretty pricy for asian food but what do you expected if ordering food from hotel, everything is priced up.    Best thing about this place was the location since it was in venetian and I was staying in the venetian.  Didn't have to walk to far to get there.  Will probably come back to eat here when staying at the venetian or plazzo.
