HWqhXXFMKyy0QyLCu0eUFg.text: Honestly it is so damn hard to find a descent Asian place to eat near Palazzo. Why?! We just wanted Korean food and walked to Ginseng 3 which is apparently closed for renovations so we walked back to our hotel and came here.  It's right in the casino by the poker room and although it was really busy we got seated right away (small party) and was greeted fairly promptly. Our food came out much faster than my expectations and also exceeded my taste expectations! We ordered the schezuan beef soup and chick mushroom vegetable soup which both hit the spot. AND THEY HAVE ASAHI HOORAY!! The beef soup was so salty though and thank goodness I asked for less spicy... Overall pretty cheap and easy option to those staying at the hotel!! Not quite sure if it's worth the travel if you're elsewhere.  Bon appetit!!

tPtN8_veN1y4Vq_XekduEA.text: I think the prices have gone up and the quality has gone down since I was last here (last summer). I think it's pretty middle of the road now. It's decent Chinese food with Vegas pricing. It was previously good Chinese food with subVegas pricing.   Then again, we split a dish of beef flat rice noodles, some siu mai and drinks and it only cost $34 bucks so I guess that's not bad in the grand scheme of things.  It just didn't taste as good as we remember :(

qX4DXtgWOsDU9hCWtUgckQ.text: Delicious Pho! Good for the soul after eating all the buffets in Vegas. Priced just right being inside the Venetian. Ambient is a little too noisy being next to the casinos but who cares!

sH2sCS8UgXA_fOj2Lp2cDQ.text: After a lonnnnng day of walking, the husband and I decided to get some Egg Drop Soup. Since it was late and we were staying at Planet Hollywood, we got it to go. If you ask me, it's a pretty brave thing to ask for SOUP to go after 9PM and you have to make a long walk back to your hotel. But, the husband managed to get the soup back to the room safely.  We paid less than $10 for the "bowl" size and honestly, it was big enough to fill us both up for the night. While it took awhile for them to get the soup to us (it was pretty busy), the workers were still pretty attentive and helpful to us, even if we were hanging out outside. The guy who packed our soup taped down the lid and make sure to include spoons and napkins (major plus for caring)!  The soup itself? DELICIOUS. It was exactly what we needed to comfort us after a long day.  Next time we go we're definitely coming back for the Egg Drop Soup here!

qBwto-BuIOSh9UwUrr8Y4Q.text: Good food but had to ask for Mushrooms on my Chicken & Vegetable Noodles. Only came with green and red peppers...no carrots, broccoli, or anything...The Hot and Sour soup is some of the best I've had! The noodles were cooked perfect. I would recommend this place out of all the restaurants in the Venetian...good value

fVRJGsd6V7PClReBr8z77Q.text: When we I got there I would like to say is quite excited but when are hostess came she was really rude she started off by yelling at us to stand in a line to the side which was kinda weird and the people in the line were rude and kept on yelling and it was making us uncomfortable are hostess also was seating people before us that weren't before us in the line when we sat down are waitress was nice but was ignoring when we ran out of water and ignoring some of are requests the food overall was okay the overall experience was awful

2xxUB-Dtm9UH1H71zNAn7Q.text: Food- 5/5 Probably as authentic as you're gonna find in Vegas  Value- 3/5 Definitely not cheap chinese food.   Ambiance- Nothing special  Service- No complaints  DISHES TASTED  Red Won Tons- 4/5 Good flavor  Szechwan Beef- 5/5 AMAZING. One of the best beef noodle soup I've had in the US.  Shanghai Noodle- 3/5 Nothing special

bmHouToe6xE5j_tOfPOWzQ.text: Except for location, this place is really just so so. Tried soup dumpling and char-siu and roasted duck with rice. Just like most HK fast food restaurants, vegetables were not fresh at all.  There are definitely much better choices in Chinatown!

8YlC1eEdoELBPHDGwJlaUA.text: I really like this place for food. The wait staff are usually unfriendly but they do bring the delicious soup.   The dumplings rate up there with the best. My go to here is the BBQ pork & duck soup. It's rich and steaming and you won't find any better on the strip. After a long day this is the perfect stop before heading to the room.

ilbImZjW1knru9xXe_nSsA.text: Not bad of a place to dine when you are craving Asian food after a long night of party/clubbing or gambling. It is right next to the big screen tv/sports betting area and you can watch sports while you eat through the huge glass windows.  I wasn't sure what to expect but was pleasantly surprised with their food.  Schezuan Beef Noodle Soup- Very good! I like it just as much as the places in Rowland or SGV! Chewy noodles with a dark beefy soy/vinegary broth and lots of tender beef chunks. The only thing is i wish it had some MORE greens in it than the skimpy green onions. Perhaps some cilantro/onion and the chopped pickled mustard greens or bokchoy like the other places. Overall delicious but the soup gets hella salty towards the end be warned.  Spicy Ying Nan Noodle Soup- NOT spicy at all. Tastes pretty bland. Its not seafood broth or chicken or beef broth. Can't really distinguish what the base taste is. Even with 2 generous scoops of Chili sauce it wasn't really spicy. I would skip this next time, however other people liked it.  Hot and Sour Soup- Loved it! I was wary since some reviews say it is not good but we liked it alot! Good balance of sour in my opinion and lots of toppings  Pho Special- $18 for a bowl of Pho better be good and it was according to my fellow Vietnamese diners! So if you can't make it to Pho Kim Long, here is a back up! (Another Pho back-up would be ordering the "Zen Noodles" at Grand Lux Cafe)   Overall, i wouldn't go out of my way to come here but if you staying in the Venetian and can't make it out to Chinatown but crave some asian food, Noodle Asia will do!

ORBiVI4brjw58DWcmA7IsA.text: I had the misfortune of getting sick right before my Vegas conference, so I searched for somewhere with some soup without paying an arm and a leg.  Caesar's had a Chinese restaurant serving soup, but I didn't feel like paying $15 to $20 for a bowl, and then I remembered hearing about Noodle Asia's Won Ton Soup.  I went there for a late lunch during a week day, and it took a while before anybody sat me, even though the restaurants wasn't crowded.   I did get my order taken quickly, though, and the food came out within a few minutes.  I ordered the Won Ton soup (no noodles), and it was slightly bland but soothing.  The won tons were really good, though I wish they didn't have shrimp in them since I'm allergic.  The bowl was about $8.  It took forever to flag someone down to get a check, but I was satisfied with my meal.

HzvvehzZquxNXrs0hfhUtQ.text: More like 3 1/2. I ate there the other day, while on a break from the convention I was attending. Service was quick and friendly, if a little brisk. The chicken wings were excellent and crisply fried but after eating a few bites of the orange chicken I felt like I've been dipped in garlic. This meal exhausted my garlic allotment for the second half of 2015...I love Chinese food but there weren't many option on the menu and it wasn't cheap.  The Thai iced tea was lovely and I would give Noodle Asia another shot.

2oiyq22sqTNsfGROMQp0_Q.text: They didn't want us to pay! We had a group of 10 and got our food and drinks quickly, but then were were quickly forgotten...some even went across to another bar to get a second round of drinks. Half eaten entrees sat out on the table for 30+ min while we waited on someone to bring us a check. We were ignored and eventually had to chase someone down to pay, then again to correct overcharging for items. It was an extremely bizarre experience all the way around.   Vegetarian options are very limited and my shrimp dish had only 4 shrimp for a TON of noodles. Several people enjoyed their meals at our table, but more people did not. (Supposedly the chicken fried rice is about as bland as you can get.)   Not recommended...there are surely better Asian options in Vegas.

0Pjjt2BX3kAvo1tw5WiJ3w.text: After reading other reviews I'm just going to say, um HELLO of COURSE they put MSG in their food. What good Chinese place doesn't? Why do you think it tastes so good?! If you don't want greasy-MSG-injected food, go have a salad or something. But whatever, you're probably on vacation so you should just go for it and work out when you get home. Or do a few laps up and down the strip. Anyway, I thought this place was one of the best noodle houses I've been to in Vegas. The BBQ pork and roast duck noodle soup was sooo good. So good....

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. BBQ pork and roast duck noodle soup

CjVjK62F3au-aTBk9DluWw.text: Went here tonight for dinner and was highly disappointed!  Egg drop soup had absolutely no flavor.  Barbecue pork was good but it was brought to the table  in seconds of ordering and and it was warm.  Potstickers had no flavor whatsoever and covered it massive amounts of oil.  Lettuce wraps were tasty and that is why I am rating 1-star.

UQdX8dSvpvpdqUnWJZH7Dw.text: Over-priced and poor quality taste. The Kung pao chicken was sweet in spite of being marked as spicy. The fried rice was fine. Overall, a very dissatisfactory experience. Will never come here again. Nor should you.

BmUirohDw-Oa3AtPdV2biw.text: This restaurant is A-OK. It isn't the best but it is not the worst. I think the price is pretty high for what they give you but then again, it is located inside of the Venetian. It's just your average Chinese food spot, so if you are craving Chinese.. go somewhere off the strip to save yourself a few bucks.

0Uwe6s5pISSp8PRU4TxURw.text: This is one of the cheapest and most authentic places for Chinese on the Strip.  It's conveniently located and the dishes come out fast.  I had a variety of the soup noodles and the congee.  After tax and tip, it came out to be less than $30 for two dishes.    I've been here on separate occasions with family b/c my parents prefer to eat Chinese and I've had no complaints.

e6cB9WzjeVGiQnqR3ro4OA.text: Hey, not bad.  I was actually dreading coming here initially. A huge group of us just flew in to Vegas and now we're starrrrving. We wanted a place closeby, and somehow we stumbled upon it.   I'm happy to say my food was not drenched in tons of oil or MSG, like usual Asian restaurants! The portions are deceiving, too... it doesn't look like a lot, but it's filling! Especially noodles, since they're carbs.  I recommend the spicy peanut noodles. I'm a sucker for those... definitely not as good as the ones in the bay area, but not complaining. I split it with my friend actually, and it didn't seem like enough, but after a few minutes of sitting around waiting for the check, I felt satisfied.   I didn't get to try any of the soup noodles, but they all looked pretty good. Seemed like everyone enjoyed their food... lots of leftovers, too!

gARqS7mcONPiXI5bS4j5kw.text: I love Noodle Asia!  V E G A S  T R A D I T I O N Every time the BF and I come to Vegas, Noodle Asia is ALWAYS one of our stops. The restaurant is open late (until 3am, I believe), which is a huge plus after a long night of gambling or partying. The food is delicious, and I'm not talking about when you're drunk and any food you shove into your mouth tastes like heaven.   B E E F  N O O D L E  S O U P If you like your soups spicy, order the beef noodle soup. The BF and his friends ALWAYS order this dish when they're here. Sensitive to spicy foods, that's okay! Give their BBQ Pork Fried Rice a try. So, I normally order the fried rice, and the BF shares a portion of the beef noodle soup with me. Those two dishes together make for the best combination, EVER!

50xVjvqYcRMs3w6hA0-wHw.text: During my stay in Vegas, I went twice to this location so that should tell you if I liked it or not and here's what I thought about it...  PROS:  1. Food- full of flavor and seemed fresh.  They offered a good selection of entrees. 2. Staff- friendly and somewhat fast service. 3. Ambience- not too upscale, not rundown, but juuuust right. 4. Value- It's Vegas and the Venetian! Lol, but considering that, it wasn't too pricey. 5. Hours- I loved this place because it's one of the restaurants that close the latest.  Afterall, it is Vegas and you don't want dinner too late in the morning lol.  By the way, they usually close at 3 a.m.  CONS:  1. Location- If you're not staying at the Venetian, it will be a little hike to get to the restaurant, but it might just be worth it (especially if you love Chinese food). 2. Pricing- I mentioned it above, but if you're looking for a low-cost meal, this isn't the place to go to.  You'll probably spend around $50-$100 for a full course meal for two (including tip and depending on how inebriated you might be).

mIhE8FzABrRzXwa66F4IpA.text: Had the seafood soup. Was okay. The portion size was perfect. It was better then a lot of other seafood soups I have had.

8m5p1nW3yQJMkJPWOwogrg.text: You will get a huge bowl but a little noodle inside. I ordered pai goo noodle which supposed to be noodle with short ribs. But there is no ribs, only some fried meat.

LAhwr6qxwPeOXupcpPnzPA.text: Service: 4 stars Food: 4 stars  Every time I come to Vegas I go to Noodle Asia. I'm not saying it's the best chinese food ever, but it's definitely a restaurant I crave and love. The food is actually pretty tasty and authentic, and the service is pretty good. I love their noodle dishes (XO with Shrimp and pepper beef), and also their chinese broccoli with garlic sauce. Their dishes are more on the oily side, though. Also, the prices are definitely high for what you're getting, but that's probably because the restaurant is in the Venetian hotel. Overall, it meets my craving for some good Chinese food!

arRJ-xpyh05RLEgbAMvvUw.text: We went in for quick lunch during expo thinking the wait won't be too long as most dishes were Chinese food.  Dim-Sum we had order came out right away which was good (but bit pricey for the amount of food came out) but the noodle dishes we had order took another 30 minutes before it came out which I didn't understand why it took so long, especially when the restaurant was nearly half empty.   I had ordered Singapore mei-fei which was salty and all noodles were broken as it was over-cooked. My co-worker ordered Vietnamese noodle soup which was good but the side condiments which needs to go into the soup came out 5 minutes AFTER the we had started eating. No point of having them at all. Chicken noodle soup was the worst of all. Soup was bland and not very tasteful, noodles were extremely over-cooked that it was mushy. It seem like it was made awhile ago. Co-worker took 3 bites and couldn't eat anymore. Both noodle soups were just warm, not good when you were expecting nice hot soup.  Price was OK considering Vegas and its location but I had so much better food at much lower price. I don't think I'll be coming back here.

oRS7L0so0lcz9kT_wPbzmw.text: My go to spot for comfort when in Vegas.  Came here on a Thursday at 2:30am and service was still good.  I always go with the duck and roast pork noodle soup, never fails.  I'm always satisfied with this spot, you can't compare prices here and complain it's too expensive, you in Vegas.

ndsX6_lJVoIiXg_E0ejTVg.text: The best chinese food , price is ok and food is delicious. I really love their BBQ pork. All dish come with reasonable price

qJh0-9M73q0GPLTDFKrVVA.text: We ordered the bbq fried rice, beef and broccoli and soy chicken. The fried rice and beef and broccoli were just ok. The soy chicken came out cold and it was more bone than meat. Every piece we bit into had a piece of bone in it. My boyfriend and I are black listing the Venetian on our places to visit because the 3 restaurants we ate here were disappointing. Especially when you're spending a lot of money because the restaurants here gauge your wallet. We even had to push our dinner reservations back later because I felt nauseous after words and took some nauzene. Never again.

EHQYvdWj9fQgIm44hkNUIQ.text: Amazing fried rice, Shanghai noodles! And best of all: Vietnamese Iced Coffee (must try)!!!

0UqOQshP47TYT5Q3u-HlwQ.text: We had hot and sour soup, the Szechuan beef noodle soup and the bbq duck & pork with rice.  Typically I hate hot and sour for being too tangy but the soup here even I would eat. The beef noodle soup was hot and salty with chewy noodles. Everything about it was amazing except for the beef.. kindof chewy. The bbq duck & pork was yum as well, it came with steamed bok choy on the side.  Open late for your late night soup noodle cravings! Mm.....

56KdoMvlr6VEFYsuyVb9qQ.text: This place is the bomb, people. If you want either 1) very authentic chinese food or 2) a very reasonably priced hot meal - this is your place! It is inside the Venetian near the poker room.   -If you don't know want to get but want to keep it delicious and simple: go with the fried rice or a chef's specialty (i.e. Kung Pao)  -If you want to be a real ass mandarin: get some rice porridge or a noodle bowl  price point: $12-20 closes @ 3am

wkqsro8xHTs4VXxTZfxDeg.text: The Crab Rangoon was cold inside and had to be sent back. They also didn't serve it with sauce the first time. The chicken was rubbery. Service was slow and not friendly. With so many great places to eat in Vegas I doubt they will stay open long. We would definitely NOT go back.

Ol2xQ0IjLVHbaKUE2ucMhw.text: Legit, affordable, authentic Chinese joint in Vegas. Great for rice dishes w/ bbq and hot noodles/ noodle soups after the club. I get real nostalgic for these dishes because it's the stuff I ate growing up! Real Chinese food AND it's the best hangover prevention! I had the wonton noodle soup, and it piping hot and delicious. My friend let me try some of her sliced rice cakes, and they were PERFECT. Would definitely be back. Highly recommend.

GChPtSxkZVoSaPctBhKYgg.text: This was our first meal in Vegas after a long flight from the east coast. I enjoyed the room decor and the speed of the service. 3 solid stars going to food; Nothing stood out. ordered Szechuan spicy beef soup. The soup was very rich and flavorful but there was deF MSG in it as i battled unquenchable thirst and headache hours after...

mQC2C9fIiF4nCWh264KpRA.text: REALLY bland food. I had the egg rolls which were virtually tasteless.  No Chinese mustard served, so there was no way to spice them up. The Dan Dan noodles had a little spice but were pretty boring.

LBISjz3EAa429RENMsN9QQ.text: Place was actually really good the only complaint I have about it was the sports book was right next to it so the smell of cigars is a little rough to eat around. But all and all the food came out the fastest I've ever seen from any restaurant ever and it was delicious

L8XrMWjfVabuppjXWJtzsQ.text: i've had this bookmarked for years so was happy when we went here. we were staying at the palazzo so it was a quick walk over. we had a group so we shared a bunch of things.  -curry fish balls -mapo tofu -beef noodle soup -curry beef brisket soup -congee  everything was pretty good so i'll be back next time

Jwv6zLLWNrZ2u0IcTTWyFw.text: Probably the best beef noodle I've tasted in the whole North American. It's beyond the question of authenticity, it's the way you suppose to enjoy the Chinese beef noodles. Can't say anything about other food. Highly recommended the beef noodles!

gY97-zpkftZL0Sn66ZEG2g.text: I have to say this place has the best Chinese food in town. The food are real Chinese food not just American Chinese food. Chinese must try! We can comp our food but we still come here just for the god food!

Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pot stick. Soooo good.

j_WKkyasK0FPWac22habaw.text: I love this place go there every time I am in town just haven't gotten around to write a review. Food is a tad bit on the higher side but taste wise it is right on the money. Service can be a bit slow on a weekend lunch time. This is what I love on the menu  Fire house chicken wings Shanghai style noodles  Wonton soup  King pao shrimp or chicken  Seafood fried rice Dim Sum

XiC51nFTlZdguA8n3-VrHw.text: The food is so so, however it is definitely overpriced!!! One noodle plus one fried rice cost $45? Must be kidding!!!

fu97moAWzkTm2izZldQpCA.text: I've been coming to Las Vegas often because of my work. One of must stop by is this restaurant.  The food is very authentic considering its inside Venetian with all the gambling going on. It's one of the best noodle house I've been too. Their shrimp wonton is really good. I also like their porridge.  It's a simple menu but it's all good. They even have kimchi. One of the reason I can't give them 5 stars is because of their service.  It's a busy restaurant  and it's open late, I guess the employees are tired but the services is little slow and non communicative.  But overall the food is solid. The price is little expensive for noodles but you are in Venetian, the rent must be outrageous.

nPevqYMuLTHm5UG_TF-c2g.text: Yuck!! Disgusting Chinese food ever!!!!! Ordered Buddha toasted noodle!! So light almost no flavor at all!!! Never come back!!!!

lqdSjq1d9agh8VttkSK7Fg.text: Wished I could have given it more stars but the taste of the food really was very average. The Cantonese beef stew was no entirely the most flavorful nor did it taste much like beef stew.  Just salt oil and some salt.

dZ4cg-vqY1rnOCJhhz-JMg.text: I would highly recommend this restaurant if you would like to try something real Chinese.

YN35sDOdd_bwhNNUymBWJg.text: Let ne start with me saying that the food is great but the service was horrible. The busser spilled hot water all over my back and my coat that was resting on the back of the chair. Instead of apologizing or helping to clean he pretended like nothing happened and walked away. We then told the waitress and she didnt seem to care at all either. She was actually more concerned about cleaning the floor so no one trips and sues them than to apologize or help me dry my shurt or coat. If i ever come back it will definitely be to go.

JlSCks9aCF6E328s1IL93w.text: I've been here several times and have tried many of their dishes and must say Noodle Asia is probably one of the better noodle bars in Vegas. I highly recommend the Chinese sausage fried rice, minced pork dish, roasted duck, and bbq pork. Their dishes are authentic for the most part. Definitely the place to eat Chinese food if you are on that part of the strip.

3Wprxilwxy4r2hbQQfsbQA.text: The staff is nice, well at least my waiter was ok. He tried. Food...ehhh... Mmh not so good. Only thing good is that it's open till really late so I guess it's convenient. I got the easiest thing which was chicken fried rice. Chicken tastes so fake. Didn't taste like chicken. The rice was hard and just very mediocre. Ordered egg drop soup. Had no flavor. After flooding it with hot Saudi and soy it got a little better. Very average. I'm being nice giving it 3 stars.

AQW3D5EaHoi02m-z4VR37A.text: Blehhhh, blehhhh, blehhhhh! I did not like this place at all!  Ordered the chicken fried rice, yuckkk!  I had them take it back, I ended up replacing it with the chicken lettuce wraps, thankfully they were good and much better than my other dish but I've had better lettuce cups.  If your in Vegas, skip this place there are so many other good places to visit.  Even the other people in our party said their food was bland and they had to drench it in the hot sauce to make it taste good. =(

7K6g7cElqjxr_d57BrJ6Ig.text: Yelp discussions are all like: Is this the best noodle house east of Taipei? Is this as cheap as the noodle joint in your Chinatown?  WHAT THE F IS WRONG WITH YOU?  Did you just come out of Tao nightclub at 2am? Did you just gamble on The Venetian floor as "Tainted Love" blared from the ceiling? Are you in the middle of the Western US desert, at one of the most heavily touristed venues in the world?  All told it's remarkable that you can get a totally legit bowl of noodles (for your first visit, have the Szechuan Beef Noodle, it's perfectly delicious) up until 3am, right at the Venetian. I suspect it's not the best-tasting or the most reasonably-priced bowl of noodles you'll ever have in your life, but compared to other post-nightclub eats (bacon-wrapped hot dogs in LA? super-greasy "hidden pizza" at The Cosmopolitan?) at post-midnight hours, this place really is a stand-out, and a rather well-staffed treat.  Recommended.

vAd4hHEi81kPM8b8zwNCqQ.text: Came here after partying wanted some noodle soup to cure the buzz!  Food is pretty good but prices are expensive (but in fairness your eating in the Venetian Casino.) Ordered Szechwan beef noodle soup ( the beef is super tender and there like chunks not strips of meat. The orange chicken is tasty it's not battered and they use chicken breast. The fire house chicken wings were a good  choice for appetizers as well as the garlic baby bak choy.  Would Like to come back to try other things when I come back to the Venetian.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

jqzRIbSsH_4IV1C2MG4Uaw.text: This place is pretty good and the prices aren't bad especially when it's paid for with poker comps!  My favorites are the Dan Dan noodles and the red wontons.   Only gripe is that sometimes the noodles in the noodle dishes get over-cooked from sitting too long. Gotta eat fast!  Service is friendly and pretty quick.  Open late!

Ml5dZRO5HvY82khIIPV7jA.text: This place was bomb! Not sure if it had anything to do with dancing all night or drinking a Fat Tuesday but it was good and the only place open in that hotel but Tao. Got jasmine tea, noodles and rice I believe. This was over ahead ago.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Very good

3Da1_wZgwVj1O8hg4oUyEw.text: I have to admit...I was fairly impressed that you could actually find decent Asian food at a hotel eatery.  I used to think that these joints were only offered by hotels as a way to satisfy their Asian clientele from overseas.  I mean, all those old Asian guys gotta find something to remind them of home while they take a break from Pai Gow right?  Prices are a bit steep relative to normal Asian places, but obviously there's going to be a premium for being where you're at.  They're probably betting that you're not going to go out somewhere off the strip in search of cheaper Chinese food in that desert heat.  And being a casino, they're taking the smart bet.  At least they don't cheat you on your order; portions are still pretty respectable.  For an appetizer, we grabbed the Spicy Tofu dish off the little menu card in those plastic holders on the table. I was expecting to get cubes, but it turned out to be thin slices off a tofu block that had been stir fried and then triangled. There were approximately 10 slices or so, and the whole thing was spiced up wtih chili oil sauce.  Taste was pretty good and there was certainly a bit of kick, but there had to be just based on the amount of that oil on the plate.  Seriously, I imagine a little part of health freaks would die if they saw this dish (i wonder if I should even bother calling it a "sauce").    The Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup (Niu Lo Mein?...not sure of the spelling) was touted by one of my friends as possibly the best he's ever had outside of Taiwan (and apparently, one of the the spiciest based on the beads of sweat rolling down his head).  Three of the four of us ended up getting it based on how much he kept talking about the dish (my other friend ordered the Cantonese Beef Stew instead).  The broth was flavorful and it didn't seem too bad with the sodium level.  Certainly no worse than the average bowl of pho.  There were some good size chunks of meat to go with the noodles, so it certainly will help get you full.  Not too bad of a find for a hotel eatery, especially if you want to lay off some of that rich food in the buffet.  Three stars if only because I can't afford to give one more after all these inflated prices.  That said, it's still probably one of the more cost effective meals you can find, so you could do worse in that regard.  And btw, that broth really isn't all that spicy, so I don't think you have to worry about sweating like my friend.

Hzd2IyYsprVuE2YnBl51CA.text: we recently visited due to a word of mouth referral and online reviews.  The service was prompt to take drink/food orders but very slow to service the table once food was served.  I had to ask 2 people for a refill and the 2nd server said to tell our server cause we weren't his tables.  I finished my food before my refill came.  Our server promptly came back for payment.

oUX9LLLqP0pqvziI3cxfZA.text: Woooooow... how you gonna cook my bean sprouts?! Apparently this is how Chinese people do pho but how you gonna charge me $18 and cook my bean sprouts, limit my hoisin sauce and sriracha, and not give me sliced onions with vinegar?!   3 stars for a "decent" bowl of pho. Don't expect anything extravagant. The meat selection is weird and not your usual raw beef and brisket. Tripe was like a slice of small stomach. The meatballs were good though but I'm used to a higher ratio of brisket and raw meat vs. meat balls.   You get desperate when you're hung over in Vegas.

CSngPBu5gsfTP34GU-Jbcg.text: We had a Hotel credit so why not make use of it.  We we're seated fairly quickly and waitress was pretty helpful, but in a rushly mannered. Food wise it was okay. I would reccomnded the noodle dishes over the rice. The wonton dumpling soup had very nice amounts of delicious dumplings, however the broth could use a bit more flavor, same as for the shrimp Fried rice. The bbq pork and roasted duck with rice was good, but needed more meat. Overall for a westerner aspect it is really good, but from an eastener okay and pricy.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted duck soup
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bbq char sui pork and roasted duck.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Very good dummplings

k2nqVZ0Pqogf8CQX8BInxw.text: Long wait and nothing special about the food from Noodle Asia. Service is slow and waitress was rude. Everytime we asked a question to the waitress her attitude was that she was so high above everyone else, and was simply answering our question just because she wants to get paid.  We had the Hot and Sour soup, Beef fried rice, and the BBQ Pork and Duck.  The Hot and Sour soup was pretty good, tasted like all the other chain Chinese restaurants here in Canada.  The Beef fried rice was also pretty good, well seasoned, nice beef taste  The BBQ Pork and Duck I was very disappointed with. The first bite I took was greeted with a million sharp shards of bones. Both the Pork and Duck were really dry, and of course served with some even drier rice.  Another problem is the rice to meat ratio. You can tell this restaurant does not care about details or quality when they just shoved about 3 bowls of rice onto a plate topped with a couple pieces of meat. I'm not complaining about the meat, I would have rather they  not give me a bunch of rice which I am not going to eat. I am Asian and when you eat meat with your rice you usually take a bite of the meat, and a spoonful of rice. Well that's what I did (the meat and rice were very dry I had to drink a cup of water after each bite) and I did not even finish half the rice, not even a quarter.  Very disappointed, wasn't worth the 30 minute line outside for food I could have gotten at a chain Chinese restaurant.

45c7NMc3miih-uiCoDX6Eg.text: This is a review for the service and the speed with which they attend to their customers.  Among the WORST I have ever experienced.  If you choose this place make sure you have eons to wait for what is essentially mediocre food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. We&#39;re all for spending big bucks in Vegas for good food.  Save your money and go elsewhere.

ajLvrz1RPBwpSts_BHSXEg.text: For Chinese food in Vegas, Noodle Asia is fairly decent for noodle/soup-ish related items (China Grill at Mandalay Bay is better for other dishes I think). The won ton soup is pretty good-- nice flavors and whatnot, though I do think all the dishes here are a bit overpriced. But hey, it's Vegas, where everything is grossly overpriced.  Service is also a little bit slow for some things. Especially for big groups, it would be nice if all the food could come out at the same time, rather than having some people wait extra time.  Location wise, it's right in the middle of the Venetian, next to the casino floor, and we probably would not have come here if it was not for the fact that we were staying at the Venetian and it was convenient and it was soupy.  tl;dr: Yummy soups and noodles, but a bit pricey for what you're getting (though I don't know why you would be expecting something cheap...)

9cgUuKeRnIUZ5NwPNA_5VA.text: This restaurant is beautifully designed, nice and open. I'm a little disappointed with the food though. I had vegetable soft noodles that was kind of like lo mein. It wasn't very flavorful, and could have used a little something extra. My girlfriend had the Pho and the meat was not that great but the broth was pretty good she claims. Overall, I may not come back here next time I visit the Venetian.. I would probably look for another restaurant

sFfHD9H_IdNMpP_hv_654w.text: Loved this place and the prices are really good for the strip.  We had noodle dishes with a wonderful smoky sauce.  We will be back.

789sFL-PAWOAmk24L51iQg.text: Service:  Very good.  Propmt and pleasant. Food:  Polar opposite, and simply said, very poor.   Lettuce wraps passable, but the chicken fried rice and egg flower soup was absolutely flavorless...I mean shockingly FLAVORLESS...the water with lemon had more flavor.  I will NOT be returning to this establishment.

2emYDKTls_VQ5YRoWWm5hg.text: When the Host was surly and unfriendly we should have taken the clue and walked away -fast. Unfortunately we did not and had one of the worst Asian meals ever. The waiter was in a hurry and very unhelpful The endamame was soggy and barely edible The pineapple fried rice was bland  The fried vege noodles was poor the appetizer was the last thing to come The waiter never refilled our water The only good thing we had was-no dessert  Just say no to this terrible piece a.....  What a disappointment!

OWUTl075r0IBT1cpQOzQvw.text: Not so bad for hotel Chinese at a resort like the Venetian...Best Chinese on the strip; must go to Spring Mountain Road for better.  No Walnut Honey Prawns, but a good menu of real Chinese dishes mixed in with stuff non-Chinese could believe was Chinese. We had four kids and a Nanny and they made room for us. Magnificent red gloss painted trim.   Remodel bumped out big windows to see sports bar next door...good for him; not so happy for her; unless she has money on the game.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Awesome red glossy paint...I should know

9hehEA5B_y81o8dTIOaFgQ.text: ZOMG THEY SERVE FRESH YOUNG COCONUT HERE!!! they bring it out in the shell as well. I was super excited about this since i haven't had one in a really really REALLY long time!  ok ... ahem. now onto the noodles!  i had a  seafood rice noodle  here and open at 2am in the morning and eating it with the cashed out earnings from black jack, nothing could of been a sweeter experience. Im so grateful that such a tasty place is open so late at night till 4am i believe. I was so enamored with the place we decided to come back again for brunch the next day. Equally tasty sober or buzzed!  really after a night of fun and looking for something comforting for the tummy this really is the place to come to!  next time i stop in vegas again i'll be sure to swing on by back at anytime.

ExPFhGeqsUBzC7TQzmeqyw.text: Went for lunch on a Wednesday. Had the hot and sour soup which was good. It had a little zip to it and a bit of thick consistency which is how I like it. BBQ pork fried rice was tasty. Service was quick and efficient. Also, they have a baccarat section right outside...probably not a coincidence it's in front of Noodle Asia.

0R4uiPX4Td_pkQqx44TRJQ.text: Came in with a group of six for lunch on a Sunday. Four arrived on-time; we were waiting on two to arrive, but were seated immediately. Submitted our order to the waitress approximately 5-10 minutes after being seated.  1. Pork and egg congee 2. Dandan noodles 3. 2x sichuan beef noodle soup 4. dumpling noodle soup 5. Beef (and peas) over rice with an over-easy egg 6. Chicken Congee (to go)  Conclusions: *Food as a whole was delicious, but not particularly outstanding. *Service was not timely, and some dishes arrived as some of our friends finished theirs. (Namely the sichuan beef noodle soup) *Expect typical exorbitant Las Vegas mark-up on food. (Especially the dimsum) *Restaurant was very clean and provided a good seat for watching the big screens for sports betting.

WFHV_fmWtAi1Dn6R4-eWAg.text: Had the Kung Pao beef here the other night and it was pretty darn good. This place usually has a small line and the prices aren't too bad given the location. It is located right next to the Venetian Sports Book which is always a great place to catch a big game.

UATAZtxevMk2KZqd_bJgmQ.text: Excellent authentic chinese food. I eaten here many times throughout the years. Each time the service been fast and friendly. Food is great.  The combination soft noodle (chow mein) $16 is excellent. Comes with bbq pork, chicken, duck and others I can't remember. The best chow mein i ever tried. Not too oily or overpowering in flavor. Just perfect.   The bbq pork and duck with rice is also great. $12.  The beef noodle also great. I'm not a soup kind of guy but I do remember that soup. Was good.  They have little dim sum items also.   The service is always fast and polite. Sit at the bar. You get to watch the chef in action.   Overall excellent place to get a bite solo or in a group. One of the best chinese restaurant I tried on the strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bbq pork and duck. Combination soft noodles

heP09j8Myursb6-lwvmtNg.text: Visited this restaurant over thanksgiving weekend. The food was ok. Their noodle dishes and beef were pretty delicious, but I wouldn't recommend their seafood dishes. The soup was not the greatest. The servers over that weekend may have been a bit overwhelmed by the crush of people but ours was particularly mean. When we asked her what vegetarian options were available her answer initially was we have none and then she paused and said these two dishes are. Then my friend asked would it be possible to get these dishes just without the meat. Her response it will be the same price.... Thoughts that doesn't answer his question. He was polite and said that's ok. I just want it without the neat. Her response ok ok but still same price... Ok lady we get it. This all did not make a good impression on us. I would not recommend this place to anyone, however their iced coffee is delicious. If you like that sort of thing grab one to go while you explore the casino floor.

tv_MvS_DdkK3PNIL79nh0A.text: Every time my bf and I are in Vegas, we stay at the Palazzo so we can eat here.  Whenever we eat here, I always, always order the spicy ying nan noodles. It's my hangover cure. Besides that, its delicious. It's full of flavor and requires no addition except I like my food spicy so I have to add tons of spice. My bf usually orders the pot stickers and night market fried rice.  I would eat here everyday during our stay in Vegas if I could but of course, the bf wouldn't allow it. He would always have reservations at 5-star restaurants. But this is my go-to place if I was given the choice.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Ying Nan Noodle... HANGOVER CURE!!!

FwQ_be21xX2FQ72WM5fqiw.text: Ate at this place out of convenience since we were at the Venetian sports betting area this past weekend and Noodle Asia was located right next to it all. Overall, it was so so. I had the bbq park and roast duck with rice as well as the wontons and pot stickers. Nothing spectacular but not horrible either. The wontons were too salty. The pot stickers had a good fried crunch on the outside but the meat inside was not that great. Bbq pork was flavorful but the roast duck was just fatty. At least service was quick but a little pricey. But hey, that's expected when it's located inside the Venetian casino. I probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.

4juWVUoT64Q_-ToQNo07vw.text: Nice change of pace from the burgers and greesy foods.  Service is fast.  Flavors are ok, but could use a little more kick.  But if you need something other than american food, this will do.

l3VJ_Krdnt0pPf4wLKB6rQ.text: I didn't have insanely high expectations for this restaurant, as it's located right on the casino floor inside the Venetian. The atmosphere was well done,  and it did have a reasonable selection of traditional and mildly exotic Pan Asian choices.   The food itself was average, though the prices were quite high. We ordered kung pao chicken and orange chicken, and one soda. The bill was over $50.  The portion sizes were large, but the taste was very run of the mill. I don't mind paying extra for quality, but it just wasn't there.   I didn't find the service particularly good either. My entree was brought out  about 10 minutes prior to my wife's without apparent cause, and we had to actively flag down or waitress for a water refill or to get the check.   I don't believe this restaurant would remain in business if not for the convenience factor of its location. There are many,  many other excellent choices in the Venetian complex alone. I personally would have been happier with Panda Express. The food was about the same for a third of the price.

YAeKa32y7i8WngddQUymDA.text: I was very impressed by this place. My dad and I were scrambling to find a decent restaurant that we'd like as we wandered through the Palazzo and the Venetian. And then finally we ended up at Noodle Asia and were quite satisfied.  The prices were understandable since it was inside the Venetian (GORGEOUS hotel by the way) so we were fine with that.  We ordered two dishes, one was the shrimp won ton noodle soup and the other was the bbq pork and roasted duck over rice. They were both DELICIOUS! The taste was very authentic and the portions were a good size.  The only downside to this place is the service. It's pretty sub-par only because it gets really busy and the servers don't really check up on you after the food arrives. They also use tea bags in the teapot which I thought was lame and unauthentic but the food made up for everything else.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

oGMZS6LQ_RJqxHfPFOZIlQ.text: If you enjoy below average noodle dishes this place is for you. We went here thinking it would be a reasonably priced meal before our show and we were less than impressed across the board. Calamari balls appetizer were better suited for playing jacks. The noodles were spectacularly unimpressive. They brought us a plate with basil so wilted we had to ask for some fresh to use for or meal. The only thing good about the whole experience was that it didn't last to long and it has a big window looking out to the sports book. Don't waste your time or your money there's a McDonalds upstairs.

8h0-trhFNmPl2DTOHAPVCQ.text: This place was just ok in my opinion. My family loved their food but i didn't . I ordered sauteed chicken w broccoli and a side with brown rice. My main dish was good but the rice disappointed me , it's dry and some rices were uncooked. I wasted $2 for that bowl of rice. So disappointing and probably never come back!

M_fL3_-EwjteA4AYOwkglg.text: The food here was very good and is authentic asian fusion and not westernized.  The price is a little on the higher side, but the taste of the food made up for it.  The waitress was very helpful in recommending different dishes.  The food came out quickly, but you could tell that the food was cooked with care.  Would definitely come back here again.

5Qwu-LF6Hgyehw9LP3nh8g.text: My husband and I really enjoyed this place. We were seated right away. We had looked at the menu before coming in so we knew what we wanted and ordered right away. I swear our food was at our table in 5 min. It was really good too. I had the Shanghai Noodles and my husband had the black peppered udon. The beef in his was soooo good. We really enjoyed our meal here.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XPAXsQzlOqdrIIWAHhbzdQ.text: Went here twice in two days.  First visit: - service service was very good, they were prompt, attentive. efficient.  - food the schezwan style beef noodle soup is DELICIOUS, especially if you like spicy soups. The soup is slightly spicy, there is an abundance of both meat and tendon, and the noodles are cooked extremely well (cooked through, but still a little chewy)  I was thoroughly impressed, and finished the dish soup and all  - misc. (the rest) the price is a little expensive, but it is on the middle of the strip in the Venetian casino - great location and easy to get to  Second visit: - service still good, but they messed up our order  - food tried to order the schezwan style beef noodle soup, but they brought us the curry beef noodle soup instead... my friend didn't realize but I didn't mind because I had just eaten the beef noodle soup the night before (even though it was so good)  eh.. probably should've sent it back. It was okay, but curry beef noodle soup is not my favorite  - misc. price is similar, and the location is the same  RECAP: - the food was pretty good (the curry beef noodle was okay, the schezwan style beef noodle soup was FANTASTIC) - service (attentive, efficient, fast) - good location, a little pricier because in the Venetian on the middle of the strip  Added picture

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef noodle soup

n4gYy63hrnTtD0WqsHOPLQ.text: Food was horrible.  Stay away!!!  Chicken was like rubber.  Service was bad too.  Can believe the Venetian allow them to serve such bad quality food. Huge let down.

utBTOv349vPErM4BelWSwQ.text: Hidden gem for sure. Every time I'm in Vegas I stop by noodle Asia for a great bite of Chinese food. Service is average but food makes up for it. Definitely worth stopping by!

BYeHn6_-FAxTrL9XwF_2LQ.text: Pretty authentic Chinese food on the strip and it's open late. Better than I expected.   We came in at 2am on a Wednesday. They're open until 3am on Wednesday. It wasn't busy at all and we were seated immediately. The waiter promptly greeted us and made some appetizer suggestions. We went with edamame and red wontons. The edamame was cooked with anise and had a good flavor. Even better when you make a sauce mix from the soy sauce and hot pepper sauce on the table and dip the edamame in it. The red pork wontons were very flavorful too. Very good.  The food came out so quickly and was piping hot. I thoroughly enjoyed my Cantonese beef noodle soup. The noodles were cooked just right, fresh baby bok choy, tender beef and tendon, and hearty broth. Just the way I like it. Yes, it's a little pricy for Chinese food but it's expected being on the strip and located in the gorgeous Venetian hotel and casino.   I wouldn't hesitate to come back for some more noodle soup. Really want to try the schezuan beef noodle soup based on the other Yelp reviews. Next time for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red won tons
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Choice stir fry noodles with chicken.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cantonese beef noodles

7EnuuWYkYmsT5Stm5yJCVQ.text: Very good food at affordable prices Typical Chinese with a limited menu  Food for 5 came at different intervals Good understanding  of English Decor 6/10  Very busy but typical of restaurants in the casino

SDSbedWIUB4DugXMitFZRQ.text: Was really excited about discovering this place on Yelp because we were craving Asian food in Vegas. The hostess greeted us in Chinese, and about 75% or so of the customers were Chinese (and not even American Chinese I think) so I assumed it would be an authentic experience. My boyfriend ordered the Sichuan style beef noodle soup and I ordered a mapo tofu which came with a bowl of Jasmine rice. The noodles came fast since I guess more people order noodle dishes than rice dishes. I had to wait extra 15 minutes or so for mine to come. The noodle soup was actually pretty good; it did tasted like braised meat-based soup I've had in China but maybe the flavor was a bit too intense and salty than what I've had in the past. Still pretty good though; the beef pieces in the soup were too cube-y and thus not very tender. The noodles were good quality but not sure if it was hand-pulled there or they just bought good quality ones that were frozen. The mapo tofu was kind of sweet and Americanized - probably closer to the kind I would get in Japan or Korea rather than in Sichuan. It wasn't bad but I wouldn't order it again. Tofu was also very firm and not silky. Unless you're dying to eat not so authentic but not exactly P.F. Chang style Chinese food, I'd skip this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ieaRHMQ9Xyyle5P876BMQQ.text: One of the more affordable places on the strip. Not the best ambiance since it's right next to the Venetian sports book, but hey it's Vegas. Classically prepared dishes. Had the wonton noodle soup and beef rice noodle. Will continue to visit here.

T5HlHBx8btGDgnT1ZdDFbQ.text: Right outside poker room so I stoped for a quick refill. Food was ok and cheap portions on a large side

-5SfUjPD9xvY5Ye6pr4FRw.text: This place can get pretty crowded during peak hours.  Okay option for late night dining but I wouldn't say for anything else.  I got their Hot and Sour Soup and was not pleased.  It was very watered down, you could tell from just looking at it that the color was a bit off.  The ingredients inside like the pork was a little more slimy than what I would prefer.  I would definitely pass on this soup.   I also got the Chinese Broccoli, which was quickly blanched and topped with oyster sauce.  This was okay, I was glad it wasn't oily.  It was nice and crunchy...not the best, but it was decent.

irzXnbuFxpgx0tqwdlsUTg.text: Authentic BEIJING BEEF NOODLE SOUP as good as the best I have had in Beijing.   Even in Bejing it's hard to find better Bejing Beef Noodle soup than that you can enjoy at Noodle Asia, Las Vegas.

O3LCzUkN-qaDKIJGT9SvbA.text: I hate to do it but I have been to Noodle Asia three times since I've been in town the last few weeks and the service and the food has been subpar. I don't know what has happened since the last time I was here but the long times between beaming seated and placing an order for food and the food being delivered seems entirely too long. Today it took 45 minutes to get 2 shrimp dishes and one was just shrimp fried rice. The place wasn't even packed and it was well after lunch time. For the prices you pay ($15.95 average entree price) the service should be better.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp Fried Rice $15.95  Not what you&#39;d normally expect but VERY tasty. My Favorite Menu Item!
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle Soup with Shrimp and Calamari balls.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6rhl9OtVGMn3nMgnTubJAg.text: A MUST EVERYTIME IN VEGAS!! This little gem is located inside the Venetian and I hardly ever see it super packed.   My friend introduced it to me one summer and said it was the best beef noodle soup she's ever had. I was skeptical at first, and maybe a little drunk too, since we had just come from a pool party. I was exhausted and beyond hungry, so the first time I ever had Noodle Asia's Beef Noodle Soup, I was sold. It was ridiculously good and it definitely hit the spot. Ever since my first time here in the Summer of 2012, I've kept coming back.  I've tried their other dishes (only because someone else orders it haha) such as minced beef over rice, duck over rice, pepper chow mein and potstickers all are very good but nothing compares to their beef noodle soup! It's so hot with a hint of spiciness to it. The beef is tender and oh, the bits of fat connected to the beef is the best! I crave this soup when I'm back in SF. I wish I could have some right now.  It's a bit pricey because it's probably the only asian restaurant on the strip but it's sooo worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab Rangoon
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef noodle soup
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Potstickers

fo3gUZtof-k5ztjxtD1OKw.text: Nothing special, interior is basic and the prices are  way too expensive for what it is.

mSB-cKNKOg-crMC7AyqeIQ.text: This place is really amazing the food is delicious im a big fan of noodle soups ans this place just hit the spot for me if your hung over or just in the mood for some yummy food and noodle soup i would really recommend coming here!

rFw6vRWC35q7DymtVaBQIA.text: This place hits home everytime. The noodles are homemade so you can really taste the freshness and the food comes out piping out. This is a really really delicious place that hits the spot whenever you are craving really good chinese food. The big downside though is the prices are jacked up the wa-zoo, but that's because it IS in the Venetian.  It is open super late so it's a good place after a night of fun...  I've tired their congee, their beef noodle soup, their jelly fish, their tendon, and NOTHING disappoints. I actually crave this place everytime i'm in Vegas.

p-6jcpYeFi_cuQKOrLoLnw.text: Wow... if at the Venetian this is must visit.  All of these dishes were amazingly well prepared  - Seared shrimp chives dumplings - Shiu Mai steamed dumplings - Hot and Sour soup  Reasonable prices  Love this place !  If busy sit at the counter

bPkyX6OqxTGZJGazEjB5Pw.text: I had missed out on the noodle bar at the Red Rock Resort because they wouldn't seat us without all of our people present (sad) so I was happy to find this place when we moved to the Venetian.  We both ate noodle soups (me the vegetarian one). Oh boy, it was good, after all the noodles and veggies were gone I still couldn't get enough of the broth and kept spooning it into my mouth.  I wanted to go back the next day but hubby didn't want to eat at the same place twice.  It reminded me of the noodle soups we had in Thailand earlier in the year.  Our waitress was very good too and the food came fast.  Definitely recommend this place along with staying at the Venetian when you visit Vegas.

Y4AQMlhJ4FiSlIMqAf2I8w.text: Surprisingly didn't feel like you were in the middle of a casino when you ate here which I appreciated. Service was quick and food came out hot. They ran out of edamame which was disappointing. Food portions were large and a great value for the money.

dm_TRMjL69A3GqOtw4DMww.text: Kung Pow chicken with peanuts was amazing.  Good for the after effects of some late night drinking. Service fast. Not too friendly, but hey, what do you expect for rapid service?  Quick easy and very tasty.

5OJojIyoYxMerL3ScIizQw.text: Love the Wonton Soup. So fresh and clean tasting. Shrimp dumpling and the bokchoy complement so well. The price would better but it's Venetian so it's expected. The XO shrimp laifun is amazing. Can not come to Vegas and not eat here at least once.

I395WcZOKss7SjyM9mkr_g.text: My girlfriend and I recently discovered Noodle Asia during a stay at the Venetian.  The food here is pricey but worth it. The fried rice is incfedible- light with no oil, fluffy and delicious.The Kung Pao chicken and Orange chicken were equally.  Even though this place was bustling, the service was fast and friendly.

BRXmgp2J5101iG1JwR-KGg.text: Best Szcehwan Beef Noodle Soup I've Ever Had.  This place is officially a staple of my Vegas trips.  The service straight sucks.  The food is expensive for Chinese.  The wait can get a little long.  The Szcehwan Beef Noodle soup is effing legit.  It doesn't just hit the spot after an alcohol marathon, it finds the spot and smashes it with a sledge hammer.  Spicy broth.  Soft noodles.  Tender meat.  The kimchee is $6.50.  Yes, I know that is expensive kimchee.  And yes, I order it every time (and side note: Noodles at Bellagio has $7 kimchee, I will never order it again).  It's also right next to the sports book so you can catch a glimpse of some of the games, which is a plus in my book.  Warning: if you bring Chinese people with you, you will probably hear about how unauthentic and expensive this place is for the duration of your entire meal.  The kitchen is open, so you can see all the cooks and they're Chinese.  Rub that one in.  True story: I tried to bribe the guy $100 to reopen the restaurant 5 minutes after it closed at 3am.  He thought about it.  For maybe 30 seconds.  Then we were forced to leave empty handed to the terribleness that is Grand Lux Cafe.  Never again.

nNJsMkUM8FUa-dm1967g5w.text: The food isn't over dressed or fancy but it tastes good. I don't know if the people who are hating on Noodle Asia don't like Chinese food or are  just confused about the name, but it's pretty authentic.  Came here for lunch and the spicy dumplings are amazing. After a recommendation from a friend, we knew at least two orders were needed.  The beef noodle soup and HK wonton soup were flavorful and not too salty. The stir-fried Shanghai noodles were extremely oily and seemed a bit too much like noodles I would find in Shanghai.

x1nuJ24nCMpvNuXsBhk4bw.text: Good Asian dishes at fairly low prices for the Strip. Best of all, there are no reservations and they move people through the line quickly, so the wait isn't all that long. Loved this place for lunch while staying in the Venetian.

Bit3nWsxQ2504YlzhwXdeg.text: The Thai Si Jiu Beef Noodle is pretty good here. The Xo Shrimp is good too. Ordered the beef strew noodle the other day and got a whole lot of fat & no meat. sigh.

VOeIgx-vCXmTenm3s462mA.text: Pretty good noodle soup or chow fun for a place that is inside a strip hotel.  When you sit at the counter...you will see all the old asian cooks in the back...making it an authentic chinese resturant.   But be prepared to get grease food from this place..which is how the original food is cooked anyways...  Location is good since its in the hotel we actually stayed in ...and we didn't have to get a taxi to go over to spring valley to get authentic chinese food.

E9SRSoPyO4q13-kMhRHNKg.text: Had the (not on the menu) wor won ton, fried, rice, beef, & combo noodles. All good.  Service lacking they brought 2 plates only then the next 2 orders ten minutes later, warm beer, when we ask for a new cold beer they only gave  ice for the beer you don't want water down beer.  Also they forgot the appetizers so they're going to bring it with our meal I told them to cancel it.  No good! Good food poor managment. Won't be back.

kiaDoWyp3xC2OiFIDA2QGA.text: Decent chinese restaurant on the strip.  FOOD: It was good!  I got the Vegetable Moo Shoo.  It came already wrapped, and it was good.  BF got the pan fried noodles with seafood.  He liked the crunchy noodles a lot, but said the fish was okay.  SERVICE: It was decent.  They were nice, and the food came out quick.  AMBIANCE:  It was okay.  It's not a romantic place, and it's basically right in the middle of the casino floor (between the sports room and a bunch of casinos).  PRICE:  It was okay.  Each entree was about $10.  Overall, a decent place for lunch or after a long night clubbing.

_4DB0y_k8e5c8FND52043w.text: Sorry Howard, but gotta disagree with you on this place.  Well, okay partly disagree with you.  It is indeed very expensive.  I came here for some late night eats.  I split the following with the gf:  Hong Kong Won Ton (just okay), Shanghai Rice Cake (Shanghai cabbage with seasoned pork, wok-tossed in a mild soy sauce - the rice cakes were overcooked.  I like 'em much firmer), and Cantonese Sausage Fried Rice (With egg whites and thinly sliced Chinese broccoli stems - not bad).  Add in 2 very small chrysanthemum teas and you easily rack up $48 bucks and some change sans tip.  For that amount, you can feast.    Not worth it.  At least for me.

XU-bA5oJXJj5TUZRERDz6g.text: ordered won ton noodle soup & singapore noodles dishes.   both meals were a bit small.   the singapore noodles were a bit salty for my taste buds.  service was good and friendly.

kOG0Ba6oo9suQ1Doa9oubw.text: I thought this place was great!  Right near the casino at the Palazzo, but didn't feel casino-y.  :)  Prices very reasonable.  A friend and I shared a bowl of beef noodles, couple of spring rolls and crab rangoon and it was more than enough food.   The service was great, the price was very reasonable and it just really hit the spot after a long day.  I saw someone else's noodle soup, and knew I would get that next.  Nothing fancy, but  I thought the food was great.  Would definitely go back.

rl3qzAiYS3ohXvKk47SmTw.text: We had a great meal here. Beef W/ Broccoli and pork fried rice. Great service and a pleasing place for a meal

sQYLx6F-VRmfiMzFypIfqg.text: It's slightly too expensive for what you're getting.  Also, I didn't really like the flavor of my noodle dish.  I'm also not sure how the heck this place was categorized as "dim sum."  THIS IS NOT A DIM SUM RESTAURANT.  Edit: I see they changed it from "dim sum" to "chinese".  Good job, Yelp!

sqoMHTLWHSNuZtow7mgFTg.text: Not a bad place, especially when you consider their extended hours. Plain and simply Asian fare, but tasty enough.

OBCfdU9g81oSpVXr5SjVzA.text: good late night asian food, nice staff. a little overpriced

aoQ2yH9Eafc4_EMnFQ9WAA.text: I have mixed feelings about this place.  Probably hover around 2.5 stars but I'll be nice.  Yeah, the Szechwan Beef soup can hit the spot and makes me want to try the other soups that they have there but their fried rice kind of turned me off.  The fried rice was good until I started spitting out a bunch of egg shells.  I would most likely come back only if I'm staying at the Venetian but would definitely stay away from their fried rice.

lCTRKpfmHZGPYt1E5wLieg.text: Let me start off by writing why I gave this restaurant a 2 star rating. I give it  2 because the combination fried rice my fiance ordered was really good and taste authentic.  My visit here was horrible!! and whatever your definition of horrible is I must say I agree. We ordered our food @ exactly 11:11 my fiance's rice arrived at 11:35 not bad right?  24 minutes after ordering I'm sure the food is gonna be great. Around 11:40 umm where is my  food? (we ask athe server)  I then taste his rice and oh yes his rice is really good. 11:45 I still don't have  my food 11:48 okay? well now that he's done eating I think we should pay for what we ordered. I tell the server to please give us the check, he then tries to give us the check and the rest of our order to go! I was like really? really? I told him I don't want the food and that we will only pay for what we received. Not one person gave us an explanation on why we never received the rest of our order and or tried to appologize for what happened. I was upset and hungry, not a good combination but hey my fances combination fried rice was delicious. So unless you have time for someone else to waste your time, go right ahead and enjoy the food!

iyFIzmYBKF_E03PMulh9qA.text: Solid chinese food on the strip. Plus it's right next to the Poker room inside the Venetian. The Sesame Shrimp thingy is to die for.. Bomb.com

In_zNwG_0eLnVrEDV7w3Jg.text: Ahhhh, one of the many reasons I love the Venetian hotel: Noodles Asia.   The shrimp fried rice: excellent (so much that even though we were full - we decided to finish the plate).   Wonton Noodle Soup: Mouth-watering. The egg noodles and just the right amount of flavoring... completely over the top!!!  Beef Chow Fun: Not my favorite, but still exteremly delicious!!  Minus one star for the price. I understand it's Vegas and we should expect high prices, but rearlly? $45 for 3 meals... absurd!

wNLt6jivxEA4kpgkINtUbA.text: I don't even eat wonton noodle soup back home, but it's a must-have when I go to vegas especially after having drank the entire day. I think they need to be open 24hrs... but anyway, I can't leave vegas without coming here. Service isn't all that great; I can't really seem to get anyone's attention most of the time. But their wonton noodle soup just hits the spot! I've tried the noodle shop and mah jong... eh... they just don't quite have what it takes... and THANK YOU FOR REOPENING! I almost cried when I saw them closed a few weeks back. Thank god it was just for renovation *whew!

rxfXxjZ_jLVtefZ6yu6Mpw.text: Trust me, you're much better off eating at Panda Express.  Went here because some Yelpers said it was a decent Chinese place on the strip. Repeat, the strip.  First off, the location sucks. Yes, it may be in the Venetian, but it's in some odd corner where the smell of smoke is intense and you're looking at nothing but Sportsbooks.  We were seated promptly but it took about half an hour for water and menus. The food was honestly forgettable. Yes, there was variety, as well as Dim Sum, and the quality of ingredients was good, but it didn't live up to its claim of authenticity, nor did it taste spectacular. We had the XO Shrimp and the Seafood Pan Fried Noodles. And it was overpriced as hell.  Like I said, you're better off eating at Panda Express somewhere in Henderson, or in Vegas if there is one. Sure it's a chain, but the food is freshly made, hot, and tasty.  Two stars for bad environment, mediocre food, and slow service.  Another fine review by S.G. Whoop, whoop, whoop!

8-NP9crUFcBJHkp9myVnHg.text: This place was really good...probably the best meal we had in Las Vegas and we ate at a lot of places.  I ordered the Spicy Ying Nan soup -- it was very flavorful but be careful if you're weirded out by seafood.  There were fish balls, squid balls, and shrimp in it.  Imagine a meatball made out of ground fish and squid (calamari).  They were fine though.  My friend ordered the Won Ton soup and it was really good too.  Give this place a try!  They were open until 3 am and packed!

bVOprSDOuDRH4kT_3PLd_A.text: Fairly decent Chinese in the middle of the Strip. We've ordered several things from Noodle Asia and the only things worth ordering here are the beef noodle soup and the Shanghai rice cakes. Service is terrible like most Asian restaurants. It's difficult even getting a glass of water.

qZzSpQBkAD28jq4_Wm7h3g.text: My stir fried noodles were a-ok...until I felt sick no less than ten minutes later. I wouldn't have been as upset had I not just paid $16 with tax and tip for a half a plate of noodles and a stomachache.   After all, I prefer to end my nights in Vegas next to the toilet, not start with it. There are better (and cheaper) places than this.

AteCE3gNJcIRAkL0fP6JaQ.text: I love their Schewan Beef soup.  Sooo good!  Although sometimes the beef is really fatty...And their wonton soup, noodle soup is great!  I could eat here every day.

63h54yZgzDXOP0mAHBMuEw.text: I was pretty happy with my dining experience here.    We came here the morning we left and we wanted something close and in our hotel.  My cousin had mentioned this noodle asia place and it was her place to go to every time she's here so we figured why not!  We got here around the time they opened and shortly they were packed!!  I got the Beef Noodle Soup which is very much like the taiwanese style beef noodle soup and i wasn't disappointed at all!  A little oilier than what I'm used to but the broth seemed cleaner than what I'm also used to which was a plus!  They weren't shady on the beef either!  The bowl was a little pricey of course!  But hey, being in the Palazzo, what do you expect. My pretty little beef noodle soup cost me $17 with tax and tip!  Yikes!  Being asian, I know that I can get a bowl like this for $7 but oh well, it's vegas!  My cousin got the duck noodle soup and she said her duck was really salty.  My other friend who came along got the shanghai noodles which looked way too oily for me!

W-iFPNUSouBokZaQsxXGVQ.text: One of my worst dining experience at Vegas!!. Even though my wife and I are not picky eaters, we felt the same way that both foods(beef noodle and chow men) are very salty and filled with MSG. I don't believe why I had to wait for more than 20 mins to taste this crap!! If you do not have much appetite for very salty MSG with overrated price, do not think of visiting this place. There are many places for good chinese food even in food court at venetian even you do not drive to china town 3 miles away!

aozmvGYa7rbq5Dv09Yb0uQ.text: The BEST Hot-Sour Soup in the USA, Hands Down !!!! Fast Service. This is a must stop on the strip. Hard to find inside the Venetian. Look for the sports book. Lettuce wraps are fresh and hot. Very Clean Restaurant !!! Try everything on this menu. Jazmin Tea is awesome.....Excellent for late night dining

GLEBDpncIodfpNT-6SsJxw.text: There are quite a variety of reviews for this place, but our experience was quite good. We went with a guy who's been here a few times so we took his lead. Two of us had Szechwan Beef Noodles and two of us had Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle. The food went beyond my expectations, everything being freshly prepared...the noodles had some zip. The open kitchen reinforced that freshly prepared concept.  It IS on the pricier side (i.e., compared to chinatown), but for us it was perfect. A quick, clean, hearty, not-too-greasy, late-night meal before heading out.  I'll be back.

w-6sSldc4U0K8T1FQgMW_g.text: Ok I live near Asian central in LA so when someone from the East Coast said the beef noodle soup was good, I was  a bit skeptical. I actually went with a bunch of Asian guys from LA. Most of us got the beef noodle soup. It was quite authentic but the price was ridiculous! $14 for a bowl. Decent sized bowl but I will never pay that much again. I can get one for $4 back home. I just ate it for experience.

d6aB22vqQDjAssmqvP5JJQ.text: after clubbing at tao on friday night, a few of us passed by noodle asia on the way back to our room and decided to try it out, although we weren't sure how good an asian place in the venetian would be. it turned out to be a great choice!! here are the dishes we ordered:  hong kong won ton soup: delicious!! came with a huge mass of egg noodles and several shrimp (and maybe pork?) won tons pork & special preserved egg congee: YUM hot & sour soup: a bit too sour, nothing special beef rice noodles (beef chow fun): a little bland but otherwise YUMMY  we tried to go again on sunday around 6 pm and there was a line so we went to the sad food court instead. :( next time i'm in vegas i will definitely stop by again for yummy chinese food!

rvLXgfrlQFRtVawUg1vSnw.text: I was slightly inebriated, so I THINK this is the restaurant I went to. hahah. I tried confirming on the Venetian website, but that thing has been down for like 2 weeks now.  Oh wait...I checked out the pictures on here and now I know it is the place I went to.  Phew.   We ordered:  Postickers- good Wonton Soup- didn't try it but it looked good Spicy Beef Noodle soup- it was above average, not that spicy though Beef Chow Fun- pretty tasty  I'm not sure if I would be more particular about it if it wasn't 2:30 in the morning.  I would come back if it was late and that was the only thing open, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

5HvwgEL6jRDAXWrLTA_JYQ.text: The good: Soups. The hot and sour soup is delicious, as are the noodle soups. The duck and pork noddle soup is exceptional.  The noodle soups are about $15 and very filling.  The bad: Prices. It's expensive. However, you're int he Venetian - whaddaya expect?  It's no frills, pretty good food, that's pretty expensive. The stir friend noodle dishes are pretty good, but not as good as the soups.

oEkeMoptOLJDbRPuqX27PA.text: Got the Szechwan Beef noodle soup.  Supposed to be a Mama Wu specialty, whatever that means. It was spicy but not very tasty.  Beef was bland.  Noodles were just noodles to me. Also tried the Buddah Feast Pan-Tossed Noodles which were not too bad but nothing special.  Service was not very good. Our waiter was in such a hurry to get our order, just forget about asking any questions regarding the menu. When he dropped off our food and drink he never came by to check on us.  Had I known I wouldn't be getting drink refills, I would of chosen a milder soup.  Here's the deal:  Open late - Good Food - Ehhh Price - Too much for Ehhh tasting food Service - What service?  I would think this be a much better joint since it's in the Venetian.  It's good that it's open late and you are in the mood for noodles.  But really, there's just no reason for me to come back.

HqwhJWdBINJEDgHGrshhpw.text: Honestly, I don't think many people eat Chinese food while in Las Vegas. However - if you're with family or just have a sudden appetite for Chinese food, I would recommend Noodle Asia. The prices decent and the food is actually pretty good, for LV.   Highlights are the Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup, Pineapple Fried Rice, and old man Kenny, who is one of those nice old school managers.   Location/ambiance - Okay, this is definitely weird since it's an "open air" restaurant in the middle of a casino.  I think it's great for business since you get the random foot traffic as well as the people who stay in the hotel.

kTwoQJvi2sX7zwm0B_6TQA.text: I sigh, I pine, I long again to dine... I moan, I cry, I feel like I could die without...  Another visit to the Las Vegas pig-out-on-authentic-Chinese-cuisine-slice-of-Heaven that has spoiled me for any other Chinese food in existence. My partner found it during one of his business trips to LV and took me for dinner the very next time we vacationed there. We've been to Sin City six times, and four out of those six, we had most of our lunches and many dinners here at Noodle Asia in the Venetian.  It's not a very big place at all, and if you didn't know what to look for you'd probably just assume that it's another one of those chain places like Panda Bowl and pass it right by.  And if you did that, friend, you were dead wrong. Next time, back it up and go in. It's the gastronomic equivalent of putting a quarter in the Wheel Of Fortune machine and hitting the Grand Prize.  Everything is light, crispy, fresh and always served piping hot. I tend to judge any Chinese place by the quality of their egg and spring rolls, and Noodle Asia's are the kind I wish I could have shipped to my home by the dozen. Not heavy, greasy or stuffy as the more conventional egg rolls, I could just keep ordering these for the entire meal.  And then the sesame peanut noodles. My GOD. Is it dessert, or is it dinner? One mouthful, and it doesn't even matter any more. Is it possible for your tongue to have multiple orgasms? I'm pretty sure mine did.   Sadly, it's been a couple of years or more since our last LV visit, and I've had dreams about eating at Noodle Asia (oh, yeah, I got it THAT bad.) I've never been a real big seafood fanatic, but I'm pretty sure that those dishes are as awesome as everything else they have, and if I'm lucky, I may get to find out someday.  Meanwhile, if and when you stop by this wonderful place, can you find a way to sneak some spring rolls back to me? I'd be forever in your debt...  ;-)

jecJq-YztpDGUYMK70Ujrw.text: I stayed in Venetian for a conference last month and tried Noodle Asia. It is authentic. I tried the spicy Sichuan beef noodle dish. It was delicious. I finished the whole bowl of noodle, plus all beef and every drop of the soup. The price is a bit high and it is located right in the middle of the casino. The decor is not bad.

-50w7cl80dCjqPtbee_jcg.text: They offer good and real Chinese food. The wonton is really good. The only bad thing about this place is the price. Well, this is Vegas and it's inside the Venetian.

kTDv7c0ORMI7vfoDi71kyw.text: this is a best kept secret on the strip! :) every time i stay at the venetian i try to have at least 1 meal here! like i mentioned many times in my reviews,  i'm a creature of habit, italian restaurants - i always order linguine & clams, mexican restaurants - chicken flautas with rice, and chinese restaurants - beef chow fun ALWAYS.... not this time! my bf and i were sooooo hungry that we ordered won ton noodle soup, chinese broccoli w/oyster sauce, singapore rice noodles, and chinese sausage fried rice. everything was delicious! the chinese sausage (lop cheong) fried rice was made a bit different then what i am use to, noodle asia makes their fried rice with egg whites only! very delicious! i highly reccomend this place for late night dining or a lunch time visit, but .... remember.... it's on the strip so the prices are a bit high! 4 items, 1 hot tea and 1 coke = $65 including tax and tip!

xaF-D4DGvA_sojnDoXKmHA.text: I like the fact that this place is the ONLY place that opens late on the strip. Due to NYC life we eat uber late! As for the choices. I hate to say this but this is by far fast food material. There is absolutely nothing authentic about their dishes. Everything is quick and easy and they charge an arm and leg for the choices you get. The pho...broth taste like boiled water. The pineapple fried rice... Where's the pineapple!? If im paying double digits on this. I best see you serve it in a pineapple to show me that your not using CANS!? The only choice that was decent was the beef stew with noodles. It definitely needs a little veg on the side though.. I don't mean to bash on them. I mean. I have to say they are crazy smart to open a fast food Asian cuisine that charges the same price as an upscale Asian fusion restaurants in NYC. Props to them for banking it. But for a kid who grew up eating nothing but Asian foods in a diverse city. There is no comparison.

A-bXWH_OYzviuhxfgcAWkw.text: Since a lot of review talking about the bad service, I am here to tell my experience when I worked at noodle asia. In one year, there were over 100 servers or busers got the job and quit, Why? Bad management! Does a server care to give good customer service when he/she does not feel love from the company? Who care to give a F when they are only consider as a Workers? Here comes a True story, it was the first day for a new buser, after over 4 hours non stop working, time for him to take a break and dinner, he found a dish of fried rice sat in the kichen for over 2 hours due to a special order made wrong, he microwaved it and started eating since only 30 mins break time. The manager on duty found that out, she gave the buser two options: pay for the dish and keep the job, or take the uniform off and leave immediately because he was violating the rule. For the food, different restaurants prepare their foods in different ways. Some people may like the taste and some don't. It is hard to tell the quarlity since some like extreme spicy and some like extreme the other way.
