REYCUrR8C6NjDrRGu8vy8g.text: Noodle Asia was conveniently located at our hotel, the Venetian.  My friends and I were in town for a Bachelorette and went to eat here at 3am after a night out at the club.  We ordered the har gow and congee and were all pleased with our orders.  The waiteress was friendly especially considering the fact that they were getting ready to close their kitchen.  The following day we decided to go there for lunch and boy, what a change of service.  The same waiters were working, yet they were terribly rude.  1. they forgot one of our drink orders and when we asked for it, the waiter's response was "yea, and?"  2. when we asked for extra vegetables they said they would charge an additional $2, then only brought out greens.  When we asked about the other vegetables, we got a total of 3 straw mushrooms and 3 slices of carrots...def not what I would consider "extra".  3.  when we asked to split checks the waiter acted like he didn't' understand and sent another waitress to our table as if our request was absurd.  4.  the waiter never came back to collect our cards, so I had to go to the front to give them our cards.

NhpRK-8Xd0JUOoLgNERXmw.text: I can't believe I  paid $13 for a bowl of beef noodle soup!! But alas, I only have myself to blame. After us ladies got tired of the crowd at Tao, we were pretty famished! This place is inside The Venetian so it was right there. Just as we were seated the waiter rushed us to order because the kitchen was closing. I can't believe how rude he was! He even snatched the menu from my friends' hand as she was still ordering. Unbelievable!!  Our food was just average, nothing mind blowing to me. I was a little tipsy but the waiter killed my buzz so there was nothing fooling me. The expensive food, I can let slide, but the horrible service we got is just not acceptable!

DcVeC8kKFSQviuTkeNJsdw.text: Pot stickers to die for!  Honestly, I think my husband and I were the only non-Asian diners there, which should say something about the quality of the food.  The beef and broccoli was fab, and the portions are filling.  I rarely order wine at an Asian restaurant, but I did at Noodle Asia, and the house red was really good.  I was pleasantly surprised.  It is tucked behind the slot machines and there is generally a line to get in, but it moves quickly.  Great for lunch or dinner, and the price point is right on.

KeNwV-76Xjtw7c-fShpfwg.text: Before you judge me of giving a 5-star review to a Chinese restaurant in Vegas, I need to explain myself. Yes, I am surprised even at myself for giving a 5-star rating to a casual Chinese restaurant.  No, sweet & sour pork and lemon chicken are not in my repertoire of Chinese food.  No, I was not drunk when I visited the restaurant; and I think reviews by those who admitted being drunk and their judgement impaired should be tossed out.   I am picky so I do not like just anything.  I grew up in Hong Kong, have travelled to major Chinese cities, and have lived in both Vancouver and San Francisco for many years so I know my Chinese foods.  I do have to emphasize though that my rating is based on one dish that I had.  My parents and I were spending a few days in Vegas a couple of weeks ago.  After coming out from "O", my parents retired to their room for the evening.  I was getting hungry even though we had a big lunch so I wandered around to check out the restaurants opening late in Palazzo / Venetian where we stayed.  I had been to Noodles in Bellagio and Zine in Palazzo.  Both were decent so I thought I would give Noodle Asia a try.  The menu is quite extensive.  The prices are very reasonable considering that it is a hotel restaurant.  I ordered a plate of fried rice with Chinese sausages, egg white and Chinese broccoli.  It didn't take long until a generous serving arrived.   It looked just as simple as the menu suggested with 3 ingredients and rice.  I took a bite and I said to myself, "OMG.  This is the best fried rice I've ever had."  And it was, seriously, the best fried rice I've ever had anywhere!  The Chinese sausage slices were sweet and tender.  The egg whites were fluffy.  However, the rice was the star of the dish.  It was not browned with dark soy sauce and it has all the flavours from being fried in a hot and well-seasoned wok.    The plate was just under $14.  Although the restaurant is a essentially a cafe but it was far better than any $15 - $18 fried rice dishes served in many other well appointed restaurants.  A few weeks later and I still remember the dish.  My partner is going to Vegas for a conference in a couple of weeks and I told him he needed to go there and order the rice if he could only eat out once.

OCRII8GhYmZ_UhXDhSKwsQ.text: One of the pictures on this got my attention and I wanted to try the Szechwan Beef.   I am not saying this was the best Szechwan beef noodle soup I have ever had in my life but during that moment, after a night of heavy drinking, it was perfect. Usually, pho would do the trick, but I think this will be my new hangover meal.  The broth was spiced just right. I did not have to add any other sauces or condiments, with the exception of more chili peppers because I like it very spicy. The beef came in large cubes and I honestly wished they added more just because it was that good. The noodles were perfect, tender but not mushy like it was over cooked.    The service was also great! My water glass never went more than half empty. The food came promptly and all within the same time!   Next time I am in Vegas, I will be here again.

zOy4Fd6sl4wG-xnh-_N4Ug.text: I had their szechuan beef noodle soup three meals in a row. Serious wait time during lunch and dinner. Go super early or super late

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QFXWSQ--fzja42C98qCxog.text: 5 stars.  I know...ironic isn't it? How could a noodle restaurant in Las Vegas be this good? Well, ask yourself this: would a noodle restaurant located in the Venetian be able to survive if it WASN'T this good?  I keep coming back for the schezwan noodle soup (niu ro mein). The soup is so wonderfully rich and complex with just a hint of spiceness. It's so deliciously satisfying and soothing! The noodles have just the right amount of bite. I wish the meat was just a little bit more tender, but still very good nonetheless.   I still don't understand why they niu ro mein is so much better here than at any place I've had in Alhambra/Monterey Park. Shrugs...oh well. Just try it for yourself and swing by the Bouchon bakery afterwards for dessert.

-bH8ls_KJ_D3Z9xq_KOtyA.text: Love their beef noodle soup, pork noodle soup, and minced beef rice. A must have for me when I visit Vegas. Though everything here is quite pricey and two people ordering one entree each of either a noodle dish or a rice dish can easily end up with a bill of $40+ dollars, they use high quality ingredients I believe b/c I don't get the nasty feeling afterwards from low quality oil and/or ingredient like I get from some other cheaper Chinese restaurants.   At times, they do get super busy though.  You could be standing in line for 20-30 minutes waiting to be seated and then find out that you need to wait for another 30 minutes or more for your food.  But it was fine for me coz I have no time pressure when I'm in Vegas :)

Y8-rUxp7oxWQzC9SHUZfwg.text: Every time I'm in Vegas, I will make a trip out here for lunch or dinner. The food is good and the price is reasonable. I love the beef stew and won ton noodle soup. Reminds me how I use to get it at home. Definitely the place to go if your craving authentic Chinese food on the strip.

td5gH24GVHnSqGmN91l2gA.text: I come to this Resturant very time I am in Vegas I cannot explain exactly what it is about their food that appeals to me other than it is absolutely delicious.   This place is sort of a cafeteria style place off to the side of the sports betting area of the Venetian casino.   The beef lo mien and the egg flower soup are by far the best meal there I recommend all my family and friends to try this place every time they are in Vegas.

JPOHYqa1fF8nW3ZKZK3vQg.text: I got the Buddha Feast when I was there on business.  I didn't have a lot of time and just had to pop by somewhere quick.  I really enjoyed the food, and the service was quick and efficient.   It wasn't cheap, per se, but it certainly didn't break the bank, either.  I also liked that while it was fairly crowded, that it wasn't terribly loud in there.   I'd definitely go back.

FLe7e4ExUN87WiPPuWJBlg.text: Favorite Asian place to eat noodles. The spicy beef and spicy ying nan noodle are delish! My husband loves the BBQ pork lo mein.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy ying nan and BBQ pork Lo mein

Ie6GCpEvgPyOY2CvEhJyUw.text: Was so happy to find this place nestled in the Venetian.  I sat at the bar and was waited on almost immediately. Extensive menu.  Enjoyed the spring roll appetizer, szechuan beef noodle bowl (it was huge!), and warm saki.  Yes, more expensive than one usually spends at a noodle house.  However, quite reasonable for Vegas.  No doubt I'd eat there again on a return visit to the Strip.

HHXdkhN9f2ATFLrDm8GEVw.text: I would say they deserved 4 stars but it's on the expensive side when it comes to dishes, but what do you expect since it is located inside a hotel and on the Las Vegas Strip. My family had the Orange chicken, Mongolian Beef, Rice, Egg Soup, Shrimp Dimshum, and Wonton Soup. The rice was perfect! Love when a place knows how to cook their rice, not hard, yet not mushy. The Mongolian beef was my favorite, very soft and tender. But it was $20, my family overall had 7 items and 1 drink and that became $106. But, when she came over to pick up the check she said that it did not include tip, and if we wanted our change back. Now, we were going to give her tip, but she decided to give her even less because that was so rude and made her look money hungry. As well as making the restaurant look bad

0nVqo2TXHUGoMJyu17g7Pg.text: Food tastes pretty authentic being inside Venetian at heart of the strip! I come everytime for good ole noodles and soups. Must check out. Of course pricing can't be compared to china town.

8dZJKUrII_zOZUpJLhmF_Q.text: Please.  Don't tell anyone.  I don't want to get in trouble with the "What Happens in Vegas . . ." crowd.    But it was late.  We had been enjoying ourselves for a long time at the Whiskey Bar.  We were hungry and Noodle Asia was there.    We both ordered big bowls of noodles.  Nothing for us to drink thank you.  Had enough of that already.  Yes.  Water please.    Almost before the waiter left the table, our big bowls of delicious noodles arrived.  Hot, fresh, salty, delicious.  It was just what the Dr. ordered.    I have a feeling it isn't going to hurt as bad tomorrow ... Oh wait, its after midnight?  It isn't going to hurt as bad today when I get up at 11 am to check out of the Hotel all because I had these tasty noodles.  Thank you noodles.  Good night.  Zzzzzzz

sRLspwPRXXy1K0yClEqUqw.text: Open til 3am.  The owner/mgr/server was so sweet and friendly considering how late it was when we arrived, 2 am.   Super fast service and the food was surprisingly authentic and delicious for being a late night eatery.   We ordered the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, Wonton Noodle Soup and Fried Rice.  All three were excellent!!!

fNrZPWadLdY_D-CLCC2dnQ.text: Noodle Asian is just great. It's convenient if you're staying at the Venetian/Palazzo. It's not terribly over-priced. And it is literally the best hangover food you can get. I love the spicy red oil wontons, all of their noodle dishes and the duck over rice. Can't speak to how it tastes when you're not drunk/hungover, but it's definitely a must have every time I'm in Vegas!

fx8vpKsW1owsuKzmD-kTpQ.text: I had seafood noodle soup and the fresh coconut drink for lunch. The noodle soup wasn't bad but nothing spectacular.  I have had better at the Dragon Noodle Co. in Monte Carlo.  The coconut drink was right out of a fresh coconut and that was actually great.  I'd eat here again but will try out another dish.

UkHSWC46-pK-Kp7Of_U3dA.text: Good chinese food and reasonable prices.  My noodle entree was $15.00 and was delicious. So happy to find this restaurant in Vegas.

GZgU1wirUWj4jmdqUH2bqA.text: Wow, who knew Asian food in a hotel could actually be good?? The prices were slightly higher than back in the Bay Area, but hey for Vegas, it was pretty reasonable and maybe even a good deal!  - Shu Mai: comes in an order of 6 for $9. Yeah, pricey! And not as good as home, but they were sweet and hit the spot especially when you're hungover.  - Won Ton Soup: $5 for a cup. Yeah, again pricey! A cup consisted of 3 wontons and a piece of baby bok choy LOL. But again, sweet, soupy, and hit the spot!  - Beef Noodle Soup: My friend ordered this and loved it. I tasted her broth and it packed a punch! That satay flavor will creep up on your throat though! $13  - Combination pan fried noodles: I was actually really impressed with this dish! The noodles were crispy, and the sauce/gravy was really tasty. It also included lots of shrimp, chicken, and veggies. Good portion to do family style!  - Combination fried rice: $15 nothing special or memorable. But it's a good choice if you're looking for carbs.  Open late and conveniently located inside the Venetian. Perfect spot for late night soup after clubbing or that morning soup to get you going again!   EAT.SLEEP.RAVE.REPEAT.

uAXExTG5qMOoFMg8hT82xg.text: Food was good, ordered the chicken fried rice, shrimp tempura, fried zucchini and edamame.

uJSX2IIMruEd5uFqvookTw.text: This place was really fantastic. First off we needed a place to grab a snack before dinner. We both enjoyed a very large and generous pot of jasmine tea. Next we enjoyed pot stickers and crab ragoons. Both were fantastic. Very large portions and more than we needed. We took some of it back to the room. The service was great and we watched the football game while enjoying our food. Will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great view of sports and our large pot of jasmine tea.

r_XmRb-tQGeG1FbNA6Og0A.text: Super expensive for the quality and bland. Although, the portions are decent. Do not come here if you're a vegetarian. There are very few options. I got the veggie fried rice and asked if I could swap in brown rice for the white. The answer was no. I added tofu for some protein ($4 extra). The tofu was fried, but soggy and semi cold. The food came out right away, so clearly it was premade. My fried rice was over $18 before tip! Our waiter was hard to understand and not very friendly. I would choose another place to eat next time around.

FYhtrG9WnW7WszqpETrMmg.text: Love the food here! The soup, noodles, and shrimp is amazing! The only reason why I gave them 4/5 stats is because their service sucks! I kinda expect to get sucky service anytime I'm having Chinese food, so I wasn't too disappointed. I just think the Venetian can hire better trained people to work there. People staying at this hotel expect a certain level of service and the people at noodle Asia don't deliver. But the food is amazing :) love it!

HjME4jPeKtyfds_wO8e4XA.text: Having been to Vegas 7-8 times, I always seem to forget Noodle Asia - not in a bad way, because I've been there 3 times now.  But I never thought about writing a review because it's one of those places that you'd go for three reasons: 1) convenience, as it's located in Venetian, 2) hung over and need Chinese food, or 3) you want something other than fake PJ Chang Chinese food.  Tips: don't order dumplings, wonton soup, shu mai and other classic dishes that restaurants can make in big batches.  Go for dishes they actually have to stir-fry and cook.  Knowing to skip large-batch menu items, we went with the mushroom chicken noodle soup and curry beef stew.  For both dishes, they'd be considered above average in Chinatown, and definitely fantastic in Vegas strip.  Case in point, when I had their wonton soup and shu mai, they felt store-bought and under-seasoned.    There was one black mark during our visit - we ordered a Thai ice tea and they didn't have anymore.  But a few minutes later another waiter said they had one last cup - we happily accepted.  They added so much water to the Thai ice tea that it was a joke.  I found that to be shady.  Nevertheless stick with dishes that they HAVE to cook (and I don't mean fried rice), and you'll come away with a positive experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Curry beef stew

c_9-IFFTW3jrZA29WzfgWw.text: We had visited Noodle Asia several times in Las Vegas and the first time can be traced back to 2014. Food in Noodle Asia is overall delicious and not so heavy. Although their prices are higher than regular Chinese restaurants, we still love it because of their authentic noodle soups and the store hour. If you want to have a hot soup or a good noodles in the strip at late night, this is a must-visit place you need to try. Highly recommend their noodle soups. Oh by the way, their service is way way too good than any other restaurants in the strips.

wIIbEpXVrurB8o-yoJIfog.text: This restaurant had terrible service.  There were 4of us and the entrees came out one a a time.  By the time the last person got their food the first person was through eating.  First entree came out before we finished our soup.  Lazy waitress could refill our water.  Not impressed and the food was horrible.

M37ozhUCqBHf7VYIuF8pLQ.text: Among the many creative culinary offerings that make the Venetian hotel and casino a stand out on the strip, Noodle Asia isa stand out in its own right. The ultimate round the clock asian restaurant, made to order custom cooked asian dishes are inspiring if not down right energizing.  The noodle selection is awesome, with several dishes featuring flavors from across the continent.  The Singapore vermicelli with curry, shrimp, and pork was spectacular.  Located just outside the poker room, with direct access to the casino floor, the Noodle Asia restaurant is also a perfect stop if you are watching a game in the totally amazing newly redesigned sports book.  I shot a quick photo of the orange chicken we had at 1:15am after a fun evening on the town.  Check them out if you can stop by the Venetian.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious classic orange chicken.

H2IMz45A5cvhPNMx7yCr4w.text: Very poor service with little portion for a very expensive charge for the food. Not to mention they give u pressure when u order the food, as if u don't order a lot seems you are cheap. Did nor enjoy the food or the atmosphere here. Bad bad bad...

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 10 pieces of uncooked shrimps for $26. Ridiculous ...

nLRCAdihOVGwSpZv_QM4Kw.text: My favorite place to go when I'm in Vegas! Beef noodle soup and lychee martini were both very good!

LUWOY2hxkjndEav4ItI6Eg.text: This place gave me the worst food I have ever ordered except for that one sushi restaurant in California that may have served me warm goldfish.  If you are celiac, don't come here.  Even the dishes that are normally gluten-free, like pho and congee, have gluten here.  According to my server, nothing on the menu was gluten-free.  She gave me something "special", which was rice noodles cooked in oil, a few pieces of broccoli and carrots, and boiled chicken with no seasonings (not even salt) and no sauce.  It was bland and unsatisfying and cost $15.  I have been gluten-free for over a decade--since before it was cool.  I am good at avoiding restaurants that won't have options for me.  I can always find something at Asian restaurants.  Until now.  My friend ordered Mongolian Beef and was unimpressed.  Then he felt ill well into the following day.  TL;DR: If you have to avoid gluten, beware that the normal options will not work for you here.

RugKu9o3DnmmYokyW_x4lA.text: Literally the worst bowl of noodles I've ever had the misfortune of eating- and I was STARVING. When I arrived to the barely occupied restaurant, I stood by the hostess stand for 5 mins with no one attending to me or the person in front of me. Finally someone came (with a poor attitude) and sat us. Food came out and I was hoping it would taste better than it looked.. to my dismay it was unfortunately significantly worse tasting than its appearance. Please save yourself the money, time, and appetite and go anywhere else.

sRAQKHLKGc8v2UYcAe989A.text: Good food and spicy (as we like)  I was interested in more of vegetarian options which and I could get only one or two in the menu but even that was good.

Ju07CADfeCEa1zEeOZTzmg.text: This place is horrible. Food is bland and oily. It's the worst "Chinese" food I've ever had. Combine crap food with a $60 price for 2 (no alcohol), and you get a very angry eater!  Their XO shrimp was like eating store bought noodles covered in oil. It had no taste and 4 shrimp.  The noodles in broth had no taste at all. Noodles and water.  The worst were the  pot stickers. They were big fat doughy fried crap that were an insult to Chinese chefs around the world.  Avoid this tourist trap at all costs! I guarantee you the 4 star reviews are posted by employees and their friends.

NNUVg74ZhQH0V-tAx1H7tw.text: I am pleasantly surprised. My friend and I ordered the Pepper Beef and the Hong Kong Won Ton here. The food arrived within seven minutes and raised no complaints, at all - just the opposite. The Won Ton was delicious; the Pepper Beef was amazing. The meat was cooked just right and so, so soft, I ate more than I usually do! I deeply appreciate that the food here is not as greasy as that in many other Chinese restaurants I have eaten at.   The decoration of the place and the uniforms of the servers and chefs are distinctly Chinese and add a nice cultural touch to customers' dining experience. The walls of the restaurant are made of glass, so customers can sit down inside and eat while observing sports games on the big screen outside. There are seats positioned facing outward from the restaurant for precisely that purpose. I imagine that is a huge plus for sports enthusiasts.   Our server wasn't too talkactive or smile-y, but he was quick and attentive, which is all I need in a waiter. I always had water in my glass, and we never even had the time to notice the lack of anything before he put it on our table.   Prices are pretty average for a restaurant is on the strip, nothing that should come as a shock to anyone. Many of the meat dishes are served with rice, and the chefs have no issue adjusting the spiciness level for customers.

U7NhPOynToUyd_D1Jd-mLQ.text: I don't know how they can substantiate their absorbent pricing for their Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup but I certainly fell for their ploy. Considering I am already on the strip, I didn't want to venture to Spring Mountain Road for noodles so this was literally the closest restaurant. The beef noodle soup was decent, but at $14 before tax is a complete rip off.  It looks like they have a good variety of Asian food, but in order to satisfy your cravings, you would have to pay a premium to indulge.

Ha33JVQTlV74fo5R_-OwZQ.text: One word: OVERPRICED.  But given that you're in Vegas.... what isn't overpriced? The food is actually decent and is probably one of the most authentic Chinese food you can find directly on the strip.  I've only ever ordered one thing: the beef noodle soup. Spicy, flavorful filled with beef & tendon, thin noodles and topped with some green onion and Taiwanese sour cabbage. For $14, it's a major rip off but it definitely hits the spot and it's so good that I can actually finish the whole bowl myself. I tried sharing once and.... let's just say ... THAT was a mistake. I have pretty high standards for beef noodle soup and I definitely like this one.  Speaking of mistakes, don't make this one. As an Asian person, I'm used to ordering a round of water or hot tea for everyone at the table. One time upon ordering tea, the waiter asked me "how many cups for the tea? " and I told him "8, for everyone at the table." - also thinking.... don't you just bring a big pot of tea? ANYWAYS well, I was not informed that tea cost like $2-$3 PER CUP PER PERSON. So after he brought 8 cups and only 4 of us actually drank the tea.... but we still got charged for 8 cups of tea! So ridiculous!! Lesson learned.  They've also remodeled since I came last and it looks GREAT! Definitely looks more Vegas and gives a more modern/clean look. Service is ok, could be better.  Sober or drunk.... the beef noodle soup is good. 3.5 stars for good noodles, nice atmosphere and location in the Venetian and... good noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My regular
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Remodeled! Damn.

Hg9CjM_M0puWjeoQRRwvlw.text: This is in the Venetian hotel.  We have eaten here many times and the food is always excellent.  We have brought many friends over the last few years and they always agree that whatever they get is great as well.  My favorite dish is this the siu chiu beef, crispy noodles with vegetables and black bean sauce.  I crave it even as I write.  The five spice tofu is excellent too, however good chance you may get bts later.  The cost is very reasonable for a Venetian restaurant.  Give it a try.

tSwi_W8-gB-QS5PUtBta2Q.text: I ate here under the influence of alcohol so readers beware haha! But I think even if it was not a late night eat, what I ordered is pretty legit. I'm not sure about the rest of the stuff, but the Szechuan Beef Noodle soup hits the spot, especially after a night of partying. It's not worth $15 so 3.5 stars overall. The price tag fits Vegas even though it doesn't fit my pocket book. I'd definitely come back and order the same thing again the next time I'm there though!

1uVQJl2h4tOSsq5AVFEyog.text: great for hangovers when you do not want to drive outside the strip. it's a bit pricy, but the food comes out fast and it's pretty damn good. the service is like any other asian restaurant which is fast, rude, and kind of annoying...or i maybe saying that because every time i come here i'm realllly hungover haha.

YczshByUxyQyaHbRo8_VNQ.text: Very good noodle joint on The Strip. Had the combination w/ chicken, bbq pork, and seafood.  Fast too. Took back to the room so we could enjoy some Angry Orchard Hard cider - my friend is now addicted - and it was a great combination. Now we want to try the rest of the menu!

ozXXNr64mRATiolP8OXvXA.text: Delicious! Best noodle soups we've had outside of Taiwan. The spicy beef is the best! The spicy shrimp was also tasty. You're not paying for ambiance, as your view is the poker tournament area of the casino, but the food is inexpensive and amazingly good.

gN2fAQnnxWj7EjwDidh98w.text: i dream about this noodle place, but not especially for the noodles. They have the most amazing shrimp fried rice that I have ever encountered. Seriously-AAAAAmazing! Its kind of hard to pick a noodle dish because the descriptions are vague and the servers are very "authentic".  I've been there at least a half dozen times and the shr fr rice is the most amazing dish every time, as well as the hot and sour soup. Those are the best in my book.

9RRNoTyaRQyEIHpEs-1tqg.text: Group had after clubbing munchies and we didn't want to drive to Chinatown so went to Noodle Asia.  The food is tasty but they really need to easy up on the salt. We ate family style. One friend ordered the wonton soup, which was okay, I'm not really a wonton soup kind of gal but it was the cleanest (sorry there's a word in my culture that I can't find in English that accurately describes the broth ppl that are Taiwanese and Chinese know what I mean). Another friend ordered pai goo noodles, which was pretty good. Another friend order the beef noodle soup and the noodles were good but it's on the spicy side and I think a little less salt would be better. My friend did try to get more soup for her beef noodle soup but they said they were charge just for the soup.  Booo. So we opted out. She also ordered the blacked peppered beef udon, which really aren't really udon noodles, since this place is mainly Chinese influenced food and not really Japanese and that was just okay.  I ordered the Shanghai rice cake dishes, which was good but a little too salty. And another friend ordered the pork and special preserved egg congee, which was good but the pork was also too salty. Since I try not to overeat since I'm an old lady now and don't want tummy issues before bed I didn't puff up the next day. But some of the others gals puffed up a bit from the salt the next day.

ejIn5a-rbIdEI5cot3wyfw.text: Four stars seems high, but I feel I must because this place just hits the spot when you're road-weary, hungry, hung-over, and need basic, real comfort food.  I'd suggest sticking with the soups and noodles.  The other dishes are okay, but not their strong suit, and, as other reviewers have mentioned, priced on the high side.  However, I don't mind paying $10-$12 for a big bowl of great soup in Vegas, whereas I'd be might pissed if I were charged the same in SF.  Be sure to request "No MSG."  They are very accomodating.

maLr1ePnsfJHYHZWAdwUAg.text: After digesting the fact that you're paying probably 3x as much as normal, please enter this establishment and enjoy your meal! I was brought here by some of my Taiwanese friends on a previous trip and now it's a spot I crave when I'm in Vegas. Whether you're hungover or just plain hungry, the Szechwan Beef noodle soup will deliver. House-made noodles with tender chunks of stewed beef in a delicious broth...you can't go wrong with this one. Their beef rice noodles and their fried rice dishes are an excellent choice as well. My only qualm is with their service which can be pretty horrendous as you'll have to flag your server whether it is for a napkin, more tea, your check, your check to be processed...you get the picture.

tGfeMJ0i2L5I_x8JbECkFQ.text: We are frequent visitors to Las Vegas (8+ times a year) and our trip would not be complete without a meal from Noodle Asia.  Noodle Asia never disappoints us in its quality of food or service.  Siu Xiang Beef (Beef in Spicy Bean Sauce over Pan Fried Noodles) is simply the best we ever had in Las Vegas.  Hot Sour Soup, Spicy cucumber salad and steam pot stickers - My compliments always to the chef and staff at this restaurant who can be proud of their consistency.

6Fjs1SfKgyRvdlSbBlJidw.text: won ton soup 4.5 stars shanghai noodles 3 stars szechaun noodles 4 stars (perfect texture)  would come back for won ton soup and szechuan noodles.  I didn't like the shanghai noodles because it was very carby and lacked the protein that my body needed, it was good but its just a preference thing.

-QRYaGZawwh9awbqbGFCtA.text: i read the previous reviews. and they were very helpful. and the chinese sausage fried rice was very good. when youre in vegas everything is expensive. i went here recently after christmas and wanted asian food. this is conveniently in the venetian where we were staying, so tried it out.  -bf had the wonton noodle soup-was actually really good. -i had their chinese sausage fried rice- delicious -appetizer- -tried friend's spicy wonton appetizer.- really good as well. Friends: had schezuan spicy noodle thing, they said it was good. We ate here for lunch. and by 5pm i was here again for early dinner and ordered what my bf had for lunch (haha), and by 8pm we were at the wynn buffet waiting in line.  Would have given this place 5 stars, but i only tried few dishes, and others looked too greasy.

rmlAO7-Uis0ZXkZ89JxYbQ.text: unimpressive service with tasty food and extra hair.  i'm still kind enough to give tips and 3 stars for this restaurant, just because we love the fried rice here.

ACOWd8iIovdjg4mB1XtCNA.text: the BEST place to eat after 1 a.m. :)   if you haven't tried their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup then try that first (or have at least one person from your group order this dish)   my second favorite dish: mooshoo chicken/pork. chinese style burritos with hoison sauce  trust me... you won't be disappointed. we stop by everytime we're in vegas... just like the regulars stop by el taurino in L.A. we stop by here in vegas :) hopefully you like it as much as we do.

UrBYAGmmpqQRzSZXvfOvvA.text: @ the Venetian next to the casino  Loved it!  The beef noodle soup is delicious!  We came here by recommendation of a friend and we all ordered the same thing.  I want to go back again just for this!  YUM!  You definitely won't be disappointed if you get it.  It's a very big portion size (think big big soup bowl) - I think you'd be good if you shared this and then ordered another entree.  Or just eat it on it's own!  The beef and the noodles will help fill you up.  We also ordered fried rice just to mix it up a little and try something else...but it was unremarkable.  My only problem with the restaurant - if you drink the water, you can definitely taste the oils/residue from the other food probably because all the dishes are washed together...GROSS!  I'd bring a separate bottle of water since you'll get thirsty.  :P

jBj6mWsErz09o2LWD5Lf4Q.text: I cannot believe I have not reviewed Noodle Asia until now.  I eat here at least twice every time I'm in Vegas.  To be honest, the last time I was there, there was some lack in consistency.  Still, this place brings a smile to my face.  When it is good, it is very good. Winners: The Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup, congee, and pan fried noodles.  Yum!

UdwR2rKGYBRw8L1xaHSFDw.text: Went to Noodles Asia, late one night.  Love how they are open till 3:00 AM.  Had a group of eight the service was very quick, we sat down ordered and food came right out.  I ordered the Mixed Seafood Pan-Toasted Noodles it was very good, piping hot I burnt my tongue.  I did think it was pricey but then again your in Las Vegas isn't EVERYTHING :-)

TmNqhY9JUkqv3cieqwVi5g.text: I give the restaurant 1 star not for the food - the noodle dish I had with bbq pork and shrimp with a light curry sauce was perfectly cooked and the jasmine tea was hot and plentiful. But the lack of customer service was abysmal. I was by myself and it was 2 pm and not too busy (restaurant was half full), but once I got my food that was the end of seeing my server or anyone else.  I sat staring at the wall for 45minutes after finishing eating before I finally had to practically tackle someone who was not my server to ask for the check.  I was so mad at that point that I paid the bill - with no tip and left.  Gigantic customer service fail...

W2c11TyDF-EbiDVWHl8d2w.text: You have to know what to get.  I only get the beef noodle soup and it is spicy Asian divineness.  The broth is yummy, the meat is tender, and the noodles are like ramen heaven.  It's a good deal for Las Vegas so if you want a quick lunch and you're in the mood for Asian food, this is a great option.

dgZqQ_PBqNxO6a95lCN4mg.text: We were craving noodle soup since it was raining the whole day in Vegas and i ended up having colds. so we ordered: - wonton soup... very very good, it is the best wonton soup i have ever had, the soup was refreshing and warmed my tummy, the wonton was so tender and tasted fresh.. a must have. - shanghai style noodle.. good.. it is okay just like regular noodle. - tainan noodle,., good.. it is not too salty, warm the tummy.  The price is bit more expensive but i guess that what you pay for hotel food. I give them 4 stars for the wonton soup and for being opened until late night.

VFYjJ5DquKTIr9IfeINfig.text: The beef noodle soup is FANTASTIC! The beef was tender, the broth flavorful, and the portions were huge. This is a great value for the cost.

IRHTWKVGt4NdE3iFyPNUTQ.text: This is about as authentic as you can get for Hong Kong style noodles and rice dishes. Just take a look! Most of the customers are Asian; most of the wait staff is Asian and of course the 4 chefs/cooks are Asian.  Yes, it costs more since it is in the Venetian but by the time you get in a cab or drive to Chinatown, you have wasted precious time away from strip.   I recommend any of the noodle or rice dishes - big dishes too. What is more impressive is the dim sum. They have it ready to steam and it comes out fresh.   And the additional bonus - cleaner than those chinatown establishments.

a3Nm_USfkTLRUZmuohnl_A.text: Mongolian beef and pineapple seafood rice is great. Crab rangoons are light and tasty. Food comes out fast. Give it a try!

HUVAhesQkA1kxw6dlPqb_g.text: Eating here on the last night of Vegas has became a tradition for my bf & I. He thinks that Chinese broths cure his hangover, but I can't agree with him since I don't know what a hangover feels like.   We ordered:  Cantonese beef stew noodle - big chunks of meat and bone marrow with egg noodles. Broth was too bland for me, but it can be fixed with some chili oil and soy sauce...  Har Gow - tastes like every Har Gow I've tried..  Si Jiu Beef pan-toasted noodles - I love the crisp of the noodle, sauce was seasoned well. I love this dish very much.   Szechwan Beef and Shanghai noodles were a big hit as well.

wF7Iehmt7GuIT2DxMcdAMw.text: I ordered the Ba Bao Noodles to go while staying at the Venetian and I was impressed. The dish was $14, which is extremely affordable in Vegas terms. The dish comes Mandarin noodles topped with jumbo shrimp in a spicy, shrimp sauce and peanuts, stir-fried Napa cabbage, Chinese mushrooms, spinach. The spicy, shrimp sauce was beautifully authentic tasting.  Need I say more really, conveniently located in the hotel right off the casino floor, I wanted to go to Noodle Asia every day I was there.

vs7yruLbn8a8FAD0_fLtmQ.text: One of the least expensive meals we had in Vegas.  Good value for a hot sit down meal.  I was feeling a little mealy from all the drinking and the smoke in the casino so I decided to have a soothing bowl of chicken congee which is rice cooked in broth to a porridge with pieces of chicken breast topped with green onions and bits of crispy won tons.  It was a large bowl but it was so delicious and tasty that I finished most of it.  My husband ordered the large won ton soup which he enjoyed.  We shared a pot of jasmine tea.  The bill came to around $25 which we thought was a steal compared to all the other meals in Vegas.  Definitely a good place to sit down and have a decent meal at a moderate price!

ltGWjmzlXdv8Ek_77jCM7w.text: Pricey! ouch! never paid this much for the same style dishes in SF but here is vegas and it is pricey no matter what restaurants you dine on the strip hotels. I am just glad that their Chinese food is authentic! I have been here couple times over the past few years their level of service and quality of food have been consistent, will keep coming back!

QH-G98NJDrviTHHoWpzSQg.text: Food was good but a tad expensive for what you get.  Service was okay.  I did find it weird though that the server hovered while my brother-in-law was trying to fill out the tip and total.  I felt that was kind of rude and made us feel rushed.

lwTAnA3W4dmAymCQ5n13cw.text: I've ate here a lot in the past.   I wouldn't go out of my way for it, but if I'm hungry, and they're in front of me, I'll find myself sitting down at one of their tables.    Good stuff.  Dishes I remember my grandmother making.  But nothing that compared to her recipes

TKj9WsJaBQ_j5AXxvS9l2A.text: This isn't a bad spot if you want decent Chinese, don't want to overpay and don't want to wait hours to complete dinner service. Some of the dishes didn't hold up to other options we have back home (mushu chicken, Shanghai noodles) but the won ton soup, steamed won tons and Mongolian beef were very good. I'd come back if I was traveling here alone, but likely wouldn't make it a location for dinner otherwise.

4hfYJQj056LCo22WRrXr3A.text: Before going downtown to throw some hard 8s & 6s at the craps table, my buddy and I decided to get a quick meal so we didn't have to eat during our all night of gaming. We found this place and decided to check it out because it seemed to have Asian patrons.   We were quickly seated and ordered the Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce ($10) and the spicy ying nan rice noodles ($14) and the service was very quick. The portions were decent and it wasn't as greasy compared to the True Chinese restaurants back home. The spiciness on the soup was fair and the Chinese broccoli was steamed just right where it still had a crunch.   Expensive, but what do you expect in the Venetian? It's an alternative when you crave decent Chinese food on the strip late at night without driving to Chinatown.

Uvarld6urNxMY2BBl_Xm4w.text: Good news... They've added fish sauce. And their spicy beef noodle soup is the bomb.

H1rfJbBVrodhc5RT9Lz9vQ.text: Excellent soft chicken noodles. Dim sums were safe selections and very tasty. Definitely recommend!

SULAkEkxNDOF4bxpoMkEkw.text: Might give them a 4 stars if I weren't asian, and I might give them 5 if I weren't asian from San Gabriel Valley in LA. We got noodles and calamari there, and they were alright. Maybe it's just me, I'm not impressed, kinda fooled by other 5 stars reviews here. But you can still consider it if you're craving for some asian food in the hotel. Just don't expect too much from those 5 stars reviews.

ymYD5rVblivebQWKQ-vBrg.text: Best chicken wings! Best pan fried noodles.  Best. Best. Best. Open late. Best Chinese food in Vegas.

RMfY9pGCt_iHY6Nct9W9fQ.text: This place is so delicious! The chicken fried rice is the best! Its located in the Venetian Casino, not the mall! Service is awesome and super fast! Portions are big enough to share with the table and some! They also do to go orders which is really nice so you can take it to your room! Very authentic and fresh food! Definitely going back the next time I am in Vegas!

gNFHOOY3ui0qT_rX4OnyXA.text: Very legit Chinese Food in Vegas! Located in the Venetian! Only flaw is that it is a bit pricey, but what's NOT pricey in Vegas?  Recommendations:  * THE CHICKEN WINGS! --The seasoning is so bomb! I even ate every single piece of the seasoning with my rice! Must try! It comes with only 6 wings so order wisely! * Salted Fish Fried Rice--pretty flavorful! It's a good entree to have!   Tip: If you're with a group it is best that you order family style so you can have the best of both worlds ;) and after splitting the check it would be a decent price!

1dYgBQ2-vJwQdbiN2eid4g.text: Okay Chinese food nothing special. The good thing is that they are open late, about the only place. Came here twice late at night. First time I had the egg flower soup. We shared the Mongolian beef and rice. Pot of hot oolong tea. Mongolian beef tasted good to me but a bit spicy for my gf. So the next time we had orange chicken. Eggflower soup tasted different the next time, not as tasty.  Service is good.

0E68NwXalWzVfz_W2wdiXg.text: Vegetarians beware!  Ordered two vegetarian dishes from here. Both had pieces of mystery meat in them. It was busy, so very difficult to get the servers attention- apparently the only way to do this was by holding out our credit card. The sever huffed, took my plate and credit card, and stormed off to show the plate to the manager who literally laughed. They then ran my credit card and had a different person bring back my receipt to avoid speaking to me. I tried to get the manager, but he refused to talk to me as well.  Not even an offer to remake my uneaten food, or at least box it so I could give it to someone more excited to eat mystery meat.   At least an apology or acknowledgement of the mistake would have been nice. It shouldn't be that hard to cook what I order without mixing in pieces of someone else's order. The rude and disrespectful treatment I received is all the convincing I need to not head back to this restaurant.

VT1FJtaBiVcZrAtX6n-Iug.text: Horrible place to eat! Don't go there!!!!! I ordered a plate of fried noodles with different kinds of fish and the fish was so smelly, it was unbearable and impossible to eat! I am sur it was perished and besides, when I asked the waitress if I could switch with another dish because I was not able to support the smell, she refused! First time in a restaurant that I cannot switch and that I have to pay for something I didn't eat. DON'T GO THERE THEY SERVE PERISHED FOOD!

OCBm_eJb9pBdWxYll9J6AA.text: One of the better places to grab a quick lunch on the strip.   The good:  ++ Good food but a little greasy and salty. We ordered the mixed greens in garlic sauce (Ok but lacks flavor) and mixed vegetable fried rice (Yummy and highly recommend!) ++ Fast service. There was a long line but it moved very fast.  ++ Really liked the modern Asian decor.   The bad: -- Very few (3 or 4) vegetarian options. -- Quite pricey. 2$ for a teeny bowl of rice. But it is on the strip so I can't really complain.   Tip: Looks like you can order take out and bypass the line. Just walk up to the maitre d'.

FVM59j0swuJbQb9J9TBI8Q.text: Hits the spot. Eaten here for years and every meal is consistently good. Polite and quick service. Dine in or take out...food tastes great either way. I recommend the chicken stir fried soft noodles.

F4yLv9F3Yi8VRiOzcjsLqw.text: I used to have dinner here almost every night while staying at the Venetian.  They had a dish on their menu called MINCED BEEF and it was served over rice with an egg on top,  scallions and peas. I loved this entree, however, they discontinued it and it no longer is on the menu.  I am really disappointed about not being able to order it and wish they would start making it again.  It's a really simple dish and all they need is ground beef to be able to make it specially.  I would definitely give them 5 stars if this would be put back on their menu. I would really like the recipe so I could make it at home.

QPjIehKDrzPEi9-izID4ig.text: Stayed at Venetian for a work conference and was looking for a relatively quick lunch. While this place had a line when I walked up it moved quick and was worth the 5-10 mins I waited. Sat at the bar area and service was good and the food was solid. I got baked crab rangoons which were delicious and the Dan Dan noodles, which were served with spicy peanut sauce and sesame. The Dan Dan noodles were unique and interesting if you want to try something different, but overall not what I thought they would be. I would go back again and not get the Dan Dan noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Baked Crab Rangoons
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dan Dan Noodles

Y2zhoWjzxvBvINANCqKE7Q.text: I would've given a 4 stars if not for the horrible green tea mochi ice cream.. It was one of the worst ever! However, the main course was pretty good.  If you like more flavor,  all you need to do is ask for the spicy sauce in oil!  I ordered a Singapore mei fun with vegetables and eggs and it turned out great so I would totally recommend it for vegetarians. My boyfriend ordered chicken and fish fried rice and he really liked it too. Overall, a good place for main courses especially late in the night!!

nRPgdjlHa6U-ODYFXeCqiA.text: The staff were friendly and our service was great.  Food is not so bad but it's not great. I don't know if they purposely under season their dishes because I noticed almost everone around us including myself had to add soy sauce. I also think some of their dishes like the Pho for example is over priced.

Dch-YxncsGyTF_Ixb0zJ6g.text: Drunken friend: Let's go to Noodle Asia...this place looks hella good!  Next morning sober, same one: Let's go to Noodle Asia.  Buzzed ass not feeling so good me after Tao Beach: Give me 30 minutes to sleep then I'll get ready for our dinner at Scarpetta.  30 minutes go by...Me: Okay, give me 15 more minutes....another 15 minutes and I'm still sleeping...5 minutes before my dinner reservation, okay, I'll call Scarpetta to cancel, let's just go downstairs to Noodle Asia.     Went downstairs a little after 7 the other Saturday and got a table easily.  I wouldn't say this restaurant is Asian fusion, as it's more "authentic" than the likes of let's say PF Changs and Hakasaan, but like I asked the waiter what type of noodles were the beef rice noodles and he said they were like chow fun.  So I dedcied to go with the beef rice noodle but asked for it gravy style instead of the dry version.  I was surprised that they were actually the thinner rice noodle (not super thin like vermicelli, but Chinese chow fun noodles are thicker than the noodles I got).  While the noodles were slightly thinner and the gravy wasn't 100% like what I get back at Chinese restaurants back home, Noodle Asia serves up some good, comforting Asian food.  The quality of the ingredients were a little better than typical Chinese restaurants as well.  The spicy wontons were a favorite and my chow fun was huge enough to serve up to 3 people, or one really hungry friend plus me (he helped me out in addition to his entree).  My "chow fun" was $15, which, yes you can get half off off the strip, but, first off, if I couldn't even make it to Cosmo, then there was no way I was going to make it off the strip, and 2 it's expected to be pricier as it's on the Strip.    Service was pretty good, minus a slightly older lady with RBF and major attitude when I asked for change, and for two cards to be charged a certain amount.  3.5 rounded up.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

T-MyyMU_zu4dmUBxvBBLzw.text: Being a first timer in Vegas. We wanted some pho type of soup for a hangover. I browsed over Yelp and found this place. We arrived around 12PM and had a 3 minute wait. We were sat at the bar. They came and took out order within 2 minutes of sitting down. We tried the fried rice and it was really good. And it was a big portion. We also tried the Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle. It had good flavor and was big portioned as well. They are a bit pricey but I mean it is located in the Venitian Hotel in the strip.   If I were to come back to Vegas I would definitely come back.

zROq9brGg61gtzqp4MaRaw.text: Hits the spot...every.single.time.   The Szechwan Beef noodle soup is a must-stop for me every time I'm in Vegas. Extra spicy, of course.

rM_1XMitAEloHHTOoDuO5Q.text: Holy Wong Fei Hong Batman!  This place is popping with Asians and Asian noodles! Pow!    Don't know Wong Fei Hong, no worries I gather many "Westerners" wouldn't.  However, they do know one thing -- this place.  Noodle Asia is located inside the Venetian Hotel in Vegas.  I wouldn't think such a restaurant exists in The Venetian, but you know what; it works!  Noodle Asia reminds me of the 24 hour cafes located in California.  After a night out for drinks you need some grease!  Noodle Asia has all the classic Asian dishes from Shanghai, Black Peppered, Fried Rice, and Dim Sum too!  Needless to say, this place doesn't play around when it comes to Chinese food.  Tab bit overpriced in my opinion for what you get simply because the protein almost drowned out by the carbs.  Granted I enjoy my carbs, just not too much.  Also, is it me or do I need to drink a lot of water after a meal here?  I guess what I'm trying to say is that it's salty!  Guess that goes well for the "American" diet.    There seems to be a line during the day which is not bad.  The restaurant is located right next to the sports betting area so a quick glance over to see the score is awesome. - Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

AxYKH2tcYXVJOM84cwMdKA.text: One of my go to spots when in Las Vegas, my friends and I also always make one of our meals here and all dishes are solid.  My personal favorite is the szechuan beef noodle dish.  I will be honest and say one of the most amazing meals I have ever had.  Simple dish but complex flavors.  The broth is to die for and noodles and beef quality is spot on.  Different dumpling options, rice dishes and BBQ as well.  I didn't even mention the location.  Right next to the Venetian sports book with big glass windows that allow you to watch games while eating some great food.  Must stop by when you are in Vegas and craving noodles.

V3xkKMrb_DJfWgbdBSDY8A.text: Mmmm ... Not impressed. Ordered to go and felt rushed to make a decision (the place was not packed)..:: only one (1) Pho option with a ton of crap MEAT!!!  Brisket, tripe (EWH ... Didn't get that) and sausage ..: really? Can I get some shrimp or chicken???  Probably won't go back ... It was just Vegas ok.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Broth was ok...

NH7s_UOQYuw18vXEv_A05g.text: Like other reviews before me stated: this place provides DECENT asian noodle soups to cure your hang overs! My story is typical. I was a little woozy after a night at Surrender (Whoop whoop). My body was screaming for a big bowl of pho (but I didn't want to drive of the strip). My body was craving for a bowl of instant Shin Ramen (but I didn't want to pay a ridiculous $5 for hot water). Since we stayed at the Palazzo, I agreed with no hesitation with my friend suggested Noodle Asia :)  Service: sloooooow. Tookd them forever to seat us (Okay, maybe not that long, I was just uber hungry and impatient). Took them a while to take our orders and bring water out too even though the place doesn't look too packed.  Food: authentic quality. When the server finally brought the food out. I was like "Big bowl of delicious hot soup, welcome to my tummy!" I ordered the Spicy Ying Nan Noodles (4 stars  for taste) and my friends had the HK Wonton soup. They also enjoyed their big bowls of soups a lot. I should have tried a bit for a taste review. The portion was generous. My empty stomach was satisfied to be filled with liquid other than alcohol. Heh heh. The soup was already spicy, but I slapped on more chili to unclog my sinuses.  Overall, the soup made me feel a lot better. Honestly, nothing beats comfort Asian food after all. After digesting that bowl of soup, I was ready to take on another day at Sin City. Why the 3 stars then? Because the poor college student in me is very bitter at paying 2 times the prices of what the bowl of soup really is worth...

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodles

aPfwzHfMeMZUgq4wWCQIkQ.text: The only thing that I crave and order when I feel like a hot bowl of noodle soup is their Sichuan beef noodle soup. The soup is full of flavor, the meat is tender and melts in your mouth and the only complaint I have is that I always want more.....more noodles...more meat....larger bowl. What can I say, I love noodles.  Place is great to eat at since it's open until 3am, so if you don't feel like eating at Grand Lux cafe and are staying at Venetian or Palazzo, walk on over to Noodle Asia and order a bowl.   Is it the best beef noodle soup....no, you can only find the best in Taiwan...however it'll take care of your cravings while in Las Vegas

zRU5Lb1_ln_cHYovZptYgg.text: can't take the asian out of me. i duno about you but when i'm drunk or hungover i need me some asian cuisine, even if it's mediocre.   what i ate: - combo fried rice: unremarkable. as expected. a bit on the oilier side. enough for two people.  - egg flower soup (cup): exactly as expected. unremarkable  pros: - asian food, something for everyone. while leaned more towards chinese cuisine, there was pho, dim sum, etc.  - open 24/7 - located on campus at the hotel i was staying at - fast efficient service. traditional asian style as in, flag down your server if you need something.  - fresh coconut water/juice. when you're hungover, this is a godsend.   mediocre: - the food was so so. i mean it wasnt bad, but it wasnt great either.   cons:  - price was a bit steep for the food, but you're paying for the convenience of not having to drive to chinatown.   would i come again? sure why not?

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fresh super sweet coconut! $8 with tax and tip

SE5nVrQW1UTB89gNOWh8VA.text: This place is overpriced and is not delicious. Definitely DO NOT get the pho (& this is coming from a Vietnamese person). Seafood Kimchi Udon had no kimchi flavor in the soup. The Vietnamese coffee was alright. Not the best & not worth $5. Same goes for Thai tea (it has no Thai tea flavor).   I would recommend spending your money elsewhere unless you have credits. I would for for the appetizers because they have a bit more flavor such as the fire chicken wings. Service is not great either. Nope, nope, nope.

GH9IkcZpxauzhOzKjwfx2A.text: Visited a few times over the past weekend since I was staying at the Palazzo. The noodle soups were fine - the beef stew is a clear broth with egg noodles. Not bad if you're trying to recover from a night (or day of drinking).  For the other night I visited, I ordered their BBQ duck, chicken and pork. This is a $30 dish and it is only meat. No rice. No Chinese scallion & ginger oil sauce which is standard for a dish like this. I thought they had forgot it and asked for it under the assumption that they had just forgot it. Our server looked puzzled, spoke to a manager, ran to the back with a saucer, came out empty handed and told me that they did not have any. This was disappointing.   I think we do have to remember that this is a casino in the middle of the desert and we should manage our expectations. Is it good for an Asian restaurant in a Las Vegas casino? Yes. Will you be disappointed? Only if you anticipate authentic dishes.   I would go back again, but would steer clear of the BBQ plate since it's relatively expensive compared to the other items. There was very little char siu and of course, the absence of a crucial condiment.

pihDl_cDZAuVQnACru1P1g.text: This place was amazing!! I got the combination rice it was sooooo good. We really enjoyed ourselves

WLHOhmCBH7Hf-4Xk_SxQlA.text: My boyfriend and I were staying at the Venetian and came here for dinner. The food was great and the servers were super friendly. I highly recommend the potstickers!

Ns-Zr7oxjfamsYa3m0bGKA.text: Shzechuan beef noodles really hit the spot after clubbing. Dim sum as appetizers came out really fast which was very satisfying

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

c61uw46DCjA7C7AE5DKDbw.text: If I could, I would give this place zero stars. The waitresses and waiters are horrible. I went here yesterday night and was surely disappointed. First, i wasnt properly greeted. The hostesses didnt ask how many was in my party and just ushered me to any seat. I didnt know she was seating me until she flagged me down, but no talking. Second, there was a little bug in my water. I told the staff and they didn't say anything, just walked away. Third, whenever I flagged them down, they would ignore me and attend someone else who flagged them down AFTER me. The only reason why I'm giving them a 1 star is honestly because I can't give zero stars. Also, food was just okay. Nothing special. Yheres better food on the strip. Don't waste your time and money here.

5Eu7hlKYhDAohbqTx_o0gw.text: Decent Chinese/Asian food. Their fruit tea with boba is really good. Too bad, we tried this place at the end of our trip. So much better than Yong Kang Restaurant in the Paris Casino. Everything we ate was decent food. Fried chicken wings, fried rice, duck noodle soup and sauteed veggies

OVXDV7586c3qwwioRBDUVA.text: I personally think the overall food was alright but given the price and the atmosphere I expected it to be better than alright.   Beef noodle soup - good, recommended. Reminded me of beef hand pulled noodle I got in nyc but that was better. Beef chow fun - like any other fast food Chinese food, so if you're looking for something unique skip it, but I liked it.  Chinese broccoli  - average so I'd order another veggie dish BBQ combo - variety of meat offered but a bit pricey  Other nuances of the night: Service is slow. Can't get a refill in tea and can't get extra plates to share without waiting. You have to pay $2 for a cup of rice and  $4.50 for the tea pot (you can refill for as much as you like). This place wasn't amazing but filled my hungry stomach.

wrHY3z0-4pvhRDKy70SSKg.text: food is good and cheap. they are also open late as well so it works out perfectly. depends on what you get it can range from 10 bucks or more. its Asian food instead of all the other places you can eat. in case you get too drunk and just want some Chinese food to wash it down.

vuG_2WUCDMdX7eov0rpmRQ.text: TL:DR This place is good with a few tiny drawbacks that made me not give it a five.   So the place it's in is alright. Honestly a lot of noise so if you were expecting a quiet dinner then this is not he place. Also you can see everything outside so it's alright.   Wait time is little to nothing to get seated and also the food gets prepped fast. So if you're really hungry go there you'll be happy.   The food is good. If you're big on iced tea and boba they got it so that'll make you happy.   The food is my gripe. So it's not terribly expensive compared to other things on the strip but the meat had tons of bone which made the food look bigger even though it wasn't. Also, if you're not a fan of salt beware the broth is salty along with a lot of their foods but other than that it was a pleasant experience and I enjoyed the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

9EfAjXpKcI7U5D9de_z-lQ.text: Dined in late night here. Ordered Singapore Noodles with Shrimps. The service is good, staff is friendly, ambiance is above average with the restaurant being open and blending with the Casino. The quality of food is okay but the quantity is large. There is wide variety on their menu that one may try.

QTIGZkJGX7cSF_yA0iaVPg.text: Nestled in the casino floor at the Venetian, this spot offers some amazing Asian cuisine for a really good price! The staff is very friendly and the food is delicious. I started with the Vietnamese coffee. Omggg amazing!  For a starter, I went with the potstickers. The sauce that is served with them.... out of this world!!! The pot stickers where perfectly cooked and huge in size. The meat inside was seasoned perfectly. For entree, I ordered the szechwan beef noodle soup. I am soooo happy I listened to the other yelpers for this item. Delicious broth, perfectly cooked beef and just a bowl of happiness. The flavor was unlike any noodle soup I have ever had. My total cost for the meal was $40.   Definitely worth checking out if you are staying at the Venetian!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RD5rJQBizNkBVOq165WxeQ.text: Despite the fact that there might be a long wait for Noodle Asia, overall it will be worth the wait. Something that stood out to me was the fact that the management, thanked me and my friend not once but twice for waiting to be seated. Granted we only waited about 20 minutes, it felt nice to hear the management care about the wait.  Onto the food...  The Dan Dan Noodles were well worth the wait too! I opted to get the Pork out of the dish and was happy. This bowl of noodles with some peanut butter, and spices, and broth was extremely filling. I almost slurpped out what was in the bowl!  The thai iced tea was perfect, very sweet! and the spring rolls were okay, to be honest nothing to rave about, but they were a very big serving.   My downfall about Noodle Asia is the location. It's inside the casino, on the bottom floor, but its a bit of a maze to get to. Plus side--the bathrooms are 5 feet away!

9MKeufgXxb60zePCHNwQuQ.text: This place is bomb. Part of the reason I stay at the Palazzo is because I can stop by here after a long bacc sesh.

pzDggXVSW7qXoX07FaxfXA.text: Bad quality of service, do not go. Some of the waiters were from China, and they were bitchy to the Asian customers and give you bad attitude for no reason. I was asked to pay $2 for hot water. Does that sound crazy? That is how stupid the waiters are, trying to rip you off. By the way, do not order the pot stickers, the dumpling skin was way too thick.

I1vw_K5mKb43ogSFHFZpDA.text: This place is our favorite for Asian food. Nasir Lamar is out of this world. You can order just the curry chicken. I recommend Yan Chow fried rice (combination fried rice). The price is reasonable.

vI_G7X4smqJjf6e7_EZEfQ.text: This place was good. Service was great and fast. I ordered shrimp dumpling, hot and sour soup, fried rice, cheese rangoons and cucumber. Everything was great! One less star for the cucumber appetizer. It was a little soggy and no flavor.

QSnUmaCSS_M_dZse_g6lrQ.text: THIS IS NOT CHINESE FOOD !!!!  Seriously the WORST asian/chinese food I have ever eaten....SERIOUSLY !!!  We ordered the lettuce cups as a starter, VERY DRY, horribly salty and only 3 lettuce cups were given....we had to order extra lettuce twice, just to finish the meat, there were four of us so we ordered extra large plate.....horrible.  We moved on to the combonation fried rice.....served on a PLATE !! Not in a bowl, and NO FLAVOR whatsoever....do not go here, Kung Pao Chicken was super greasy and just chicken and peanuts, NOTHING ELSE !!!  Swimming in some over salted brown sauce....what a waste of our first meal in Las Vegas, NEVER EVER GO HERE !!! NEVER !!!!

YKknYmmrML4BN9S3IBkTgA.text: Hong Kong wonton soup tastes like instant noodle.  Came out to be $14 something after tax.  Does not taste good either. Over priced for an instant noodle.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hong Kong Wonton instant noodle soup

5EIN9sBgClL1LpezfydmDA.text: Asian restaurant on the Casino level of Venetian.  We were looking for a quick affordable bite for lunch.  Noodle Asia fit the bill.     Large selection on the menu.   Service could have been better but they do serve you fast.     The food was tasty and plentiful.  Not all too pretty of a presentation.   Definitely not the best Asian food that I've had.  But for a quick bite at a good price by hotel standards, this is pretty good.

IrasMKnawjNyZePw6puMsg.text: Alright.  This is my favorite restaurant.  Favorite restaurant Nevada.  Favorite restaurant USA.  Earth.  Solar system.  Milky way.  Etc.  It's the best.  This review supersedes any previous and future reviews.

u-ysur2kS1I5OwWgxr940A.text: After a weekend in Vegas, Beef Noodle Soup sounded amazing. I was told that authentic Szechwan beef noodle soup was waiting for me at Noodle Asia. We were running late and I took my luggage with me so that I could head straight to the airport after lunch.  We were seated right away and the two of us each got our own bowl of beef noodle soup and we shared an order of Cantonese roast duck.  The noodles were so satisfying. The soup had a good amount of flavor and the noodles had an excellent chewy texture. Have I had better beef noodle soups before? Absolutely but this was very solid.  I'm glad we tried the duck and it was ok. It was nice to have something else to munch on besides the noodles.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roasted duck
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef noodle soup

QkT53ecZAT6AZo9J6NhrSg.text: Yes, the food is delicious. Yes, the pot stickers were some of the best the I have ever had the opportunity to enjoy. So why not five stars? The service -- now on multiple occasions -- has been so bad, I had to take off one star. But imagine how good it is if I'm giving four stars for some of the worst service I've ever experienced!  Yes, it really is that good.  The funny story in all of this is that my wife and I were just wandering around looking for some breakfast on a lazy Saturday morning. Heavy breakfast at the Grand Lux? No thanks. Walk down to White Castle? Too far and too lazy. Then we saw the sign for Noodle Asia and thought that the idea of fried rice and pot stickers for breakfast sounded great! But when we walked up to the restaurant, we found out that it didn't open until 11 a.m. It was 10:30. So we sat down at a slot, lost $40, and then jumped up as others appeared ready to go to Noodle Asia.  First in line, we were ready to eat. We were seated. And then...nothing. Others had their orders taken but we just sat. And sat. And sat. As food started coming out for others, our order was finally taken, just seconds before we were going to get up and leave. Then others were seated, their orders were taken, and their food was served. We still had nothing.  It wouldn't have been so bad if we hadn't had two cups of hot and sour soup. How hard would it be to simply ladle the soup into a cup and bring it to us?  The problem is that this isn't the first time we have received this treatment at Noodle Asia. On our previous trip to Las Vegas, we had another situation in which we were seated, and after 20 minutes, we got up and left. We actually asked two servers if our order could be taken and they said that they would be right back. But still, nothing.  Once the food arrived, however, it was all worth it. The hot and sour soup was, well, hot AND sour. What a concept! We also ordered the Night Market Fried Rice, which was a fried rice with sliced beef, Thai chilies, bean sprouts, basil, and diced tomatoes. Don't believe the menu that claims that this rice is spicy, but it is incredibly flavorful. The basil flavor lingers throughout each bite and the sliced beef is tender and delicious.  The Pot Stickers were the clear winner of the day. The dough is not that super-thin, frozen pot sticker style. Instead, it is thicker, creating a great crust where it was pan fried, but leaving a nice bite through the rest of the dough. The pork inside has a wonderfully light ginger flavor. I added a touch of what appeared to simply be soy sauce with green onions as well as some chili paste to give it a little kick. The result was a flavor explosion in my mouth that I have never tasted before. These are a must order.  We also tried the Red Won Tons, which were not quite as successful. These, which were also listed as spicy on the menu but were not, had pork fillings and were tossed in Szechwan Hung Yao chili and presented in garlic sauce. The pork tasted similar to the pork in the pot stickers, but the garlic sauce was incredibly oily and tasted almost burned, ending with an unpleasant texture and taste in my mouth.  But it was well worth it. And that was just the basics. I can't wait to get back and try some more!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pot Stickers. So good I already ate three before snapping this.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Red Won Tons. Pass.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Night Market Fried Rice. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

pnmXWPavv1nKRgBqzwW3lw.text: Surprisingly good chinese in casino. Noodles and cantonese specialties. Authentic& tasty, quick service, open late.

LqcjPmitduNX_fqOb3d9hQ.text: Best fried rice ever !!!! Good service. Def will go back! I tried a few of their dishes and I believe if I were to close my eyes and pick anything on this menu it'll  be delicious.

N1ZNvVeHmPcop-iCKFs3FA.text: I tried a duck dish, a bowl of noodle soup and a pen fried noodle. I noticed that all of them were look good, but all of them were not fresh, nearly spoiled meat. Also I smelled mouse waste.  I definitely not gonna go again.  But it has a great location. I think this restaurant still survives only because of the great location.

XCPaX_lMSLah2mYncbqrrA.text: There are elements of my existence that are at time very much like a creature of habit. In the case of food, I will return again and again, if I find a certain dishes quality, and flavor, to be consistently good. I go to Noodle Asia at least once a week. It's my favorite noodle soup in the valley. I get the Schezuan Beef (without any fat) noodle soup, and potstickers for my appetizer. Always. I've tried a few other dishes but tend to stick with these two items most the time. Service is on point. I've never had a bad meal here, or bad service.

Uo1Vxr22DMFOkyC_lbk5cw.text: While staying at the Venetian on business, I was craving some Cantonese food and found this gem. During my week stay in Vegas I came on three occasions and everything was pretty good, at least better than I expected. I was ample to try the shui mai, wonton noodle soup, sweet and sour pork, and the Mongolian beef. My favs were the wonton noodle soup and the Mongolian beef. The shui mai were too salty and the sweet and sour pork was fried in too much flour with too much vinegar in the sauce. Also, keep in mind that this is Vegas so expect a 15-20 percent increase in prices. Overall, if you are in Vegas and craving for some decent Chinese food, I can recommend Noodle Asia.

4SBfvsAjobQMYLKVvMPZSg.text: It is worth with 5 out of 5. The food is very delicious. The staffs are very friendly. The shop is clean. It is inside the Venetian hotel casino. I like seafood noodle soup especially because I can taste their freshness and healthy Soup. If I have a chance, I will visit again this shop surely.
