Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp dumpling
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seafood noodle

B66qO4-C5l_HxxYhWIRENg.text: My cousin practically lives in Vegas and he highly recommended me to eat the Won Ton Mein here. It's like his go to dish so I made sure to eat here during my trip. I arrived a little after 7pm and the place wasn't very busy. The service was initially attentive and the workers spoke Chinese very politely to me. They gave me the option to get the dimsum the same time as my noodle dishes or as an appetizer. I chose it as an appetizer. This was a nice option to have but I wish I got all the food the same time because it got busy and it took awhile to get my noodle dishes. Service also wasn't that great toward the end of my meal so this place is more a 3.5 spot.   It's not often I come to Vegas anymore so I ordered up a feast. I got their Har Gow, Hong Kong Won Ton (Mein), Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup and some hot tea. Hot tea is not free!! I'm Chinese so paying for hot tea at a Chinese restaurant is foreign to me.   Food:  The Har Gow was very good and went great with their chili oil (you need to ask for this item, it's not on the table as a condiment). Har Gow was large and was easy to pick up without it falling apart. The shrimp was fresh and sweet.   Hong Kong Won Ton was just as my cousin described. It's really good and the won tons actually had meat inside vs just fat and filler. Soup was like Hong Kong broth and there was just the right amount of noodles. (Add the chili oil if you like spice, it was sooooo good!)  The Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup was good but my least favorite. It was the dish that I left unfinished. The broth had good flavor and had a slight kick to it. Noodles and beef were ok but nice option for noodles here. Portions were generous but broth could have been hotter (temperature wise).

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hong Kong Won Ton
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Har Gow

aP06FxXoWqTY24WmOfnKtQ.text: Came here after a long night of clubbing because we were too lazy to go off the strip for our usual pho recovery, and this was conveniently located in the Venetian where we were staying. I had the Szechuan beef noodle soup after reading many positive reviews - it definitely helped soothe my hangover, but it wasn't outstanding either. The beef was incredibly tender, but I felt like they could've used a more fragrant spice, rather than simply pouring in a lot of red oil. We also ordered a plate of BBQ pork for the table to share, which was not bad although a bit bland in my opinion.   Service was average as well; my friend's cup was dirty and it took quite a long time for them to return with a new one and they only came around to refill water once. Considering the portion size, the price was not bad, but I would recommend making the trip to Spring Mountain Rd if you want a more satisfying Asian meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodle soup

tOu_rNTAnjOr7Teq0u2qew.text: I love this place! Everytime I'm in Vegas, this is the first place I stop by to get their Schezwan beef noodle soup and their Buddah feast stir fry noodles soup. The reason why I'm giving only 3 stars is because the service was really bad. The moment we sat down, we already knew what we wanted, so we ordered the beef noodle soup with extra noodles and the Buddah feast.   When the noodles came, the beef noodle soup didnt have extra noodles so I called a waiter to double check if the extra noodles were coming. About 10 mins later, another waiter came and asked if everything was okay. "No, it wasn't. Where's my noodles?" They went back to check on the noodles only to find it not put in to the system again. The waiter asked another waiter and then they finally came to double check on my order and write that s*** down. At this point the noodles in the original bowl already soaked up all the soup so we also asked for extra soup.   The noodles finally came out but with no soup. I gave up at this point lol. The stir fry string beans with basil is really good! The roast bbq duck was so tender and the skin was still crispy!   It's okay, I will always have this place in my heart. I love you Venetian noodles! Just have better service

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yum yum!

4NmeG-drhAGiPeXsXjQmXg.text: It smells so much better than it tastes!  I still love how nearly every server is Chinese and their English is not so great. That gives it high marks in the authenticity column.  But then, the mix of dishes they have (hence the Asia in the name, as opposed to China), make it so that they do a lot of things decently, but seemingly none of them super well.  (You know, jack of all trades, master of none, kinda thing).    Being a white girl (and a pale, blonde white girl at that), I feel I have to hyperbolically express how spicy I would like dishes at Asian restaurants, so that they're the normal spice of Asian restaurants. I asked our server if the Ma Po Tofu (very authentic dish I love) is spicy.  She said she didn't know as she doesn't like spicy dishes. It was not spicy, it lacked the Ma La the it should have, and it was fairly bland. Disappointed. The only 'spicy sauce they have if you ask for any is chili oil.   I'm hoping that Jim G no longer wants to curb his late-night cravings here, as it's just not nearly as good as it smells (but it smells delicious!!!)

veTGTa_SeqHG0ytza3bj3A.text: If you are vegan or vegetarian, there are very few options here for you. I'm vegan and I ordered the mixed vegetable noodle soup and asked if they could make the broth vegetarian and they said yes. The "broth" was literally the water they cooked the noodles in, no flavor whatsoever and it was $15! Way overpriced. My sister ordered her meal to go, we waited 30-45 minutes until we asked if it was still coming, the waitress assured us it was on it's way out. We then saw her put the order in right after we asked about it because it seems that she had forgotten about that part of our order. Only giving two stars because I know its hard to accommodate a vegetarian diet and they tried but failed miserably.

pn_TkU3Ml_t8QAm_t4MeeA.text: First off, don't expect good service when you come here even though this is located in the Venetian hotel. They are pretty much a normal Chinese restaurant in a high end casino hotel. It is also super popular with all the Asian customers at the hotel which are a lot. There is a long line at opening time so the only time I've eaten here is off peak hours. Ok now about the food. The food is really good. Everything I've eaten here is good, borderline great.  This time I ate the paigoo ( boiled pork chop) noodle soup and the wok cooked steak and basil with tomato fried rice. They were both great and delicious and I devoured it all. They charge a lot for tea but the tea is good and it's a perfect compliment to the food which is a little oily. The prices are expensive but it's located in Venetian and if you gamble and room charge you can probably get the charges comped.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic steak with basil and tomato fried rice
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pai Goo noodles- pork chop noodle soup

UrMwvbMV-Mu52gIzkJ55sw.text: Vegas is not the place for Chinese food. Run away from this place. Want a plate of rice doused in MSG and Kung Pao chicken drowned in vinegar? Come to Noodle Asia!  The shrimp fried rice is edible and tastes pretty decent. Has an unhealthy amount of MSG in it though. And the Kung Pao chicken is a lie. Just a plate of chicken cooked in vinegar. It even stinks.   This is just a place for drunk white people. This is not authentic Chinese food. Drunk food for Americans, yes.  Plus the Kung Pao chicken was $19.95. Shrimp fried rice was $16.  Might as well hit the strip for a burger or a bag of chips.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp fried rice ~$17

hpCEGYH5vQm3F3wzSXSvkQ.text: Just a meh. Standard rice and noodle dishes. Nothing great, but not terrible. Would be excellent if you were drunk. The noodles would be the way to go at 2 am to rally for another few hours. Though I doubt you are checking up on yelp for where to eat at 2 am if you are drunk. If you are, then you aren't that drunk. But hey, go with the noodles!

4tcZXHQJNzjMwHgOOu_2uQ.text: Came to eat here yesterday and they were shut down by the health dept. Today we came by and they had 2 letters being displayed from the health dept, an A & C. Def will not be eating here

QegMk9RXMdRBgbo-fr_N8A.text: I went for Pho. Definitely good pho! Service was "eh". Hit and miss. Would go again for sure.

38RMZXqf0T1QUGBs2dxeQQ.text: This place is delicious. Needed to eat while betting on the horses so I ran over. Order the shrimp dumplings, chicken wings and the chicken and salt fish fried rice. It was so good! Will likely return tonight for dinner!

EEU5U_1PAiH89U3g7Po5Bw.text: Chinese food should not be expensive. If you want Chinese food, save your money and get it from China town.  People who say this is authentic, you need to look in a mirror and check your skin color. Because unless you are yellow, you don't know what authentic Chinese food is.   I got the pot stickers and although I liked how they fried the bad boy all the way around. It lacked flavor so the soy sauce was necessary to down these guys.   Now I got the Dan Dan Noodles (spicy peanut noodle) and this shit was disgusting. It tasted as if they mixed greasy oil with old ass peanut butter. Like the peanut butter was spooned from the jar and sat in the the sun for days. I took a few bites thinking it would improve but it just got worst $15 wasted for sure.  I got serious number 4's the following day. Number 4 is explosive diarrhea, like that shit was shotgunned. Please save your time and money and do not eat here.

ZCxl5QNMfm_ETUR10XLYuA.text: Took my parents here for dinner. All four Asian parents all like their dishes! Taste is very authentic and service is equally good! Chicken noodle soup has a slight Chinese herbal taste, the classic canton style. The tomato onion beef rice dish is sooooooo good.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tomato onion beef rice dish. Very very good!

ThohhWQUCEJBnhA6b1zXDA.text: As a Cantonese person I would like to say this place is a good combination of Cantonese noodles and Chinese noodles.  Because they have variations from stir fried beef noodle, to Taiwanese beef noodles, Chinese style dan dan noodle and yun nan soup noodle.  I must say their stir fried beef noodle is one of the best I had in California.  And the dan dan noodle is very flavorful with peanut sauce and a little spiciness that I liked.  My friend loved the beef noodle and he is Taiwanese so I am guessing it is pretty legit.  However the Yunnan noodle lacked in flavor and I would not order that again.

papCmQ1eZfmdu6UW60L-Tw.text: If you are looking for some bomb HK style Chinese food, this place is it.  I love the won ton noodle here!

6aCkKK4KcOVmOAhzFxSX1Q.text: Dim sum at midnight?  Totally normal here... and awesome.  Ordered Har gow, chicken noodle dish, fishball curry and soup.  Food is all great here. Skip the milk tea though.

iw1e49biHfdytOpmpGYuNQ.text: I have stayed at the Venetian at least 3 times and I always look forward to this place! As authentic as it gets! Great food and believe it or not... good service!

f29zJrzkZWP8y-hj5ztzCg.text: Expensive considering this is very average Chinese food. Then again, why wouldn't it because it's in The Venetian. Four stars if price isn't a consideration. Once adjusted for price, I would call this a three star establishment.

PpXee8INtD_hQ_iDL0Qtug.text: Quick bite on arrival.... it was the pepper noodles which were the pick.  Spicy with lots of flavor and the requisite oil.  OK for the place it is .....

dDjuM9bXSVAfBeAb07gaeg.text: Noodle Asia is located in the Venetian. Pretty spiffy Chinese joint.  We ordered Cantonese Beef Stew and Curry Seafood Fried Rice. The beef was tender and seemed like decent quality cuts. A flavorful dish. 5 solid stars. The curry rice was delicious and I don't even like curry much. Booyaa. 5 big fat stars.  Another must try are the shrimp dumplings. Ooooooo. 5 stars.   Most dishes are about 16.00  A good dinner.

rtYRkSWCJTISv2iFhHdiBg.text: Super fast service, they delivered my meal so fast I thought they had delivered me someone else order but it was mine. It was hot and tasty and plenty to eat, prices were "ok", not bad for a sit-down restaurant in a casino, a nice place to eat.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

kOwKmeq8OVutXqPyUzkpDw.text: I came since I was working a tradeshow at the Sands Expo.  The line was always filled with business men due to the tradeshow. I found out that they do order to-go! We skipped the line and ordered via phone. They say they'll call you when it's ready.  But when I checked in 15 minutes, they already had it done! Love it. I'll order to-go again! I had the Singapore noodles. Pretty on par with what I thought it would be.   I actually sat down at the restaurant later in the week.  I gotta say..as an Asian used to Asian service, the customer service is standard for an Asian restaurant. It seems gruff for a Vegas location, but just right for an Asian noodle house. They sit you down, take your order, bring you food, and take your money. That's it. No more, no less. They were so busy during the show.   My friend is on a gluten free regime. She said the beef rice noodles were great!

EYH78-7Dc0jZzENuw-oxWw.text: I gave 2 star based on the taste of the food I ordered. I ordered combination grilled roast duck and roasted pork. Taste was not good at all and it's definitely not worth $18. I am half Chinese and i know what tasty roast duck should taste. Maybe better to order something else, do not order this dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. i would not mind if i pay $18 and it is delicious... but IT IS NOT

EWvMcjQLPofvSU7Af6GvOQ.text: This is the best Chinese restaurant on the strip. My go to place every time I am in town. Perfect for when you are hungry and when you are hungover. Top picks are Beef Chow fun, Wonton in Chili Oil, Spicy Beef Noodle Soup and their Pho is surprisingly good. Definitely recommend this place.

Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wonton in hot chili oil is a must try!

15DYQaLsQWdyK5rOlGyvJw.text: Look no further! Your one stop shop for all things with noodles and hot soups are here!  There I was, laying in my las vegas suite thinking I need some hot noodle soup for this slight hangover...Scrolling through restaurants on Yelp went from seconds, to minutes, to almost an hour!  Then my gf had mentioned this awesome noodle house located in the Venitian hotel.   I was so happy that we had a place to go to fulfill my craving. This place really does the job.   A few things to try -   -chinese broccoli  -roasted duck -Won ton noodle soup (yellow egg noodles) -Pho (rice noodles) -Roasted duck noodle soup (yellow egg noodles) -Spicy seafood soup (thin udon noodles)  Everything tasted really good. No complaints. The hot soup and broth in my belly satisfied my needs.   The only issue was that we had to ask 10x for some lemons....

Gjd0jwpR6RJiOkvxv0bt1w.text: Yes, everything is overpriced but what restaurant on the Strip inside a five star hotel/casino isn't?  Unless you are getting a comped meal, you just expect to be gouged.  So, I will just focus on other aspects.  It's a great place for a quick casual meal or late night snack.  I am not Cantonese so, I can't speculate on how authentic it is but here is what I do when I am eating at an ethnic place.  Who works there?  All Chinese, check.  Who are the cooks?  All look like seasoned veterans, check.  Who eats there?  Many Asians, check.  Passes my test for authenticity.  It's a functional place with some counter space next to the open kitchen and utilitarian tables. Service can be uneven.  I have read other reviews about service neglect but personally I have not experienced what I would consider service neglect in more than half a dozen visit.  Appetizers are overpriced, (I know I said I would try to not to mention price) especially dim sum stuff.  I still love the potstickers.  Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce makes it a nice vegetable side dish.  Hot and sour soup definitely hits the spot every time.  Love the buddha feast pan-toasted noodles and mixed seafood pan toasted noodles.  Both come with generous serving of either vegetarian stuff or seafood.  Overall, while expensive, it's as close to real Chinatown as it gets on the Strip.

Ytn7GZ51R0MexUZqATm7ng.text: Located in the Vinettian this place opens till 3am.  It's a pretty pricy place for Chinese food but I guess if you'd rather eat anything else than sandwiches or pancakes, this is a good alternative.   Food:  Decent.  I got the pho and it was a bit too salty for my taste.  They don't have all the Pho condiments I usually throw in to spicy up my soup but again, I'd rather be eating this at $19 bucks than pancakes.   The Duck was good and the dry noodle dish was also good.    Over all experience was decent.  Service was decent and being open till 3AM def gets another point.

ANTx3RSEnbR2s8QUoVs6nQ.text: Dumplings were ok, not the best I have had Vegetable fried rice had tomatoes in it and didn't taste good had to add hot sauce to eat my food, and let's not talk about the shrimp in lobster sauce. And the service wasn't great

bGAKSeDky7CpkTbLRRJt9g.text: Very good food.  We had many different types of dishes and they were all very good.  I would come back when in Vegas visiting from AZ.  Totally recommend this place.

OJtNWPbtPRddKsAa9_u2DA.text: Noodle Asia is located in the Venetian casino, on first floor near all the slot machines!  The previous day, I was sightseeing, walking through the casino, and NA caught my eye!  They have a menu outside their front doors and I observed it.  Well, I saw that they have Pho!!! I loooove Pho and it is difficult to find in my hometown area.  So right away, I knew I already wanted to come back and try it.  When I got back to my hotel, I read a few Yelp reviews and saw pictures from my fellow Yeeps Ken L and Mike O.   I came back next day, before opening 11am Monday morning.  I got there 15 minutes early and a line was already forming!  I think I was the 4th person and by the time they opened, I am sure there were at least 30 people waiting.  I got the impression that this was a great sign and people in line were ready to get in and order lunch!!  The restaurant is very open area, lots of space, and nice decor.  I liked it very much and felt comfortable seated at my table.  There are lots of tables and I also saw a counter area.   My server came over and took my order.  I still looked over the menu while I was waiting and there are soooo many items on there that I would love to try, but I specifically came back for the "Pho Prime".  OK, this is the most Expensive Pho I have ever bought at $16.95.  I normally pay 7-8$ for a bowl at other places in Nor Cal.  But that being said, I really didn't care about the price, if I want something, I buy it and plus I was on vacation in Vegas... have to Enjoy every moment to the fullest :)  The Pho Prime was Delicious.  It had a great flavor in the broth, lots of meats, lots of noodles, and I enjoyed eating it  BUT, No Hoisin sauce, it didn't come with my plate so I asked for it and my server said they ran out yesterday??  The Pho Prime is a huge bowl too, I could not finish it.  It was definitely worth the price and place!  My server was OK, and she was busy with other tables as well.  I was disappointed I couldn't order a dessert, 3 of 4 choices that I wanted to try on the menu were out!!!  At first I almost didn't believe it lol, like for real?  I really wanted to order the Hawaiian Papaya :/  so I decided not to get a dessert, changed my mind.  Then it took awhile for me to get the bill, I was waiting...  Overall, I had a very good lunch and Yes, I would definitely return!  Considering the location, how much I like the Venetian casino, and all the menu options that I read sounded tasty.  Hopefully, the next time I am in town I can come in and order a big dinner.  This is a great place for couples or groups, plenty of seating.  I left fulfilled and satisfied that I got my Pho ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Under the white lid is ...
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pho Prime $16.95
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Nice big spacious dining area (I took pic early morning before they opened).

QnjYNLiuq8hfcudQ8mO2VQ.text: My third time getting the Szechuan noodle soup and it's still good as prior times. It's $15.00 but always hits the spot after drinking and open till 3 am. Hand made noodles and you can taste the difference. Last night had too much tendon but it was 2:30 in the morning so maybe they were running low. Still a great spot to get some Chinese food

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. szechuan beef noodle soup
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodle soup

wxri6v3s8twXN44mpDVREw.text: Desperate for food was more like it...after walking from Monte Carlo all the way to the Venetian till 2am our party was starving. I was reluctant to have chinese food here in Vegas since Toronto by far till this day has the best Chinese food.  Service was a 2/5, our server seemed a bit snobbish, and was not at all a people-person.  Perhaps its the the "AM" time which was getting to him.  However the female manager who came by to serve our food was very pleasant, and indeed a cutie with a twinkle in her winkle lol.....  I had the night market fried rice 4/5: sliced beef tossed in thai chilli, basil, bean sprouts, and diced tomatos was yumm!! perfect balance of flavors, however the beef slices could have been smaller.  Each slice was half a mouthful lol...  BBQ Pork & Duck Noodle Soup 2/5: Barely any duck, and a few slices of bbq pork, the presentation was great, but honestly not worth it.  Fu Chow Fried Rice 3/5: presentation, taste, and portion was bang on! lots of shrimp, chicken, mushroom, calamari, and scallion gravy...worth it!!  Overall the quality of the dishes were below my expectations.  This restaurant almost seemed like a waste of space that lacked the taste. Sorry Venetian

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_HJlH7gEPjgdV_50fG-BAg.text: This place is the perfect Vegas hangover spot. The soups are like you find in NYC Chinatown.  The wontons the pork and shrimp mix that you don't find normally. Other fantastic dishes Shrimp black bean sauce  Hot braised shrimp Mongolian beef Mixed veggies in garlic sauce Shrimp and choice dumplings.  Chinese broccoli oyster sauce  BBQ duck and pork !!!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fantastic Hong Kong wonton soup. Like New York. Great Vegas hangover medicine !

hk36eB_sbtZ8TCKlZ_eRgQ.text: I have been to Noodle Asia before but never posted pics.  On my most recent visit, I came here about 3 am after seeing Kaskade at Marquee.  We ordered char siu won ton mein - Won ton soup w/ BBQ pork, won ton and noodles.  We wanted duck, char siu and won tons, but they ran out of duck.  The basic soup is $11.95, with a $4 extra charge for won tons.  The soup also comes w/ a little bit of gai lan (chinese broccoli).  The soup was OK.  The broth was a little weak, and the noodles were not that great.  However, after two days of eating American and French food, I needed my Azn fix.  The won ton were OK, but $4 extra for 4 won tons is a little steep.  The ambiance is sterile and the service was OK.  I would come here again for an early am fix.  Yes the food is 2X overpriced, but the rent is high and the convenience of 24 hour place in the Venetian is hard to beat.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Char siu won ton mein - $15.95

faDWUBogcGQdfn8kQm2OjA.text: I mean, it's not baaaad.   My friends and I wanted something hot and soupy to recover after a night out. Since there's not that many Asian food options in The Venetian (we didn't want to venture far), there was a 30-minute wait around noon.   3-stars because I ordered the Snow Cabbage noodle soup with no pork, and it came out with pork............. I had to scoop off all the snow cabbage since the minced pork was everywhere on top. Basically paid $17 to eat plain noodles.   Make sure to double check with your waiter when you order!

-ppOUPOWbdxsqA5tTaREyQ.text: Took a break from gambling and tried this spot for lunch - sat at the bar. The BEST pork dumplings I've ever had... I'm still thinking about them months later! They were just that good.

PoVZIbJm9MD_N13ztpdeVw.text: As it's a restaurant located inside an upscale hotel like the Venetian, I'm not going to complain that the food is overpriced. Why? Because if you're dining inside the Venetian, you should expect to pay double of what you normally pay at an independent restaurant. The inside of this restaurant is really nice though with a "food-court" setup for the tables and chairs.  There is a direct view of the kitchen no matter where you sit. We were worried that our food would take a while to come out since there were so many tables in front of us that haven't gotten their food. However, our entrees came out super fast! The food was piping hot and you can tell it just came off the grill.  But the quality? Definitely not authentic-tasting and lacked flavor. You can always add soy sauce to make it more satisfying. I think the food came off the grill a little TOO soon, almost like the chefs rush through all of their orders and don't have time to season the dishes more carefully.  Bottom line: I wouldn't recommend this place unless you're really hungry and don't mind fishing out extra money to eat sub-par Chinese food.

VBLlG9gMz2r-nnY_Ua6toQ.text: I had Chicken Soup noodle.  It's not good.  I can't believe this  low quality food can be found in Venetian.

UojY5gTlLm_G81TIvd5YxA.text: My go to Asian restaurant when I stay at the Palazzo or Venetian and when I'm hungover to go somewhere and I'm dying of soup. Be prepared to overpay on your meals but expect that anywhere in Vegas. A bowl of pho is $17 or regular soup dishes or congee is around $11-15. Thai tea is not that great. Food wise, I've had better but it's not bad.

aw-LYdtT_SCz84JVv83Wew.text: Omg this place is no longer good . The food is so salty and the cold tripe is disgusting!!!

1fxaZRYVgP4_axCEXeLjTQ.text: Noodle Asia is WAAAAAY overpriced chinese food, but what isn't on the strip of Las Vegas?    The food here is DELICIOUS after night of dancing and drinking at Tao.  The Nightmarket Fried Rice will cut deep into your wallet at $14.95 for a simple plate of fried rice. But it's GOOD!  Some recommendations Seafood Noodle ($16.50), Black Pepper Beef Udon ($14.95), and Szechuan Beef Noodle Soup (13.95) - super spicy!  The service staff is attentive and as quick as possible.  I went late night around 3:30 am and they wanted to leave for the night but let me get my order in and was entirely accommodating.  It's definitely one of those places that you want to make sure you get to go to every time you're in Vegas :)

LfRbXcfyTjTgnL1MSFinRw.text: I have eaten at all the fantastic food Vegas has to offer, love the steaks at Cut and Mastro's, dinner at Mario Battali's but no matter what I eat my favorite is always Noodles Asia!  I will get off the plane and want to come here for my Siu Mai and Szechuan Beef noodle soup.  I can't find anything close to it and I won't even bother to try and make it.  But the yummy chilis, tasty soup broth and those chewy noodles always leaving me wanting more...Vegas is not a trip without visiting Noodles Asia!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodle! I fly to Vegas JUST for this dish!
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan beef noodles are my must in Vegas! Spicy tasty broth and thick udon noodles. I get it every time

Y34l31kBSs8jDaqW-8EjIA.text: 2.5 STARS...  Living in SF all my life and being such a close proximity to a variety of Asian restaurants made me forgot that people in other areas aren't that fortunate. I've come to the conclusion that there is no good AUTHENTIC Asian food on the strip...even if the people cooking it ARE Asian! Ya, GO FIGURE! Don't get me wrong, I LOVE all types of cuisines, but after countless nights of drinking, the best hangover cure is jook, noodle soup, or any type of carbs for that matter!   After the most wildest drunken night at XS, all we wanted was ASIAN comfort food without having to trek outta of the strip. We came across Noodle Asia in the Venetian/Palazzo Directory; it had "Noodles" in it's title, so it was a go!  Normally, you get free tea with your meal at Asian restaurants, but Noodles Asia charges $3.50. It's Vegas afterall, so I digress.  We started with the Jellyfish Salad ($10.95). What we got was a a glob of red-colored jelly fish on a 4-inch diameter plate. The jellyfish had a weird texture...actually it had no texture at all. It tasted like it had been marinating in a bag of chili oil. You know, one of those jellyfish packets you get at an Asian Market for 99 cents?  I ordered the "Beef Noodles" which was technically Beef Chow Fun ($12.95).  Ok, why not just call it that? It was very meh, the noodles  looked mushed together b/c they were over-cooked. And, I thought chow fun was suppose to be flat-WIDE noodles? Ummm, at least they were generous with the beef....  Service: Ahhhh, even though you're paying 2-3x more for the food here, the service NO different than any other hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant. As in, you just get your food fast and then get ignored.   Other than convenience and the fact I was CRAVING Asian food badly, I can't imagine making a point to come back here. But hey, when you're hungry AND hungover, just about anything would do...

cQ0omXZn9ZTe0nF0XhswGA.text: Oh my dear LORD how does such perfect soup exist?!  At 2am, there was a line to get into this noodle house.  And rightfully so!  Situated next to the poker room, it beckoned me..."You know you're starving...and you just won a $600 pot!  You can afford $15 soup..."  I chose Roasted Duck and BBQ Pork Soup.  It was beautiful.  Glistening, fatty duck and lean slices of BBQ pork floating among baby bok choy over thin egg noodles.  Clean, clear, deep-colored broth...not the oily kind commonly found in your average Chinese restaurant.  I enjoyed every slurp, every morsel.  It will now become my post-poker ritual at the Venetian from now on.  Absolute perfection.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Roast Duck and BBQ Pork Soup

DhdPkWN9X_eIeIwYKFiDIw.text: Definitely hits the spot after coming from Lavo or Tao. The soups and the dishes definitely have an authenticity to it that make it feel like you're dining at a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant in Chinatown in LA, NY, or San Francisco. But once you look at the prices and hear the sounds of slot machines start going off in the distance, you quickly realize that the Chinese restaurant you drunkenly stumbled your way into is inside the Venetian, on the Las Vegas Strip.  Though the prices do suck, the food is definitely well worth it and should help sober you up, if you've had one too much to drink. The service can be hit or miss, and luckily for me, the service has been ok each time I've visited here.

NfQDDIooIjyzdr0K8QObcg.text: Very casual place to get a quick bite. I had the noodle soup with roast pork. The broth was great/delicious and it included about a cup of baby bok choi.

HbMwumggFu-zgu6evkuqXA.text: Whoa! Why didnt I know about this place before!? Took a random trip to Vegas this weekend. Lost my friends at Tao so I some how ended up here at the noodle spot and I asked what was the most popular dish. The lady picked out Szechwan Beef noodle soup. And it was damn good! Serious flavor going on here and the noodles were good. Actually came back the 2nd day with my friend and got roasted duck and bbq pork noodle soup. This place definitely hits the spot :)

F04nxnk5ThySPWsK3bj1zQ.text: When you're not sure what time it is, and you need to reload with some carbs and electrolytes while still wearing your PJ's and slippers, or club dress and hat borrowed from someone whose name you can't remember. If one of your fake lashes is barely hanging on, if you're not sure what happened to your other shoe....this is a good place to go.  The service is pretty fast.  It's solid middle of the road fare.  These won't be the best noodles of your life, but they won't kill you.  The service is FAST.  This is not the place for your fancy night out in Vegas, it's where you go because you're hungry and NEED to eat SOON.  Ummm, and you can play Keno at the table.

yGcnl8pGOj6W9pMlOI9l5A.text: I'm a pretty patient person when it comes to food service, but the service here was exceptionally slow.  It was not like all the tables were filled or anything, it was just the service.  It took quite a long time for the waitress to take my order, then a longer time to get my food.  Finally I actually kept track of how long things were taking, and from the time I requested my check till the time I was able to get the check and get out was 20 minutes.  I think the only thing I saw that was quick, was when she finally came to pick up the check from me.

WjxMv-fFXKE6yG8q3iedmg.text: Bland and watery! Not sure how it's possible to get the basic Kung Pao Chicken, Egg Roll and Vegetable Chow Mein completely tasteless but this place did it. We added a ton of soy sauce and chili but that didn't make it more palatable. It's unfortunate as this place is in a great location.

QJmJP7y3hc3PNs7G7k21Sw.text: Had the Szechuan beef noodles. Beef was delicious, but noodles could be softer, tasted a bit raw at first.

RHkXKAxhbUY5Hpii3hO5ew.text: Get the red won tons (won tobs in a spicy sauce) for your appetizer.  We enjoyed them so much we ordered a second one!

-XlJETDYzR7txKqakRu-IA.text: Authentic.  Delicious.  In the middle of the Venetian casino.  Service is friendly, decor is simple, it's really just all about the food.  And very affordable food for its location.  I don't recommend the pan fried dumplings but everything else was delicious!  I could have been in LA Monterey Park Chinatown, this food was so spot-on.  And even the cook staff was Asian.  You know that's a good sign.

j0GadYD51q7ZxtpZq9RLBQ.text: need soup to cure that hangover?? You have a good variety here.  I had the Szechuan Beef Noodle.  It was pretty spicy, but in a good way.  For a meal on the strip, the price point isn't too bad.  The wait staff is friendly and tentative.  They were able to accommodate 10 people pretty easily.  If I'm craving some soup while on the strip, I'll be sure to go back.

ILe_mulwd7u_2AzYAB5Ikw.text: Food was ok. But the service was TERRIBLE. Our waitress lied to us about what our order consisted of. Then when it came out it was of course wrong. When we tried to reorder it they told us the kitchen closed, but their closing time wasn't for another 2 hours. Plus they were still serving other guests! Next, they told us they could remake it, but it'd be very inconvenient for them, since there was no chef. Ok wait... This place has an OPEN kitchen. I can see the cooks!!! And they're cooking!! Anyway... They finally remade it right. But this service was no service at all. They might as well have told me to cook it myself. Assholes. The only reason they're getting 2 stars instead of 1 is because when it was finally made the right way it's wasn't terrible.

Bozs69_H3rSL5_Z70m-yVQ.text: Pretty bad food that's extremely overpriced.  Figured it's not too hard to make pho, and had a hangover to cure... I was wrong, The pho broth was terrible.  Can't believe I have to pay $18 for this bowl, but oh well this is Vegas.  Do yourself a favor and go off strip and any pho place is better than this place at a quarter of the price.  You will get more noodle than you can handle and that's how they justify the price.

2SQSTaNxzfYWA8mGl9LutA.text: We came here only because it was convenient. You know being from San Francisco, it's hard to find better Asian food anywhere else and for such a good price too. So , when we came here, I was not expecting much. I ordered the Spicy Ying Nan Rice Noodle. It came with the thicker rounded rice noodle and the broth was actually pretty good. It had the chili oil in it to make it spicy, but it wasn't the unbearable spicy though. It had this seafood meatball in it. I think it was like shrimp and fish, not sure, but it was good. We also ordered Spicy Beef Tripe, which came cold. I expected it to be warm, but it was still tasty. I only came here once the whole time we were here, but the bf came here two times during our stay. The only thing that I didn't like was the prices, I thought it was pretty pricey just for won ton noodle soup, but hey we're in Vegas,so what do you expect.

Y-5tXkv9cmcRvXKc_QHWcA.text: not a bad place to stop by if you have a noodle craving and ambience is low on your priority list.  food: 4 stars ambience: 2 stars  food is 75% of what i care about, so this place is a 3.5 stars for me.  the next time i'm in Vegas with a growling belly for noodles, i'll push my way through crowds of tourists in 100+ degree heat to get here.  for this reason, and since i can only give integer star ratings, i'll round up to a 4.  i am not factoring in the cost.  it was the last day that the fam and i were in town, and we had to find a quick place to eat before returning the rental car and heading off to the airport.  being chinese, we had a Hong Kong noodle craving, and after agonizing at the greater-than-50% price markup on familiar dishes (compared with tried and True manhattan chinatown prices), we sat down to order four dishes to share:  1.  cantonese beef stew (noodle soup) $11.95 2.  BBQ pork and roast duck (noodle soup) $19.95  3.  Beef rice noodles (wok-tossed noodle) $14.95 4.  Singapore mei fun (wok-tossed noodle) $13.95  we expected the worst, and were pleasantly surprised.  the dishes are all very large, so its best to share/eat family style.  the noodles soups were tasty, with generous porions of BBQ pork and duck pieces.  the wok-tossed noodles were surprisingly authentic-- the Beef rice noodles had a good flavor and the noodles were long and intact, and the pieces of beef were very large.  the singapore noodles were had just the right spice.     can't vouch for the other foodstuffs, but what i had was good and i would go again.  cost is reasonable for the area and the convenience if you're already at The Venetian.

ipeKOjOfjAbLewdpFvQY1Q.text: Pretty good food... pretty authentic its expensive but its vegas so win some money and pay... haha.... I'm really chinese so I can tell you that the food is good but its lacking in MSG. Its not as msg filled as most asian places so it tastes good but not like china-town. Most people should like this...

v59LMAAWwmlpxvZ7yw9xFQ.text: the prices were ridiculous.  i think the place is pretty convenient... and the set-up is quite refreshing. however, the menu lacked a lot of things... i think it was too americanized for me. my friends and i shared multiple dishes... from chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, pan fried noodles with seafood, shrimp fried rice, and beef szechuan soup. now that soup was the best thing we had in our meal. it was so good we ordered another one. the noodles are thick wheat noodles in a sweet but spicy beef broth. the beef pieces were tender and cooked to perfection.   the service was horrible, though. we didn't even order too much from the menu but they couldn't keep up with our orders.

VPGj6jB7ymiwWUNC6A-VfA.text: I had the spicy yin nan rice noodle. Friends has the beef noodle soup and wonton noodle soup and the food was good. The prices are expensive if you compare them to back home. But for Vegas, it's considered cheap. I'd definitely be back here to eat, hit the spot.

1Wzis3z4_X0p3xt68jEiPQ.text: I eat Dim Sum every sunday in california so when i came across this returant and saw they had dim sum the weekend I was there I desided to try it and wow it was the best I ever had. I am not sure how their other food is but if you get a chance to eat there on a weekend try the Dim Sum and try the duck. it is amazing!

2AZSodl2VaCSGVhpRHDPxA.text: We came here on our first night in Vegas, as we were staying at the Venetian.  The food was cheap (for the Strip), and the quality the same.  We got a variety of dim sum items incl. bbq pork, some noodles, and won ton soup I think.  I remember the food not being particularly fresh, and perhaps even a bit cold.  Definitely not up to par for a Bay Area palette, but why'd I come to Vegas to eat "Chinese" food anyway?

0a_omu0x0sRSfhep0pXT_Q.text: This actually is impressive tasting food. The noodles were good. Had Singapore noodles, Beef Chow Fun, Crispy Chicken Wings, Shrimp Fried rice. All were very delicious. Yes, it is expensive, but really a good choice if you don't want to venture very far from the casino or from your hotel and have a craving for some good Chinese. Because most of the dishes are family style, this is great for groups.

yQHn0GPfWPSxGOlhdZDkLQ.text: Without a doubt, one of the best values (hah, clearly a relative concept) in all of the new strip -- and probably some of the best non-designer food to be had there as well.  Although I was very dissapointed in the dan dan noodles (very soupy), the potstickers and the Singapore mei fun were super yummy.

QBFddnQmQOFXrYyXCqUslQ.text: not one of the best Chinese cafes I've been too, but i always come here and eat when i stay at the Venetian or come here to play poker. its either packed or empty. just don't try to get a seat when its dinner break form the poker tournament (7-830pm) during big events. i always get the BBQ pork on rice. that is actually very good there. the jelly fish is not bad. my friend only gets the szechwan spicy noodle.   -fast service when not busy  -don't expect 5 star service. its a Chinese cafe not a seafood restaurant  -open late  -right beside the sports bar so you can watch the games  -right beside the poker room  -I've had better but I'm Chinese so ill still come here when there's nothing to eat  -you can get connected from your room and put in an order for pick up

yhDtZuZlhB_sYBVkvD90Cw.text: awesome food at great prices! open sooooo late, like chinatown!

JjYEzvgbEN83OeerPdkIhA.text: This place is on the first floor in the Casino next to sport bar/betting area. You can find this place if you cross the bridge from Treasure Island and go down the elevator and enter the first doors you see to the left.  This is pretty cheap compare to other place on the strip. Expensive compare to places like Chinatown. I had the shrimp fried rice and wanton noodle soup. It was good. But I have to admit I've had better but still very good. I would come back to this place. I wish I could of try other noodle soup.

t6ue-FYbuxkO5S7rzvEFtw.text: Make sure to get the Red Won Tons.  Food here is pretty good overall.  There is always a long line which is a good sign.  It's not that bad of a wait, so stick it out.  Stir-Fried Chinese Greens of the Day is excellent and I always get the Dan Dan Noodles.  Extra spicy.... Every time I'm in Vegas, we always go here at least once.....

PQyF0ALtA2QBKCFx-j4ldw.text: My dan dan noodles should've been called bland bland noodles.  My friends won ton's soup was no different that the one's you can get at your local chinese restaurant.  The service was slow although it was not busy at all.  Nothing special about this place, but I guess it's convenient if you're staying at the Venetian and you want Asian food.. otherwise this place was a big BLAH!

mSOjb8D8ovIDGajJv13Bzw.text: this place is ok. nothing has ever been bad, just rather eat somewhere else. but if you've been gambling too much and just need some quick cheap asian food... noodles asia isnt bad!

qd_BgWV8WZoSmMezHGLqBA.text: Terrible, hands down worst service ever, the place has a cheap feel and the food will make you run for your hotel room almost immediately.

p_mkOQVAei98D4THzbtI5w.text: Absolute heaven! Come to this place to get a break from all the bland buffet food available on the strip. The Szechuan Beef Noodle soup is absolutely DELICIOUS! Not quite as good as what I can get in Taiwan - but comes pretty close. The pineapple seafood fried rice is pretty tasty also. I definitely recommend this place for anyone who can appreciate good, authentic Chinese food.

Ty8QWWC5oRPuX9fxqw8fIQ.text: went here for dinner, plan to come back :)  most of my friends got the schezuan beef noodle soup. but my stomach was feeling weird so i ordered porridge, but the porridge was pretty good too, so i was stil happy :) :)  i tried some of my friend's soup, and it is veryyy spicy but flavorful :9 next time i go, i am totally getting that.  porridge was pretty filling. it's really not that different from any other porridge you get from chinese restaurants. it had it's own flavor, but i wanted a bit more so i added some soy sauce. it was only $11 too :)  service wasn't great. i ordered fish porridge and my friend ordered beef porridge. they brought it over saying "fish" but it was beef. so i gave it to my friend. then another waiter came saying "beef" and it was beef again. so he took it back. a different waiter brought my fish. and then the previous waiter came back with another fish haha. so yeah, their communication between themselves obviously isn't great :T   a lot of waiting involved. like 30 (maybe more) minutes of waiting in line outside. and waiting for a long time for our food after ordering :T sucked because we were starving! so don't go if you don't have time and also if you're really hungry... you will wait A LOT.

jH-0O6P9oKYsynJ_fWxm0g.text: Very bland food that was probably marked up 500%.  I'd take Panda Express any day over this place.

qHGooFe7iYztGrk5TV3NGg.text: For a chinese person like me, this place is blah.... I definately had better. It is definately over priced, but hey, we're in Vegas and it's in the Venetian so what can I say. I know we all sometimes want that late night fix and noodles always sounds good and Noodle Asia is the only noodle place that i know of and it opens late. Vegas really need a 24 hour pho restaurant. I dont know about the "Pho at the coffee shop" in Treaure Island, it just doesnt sound good.

HafoJnJQhjjZdt8_ix7edg.text: We got to Venetian at 1:45AM. Glad Asia Noodle was still open. Had the shrimp pot stickers and Szechuan beef noodles. The rich spicy taste of the soup was perfect for my palate. Great place to go for a late night food craving!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hungry after a long flight from NY. Open until 3am

3Hbycr1W4Wj_JvlBLY9PWQ.text: The service here is very slow. They take time to take your order. Also do not have many servers here to help us out. We loved the curry chiken fried rice.

aFv6bmVx6AA6LsrJJ39eng.text: I came to this restaurant on friday lunch with my cousin and it was disappointing.. With service and food!  We were craving Asian food so much and we were staying Venetian so it was close and looked pretty nice!   We ordered chef's special both were noodles  My cousin's food came out super quick but it took forever for my food to come out to the point where my cousin finished her food and still didn't come out. We asked the waitress to check our food and we still had to wait for another 15mins. Finally my food came out and before I even finished, waitress came by and gave us the check and asked me if i need a box for my food when I'm not even done eating so I thought that was pretty rude.   Overall food was okay and they need more improvement on the service.

YKr4rs2iITcvw1a4PmF8qw.text: Ordered carry out around dinner time at this place over Panda Express and was super disappointed. Got the fried soft noodles, pot stickers and Kung pow chicken. All were underwhelming and over priced.

pVS258GvSxbQh-jJczw8eA.text: This place is great!  It's right next to the sports book with a glass wall so you can see the games but be shielded from the noise and smoke.   The food is authentic, flavorful and filling. My husband I got an order of potstickers, a fried rice dish and a cup of soup and left stuffed for a reasonable price ($34) to boot.   Service is quick and it's a quick moving place but I'm so glad we stopped in. If you like Asian food this is your spot.

jN5uU1ZeXQdAul886PRkwA.text: I live in LA where the Asian food is cheap and awesome.   So of course compared to that,  this place would be very disappointing.   Perhaps it's unfair to rate them so low.   After all,  I am Asian and had only the best Asian food.    Still,  it's hard to give them a better rating when a simple standard dish such as Mapo tofu and Hot and sour soup was horrid.  Soup was overly sour and the Mapo tofu had no taste.   It just tasted like tofu with cornstarch cooked into it.  No flavor.  None.  Maybe some salt?   The crispy noodles and Mongolian beef was decent.   I added an extra star because these two dishes were borderline food court level.   The shu mai dimsum appetizer was also decent but nothing special.  $9 for 6 pieces.    Every dish was around $15+ but that's because it's inside a hotel.   All the cooks and servers were Asian.  Service was Asian like.   That means it was below average.   Don't expect superb food,  ambience or service here.   If it weren't for my father in law wanting to give this place a try,  I'd rather go eat at Panda express.

USBOhtlm7vfZBqR3vZv7yg.text: This is my go-to when I'm staying at the Venetian (which is most of my trips to Vegas). My boyfriend and I love this place for their beef noodle soup and have brought our friends with us. What we've learned is that Noodle Asia is only good for their beef noodle soup. Anyone who has ordered anything else got meals that were average or less than average. So now we make sure that those who go there only order their beef noodle soup. Don't try to get fancy or anything. Beef noodle soup or bust. It is pricey because you're on the strip, so go to Chinatown down the street if you want something cheap.

CVrlmEYbg8SPjg1OawLoZg.text: Awesome food, great service. Large portions. Possibly one of the better joints in Venetian

5rmV-ME90Bw-VbrU_G_hsQ.text: Huge mistake. I figured such a classy looking place would have a real chef and not rely on MSG. I ate the soup For a while and it was literally like eating a bowl of hot water and MSG  Now I'll have to deal with the headache.

h1xVvKu_eYtYaI8P-tU-eA.text: Very pleasantly surprised....it was good! I had a black bean crispy noodle with beef...a little spicy and very tasty....the portions were very generous.  Ordered a won ton mein for my husband...again, generous portion and tasted very authentic...meaning, like the kind of Chinese won ton mein we eat at home... People were nice and prices seemed to be fair.

DjmRSv54_gN9_qoS4xXqTg.text: Consistently good! You must stop and eat at this place. I eat her every time I'm in Vegas hands-down my favorite Chinese food. Located inside the Venetian Casino level.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bar

DL_Ltu4alHLBhMxX5QywRg.text: After days and days of burgers in Las Vegas, we were a bit tired of it and wanted something Asian (we actually missed Asian food soo sooo much!!)  We came across this restaurant by accident but when my parents' friends saw it, they immediately decided to have dinner there. They said they really wanted a hot bowl of noodle soup. There wasn't a lineup so we got seated really quickly. It took them a while to bring us tea. In fact, my dad had to ask the waiter for it. I wouldn't say the waiter was super friendly and attentive. While he was taking our orders, he was just looking at other tables, which I find was unprofessional.  The menu has a big variety of dishes ranging from congee to noodle soup, from fried rice to dim sum, etc. It took me a little while to decide what I wanted because there were a lot of dishes that I like. I finally decided to try their Cantonese Beef Stew Noodle soup (). My sister ordered their Fish Filet congee () because she wasn't feeling well and congee is easier to digest. My mom ordered their Snow Cabbage with Enoki Mushroom and Fried Tofu Noodle Soup (). My dad and my parents' friends all opted for their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup (). I wanted to order the beef noodle soup but I was scared it would be too spicy so I didn't get it. My Cantonese Beef Stew Noodle soup () came with wonton noodles (also called wanton mee). Some people, like my mom, dislike the flavor of this kind of noodle but I'm fine with it. I liked how the texture of this noodle is firmer and thus, chewier. The dish came with only 2 baby bok choy... I definitely would enjoy more vegetables here. The beef stew was flavorful but it wasn't the best I've ever had. I didn't like the fact that half of my portion of meat was just fat. I was expecting more tendons and meat for the price I paid (pay $15 USD). They also cut the meat in small pieces, which made it seem like there were a lot of mean in this bowl.   My sister's Fish Filet congee () congee was pretty good but definitely not worth the price considering the amount of fish filet she had. It was just a decent bowl of congee but nothing too special about it.  My mom's Snow Cabbage with Enoki Mushroom and Fried Tofu Noodle Soup () was.... I don't even know how to describe it. It definitely didn't look like what she had imagine! It looked really messy with enoki and cabbage all spread out and floating around... It originally came with wonton noodles but since my mom doesn't like this kind of noodle, she exchanged it for Lai Fun (). This bowl of noodle soup didn't taste bad but definitely not worth its price considering there wasn't a piece of meat and all the ingredients are not expensive at all...  It seems like their Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup () is a must there but you will be quite disappointed, especially if you've had the beef noodle soup from Asia or Taiwan before! It is just not comparable!! It was tasteful but still lacking flavor as compared to any of the beef noodle soup restaurants in Taiwan. I highly suggest anyone to visit Taiwan because this country is a food heaven!  In short, there aren't many Asian restaurants on Las Vegas Strip, if you are tired of Panda Express and would like something classier (conveniently located inside The Venetian Hotel, on the same level as their casino and beautifully decorated) and more expensive, Noodle Asia is the place to go! I don't think the price justified the quantity and quality of their food but it was nonetheless a satisfying meal for us.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fish filet congee
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Snow cabbage with enoki mushrooms and fried tofu noodle soup
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechwan beef noodle soup

jfJ9EtRwWlseaIp6sLGkQw.text: I was so pleasantly surprised by this place. I went to Vegas with a few friends and one of them really wanted to go here. I saw the name of the place and thought to myself... really? Noodle Asia?  Good thing I gave it a shot. My boyfriends and I weren't super hungry so we ordered an order of egg rolls and we split a BBQ Pork and Roast Duck noodle soup. Honestly I wasn't expecting much, but this place was pretty good. The broth was toned down for the American clientele, but it was still flavorful and rich. The BBQ Pork and the Roast Duck were so yummy. The egg rolls were just okay, nothing out of the ordinary.  I will definitely be eating here again. I mean, you know the place is good when you go to an Asian restaurant and all you see are Asians eating there.

gy7G8BHfLdG3j4ZPnCowRg.text: One nice bowl of soup is all you need to forget all the money you just lost at the poker table.  And the roulette table.  And the craps table.  And the goddamn spin-the-wheel.  At least that's what I tried to tell myself.  I sat down, table for one (sigh) and ordered the BBQ pork and Roast Duck Noodle Soup and a nice, big, free glass of water and watched the World Cup on the big screens in the sports betting pit.  The water was worth every penny.  So was the soup!  By the time I left Noodle Asia, the bowl looked much like my wallet: bereft of anything holding value.  Will definitely do this again, but I seriously hope I don't do what preceded this meal again.  But I know I will.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The BBQ Pork and Roast Duck Noodle Soup did not disappoint.

qtJimQNH6fcV42gs5yUQlg.text: The place is nice and the service was good. Keep in mind they werent really busy. I liked the food but you get the feeling something is missing on the flavor. Only tried their noodle dishes, didnt try their soups

LrQFOgyCDfk6ui2XPlpp5A.text: Service was good. The prime rib pho (around $17) and Szechwan beef noodle soup (around $13) were both delicious. The noodles in the beef noodle soup was probably the softest and smoothest noodles I've had. Not sure I would come back though due to the price which was the reason a star was knocked off. However, it was good to experience this place once.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechwan beef noodle soup was delicious.

ZxZyHeyX9XFZsxROxqzJAw.text: Omg!!! I'm so amazed that this place isn't crazy busy with a line out the door. It tasted authentic as *uck!  Four words: Szechuan spicy beef noodle.   That is all.   Your welcome.   Do it!!!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Slurp that spicy sticky broth...don&#39;t be shy.
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Szechuan spicy beef noodle is heaven on earth.

DrENnfML5b_za98eb2ZclA.text: Best Chinese food I could find on the strip. You can tell it's legit by the fact everyone working there is Chinese and in particular the cooks in the back. It doesn't really Americanize the food the way many of the other nice casino Chinese places do.  The snow cabbage noodle is pretty good. The sichuan beef noodle is excellent -- very spicy but also quite authentic. The bbq pork and duck on rice is great though on the salty/saucy side of things.  Price is a tad higher than what you'd pay in the suburbs of most Chinese-populated areas but hey, it's Vegas and in a casino so overall I was pretty happy with the value.

Pr8srLpRizjn2gKfDEQRww.text: Someone else paid, so this 2 star has nothing to do with their ridiculous prices - yes they're pricey because it's on the strip and they can get away with it.   The menu mostly consists of noodle soups, stir fried noodles and fried rice. Besides that, they have less than 10 main dishes to choose from, and it's pretty much only the standard things my white friends always order - beef/chic broccoli, orange beef/chic, mongolian beef, etc.   We did a bunch of stuff for 6 family style. Things that were good: nothing. Things that were decent: fried rice, hot braised shrimp (aka sweet sour shrimp), siu mai. Things that were crap - everything else we ordered. Pass on the following: pot stickers, beef curry stew, kung pao chicken, mongolian beef, orange chicken, egg roll/spring rolls. Food was bland, and nothing "spicy" actually was despite the presence of chili peppers.  If you insist on staying here to have asian food, you can probably get comparable quality stuff for less from the panda express type place at the food court - think it's called wasabi jane?  It probably even includes mediocre fried rice and a stale egg roll with your meal. Or if you want a sit down experience, Zine at Palazzo is priced slightly more, but with a much better menu. I'm not a huge fan of their food either, but if you really must do overpriced chinese food at this hotel, Zine is the one to go for.   An asian food court is supposed to open at Palazzo off the casino floor eventually, so it's nice to know there are potentially better options coming soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork pot stickers 6 for $9 - big but w too thick wrappers. Was more like an empanada than dumplings
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Siu mai - pork, shrimp &amp; mushroom dumpling 6 for $9
Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kung pao chicken $18.50 - the theme in this place is bland food, which isnt spicy when its supposed to be. Pass

qHVpaMKZdGBs0aQQEx390Q.text: In Las Vegas there's nothing like a hot bowl of fresh noodles to top off a night of drinking partying and gambling.  I wish it was as good as some of the best noodle places in Chinatown and LA but it isn't.  Plus a star because there really are no other alternatives and I'd take their beef noodles any day out here in stony brook.    Make this part of your Vegas weekend.

j_mRprakXXV2Kq34M_gPbw.text: Service is terrible. Don't pay with cash they expect the change to be tip. Ordered roast duck and they didn't have it, which I wasn't informed of and still waited 45 minutes for it. F*ck this place

VM2qSKb5A9uQNsPhh3YfIw.text: Had the fish filet congee and beef stew soup.  Everything was below average.  Not horrible just below average.  The beef was the only thing that was good.  Tender and nicely seasoned.

M8CopL_dugnMjFbkRfEhEQ.text: This place is such a hidden gem. A must for locals and tourists. Every time I have been there it was great service with outstanding food. Make sure and as for the coconut. They have a ton of things you can order that are not on the menu. I can't really say I have on favorite dish because they are all good. They are open late and has a cool atmosphere especially if you are out late on the strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States

uLBMzFNI7FRh6CMQRBsUHQ.text: This restaurant is located inside Venetian hotel casino.  Having eaten in Hong Kong and Singapore at some of the best restaurants there, I would say that the chefs here are among the top chefs.  Try their beef noodle soup, this place makes the best beef noodle soup.  Sometimes it is a bit salty, just add a little red vinegar and it will taste better.  I would recommend you try the spicy wonton appetizer, Mongolian beef and scallion, wonton noodle soup (pay an extra $9-$10 to add the BBQ pork).  If you are vegetarian, try their stir fried string bean.   It is pricey, but don't forget that you are in Vegas.  $10 may not be enough for one hand of Black Jack, but it can buy you a good bowl of noodle.

9VaJSaAVqwT-qdqqsnIjKg.text: This place is okay. It's inside of the Venetian (in the casino by the slot machines) so it's worth it if you're really craving a quick bowl of noodle soup and don't want to make the trip to Chinatown. It's a little pricey-the noodle soups will run you about $15 per bowl, but you're paying for the convenience of the location. Ambiance is nice and casual. It's open to the casino and you can see/hear the slot machines going.  Food: It's okay, nothing spectacular. Been here a bunch of times and always get the same dishes: wonton noodle soup, Cantonese beef stew, veggies. Usually everything tastes fine, but on this last visit the broths were very bland, almost tasteless.  Service: Surprisingly subpar for a restaurant located inside of the Venetian. In the past it's been quick and decent, so maybe they were just having an off day. I can certainly understand service being a little slow when it's super busy. But this last visit to Noodle Asia was not during a rush, maybe about 8 tables were full. Service was very very slow. Asked for some extra chopsticks and had a pair LITERALLY thrown onto the table by the waiter who couldn't bother to walk an extra foot. Getting the bill was also an endeavor and took probably 15 minutes. The other tables were experiencing the same frustration too, I could hear the table next to us loudly complaining about how long it was taking.  I'm sure we'll be back though because it's convenient. Hopefully food and service will be better next time.

OWXzmLD0g2QQuiQ6Mi8fmw.text: I'm a local, and I was looking forward to this because I had walked by several times in the past, and the place always looked busy.  I ordered the pork and century egg congee, it was disappointing!  The egg pieces tasted moldy, and I had had this before in other places, and the century egg did not taste like this.  I ordered lemon because i like eating it with congee, and the server gave me lime instead.  Not the same thing!  Service was not that attentive. Sorry, I definitely would not recommend this restaurant.

ghOBiWDOvQRT7FSq8QaC_A.text: Okay now this place is really good!..Fresh ingredients, never crowded and open till 3:00 a.m. I will admit not every dish is unbelievable, bit i've tried many things here and i can only say that the egg drop flower soup or whatever ya call it, was a bit bland, but that kind of soup is bland anyway. And the beef or pork chow fun was a little to greasy for my pallet. other than that, the crispy toasted pan fried noodles with seafood or beef are great. As is the Singapore em fun..Big noodle soups ya can't go wrong like the brisket curry noodle soup...Anyway, when you're on the strip and want some good chinese, stop in the Venetian and check this place out..Oh yea, a bit pricey, but hey, it's in the Venetian...

hYfcLOlj6La63ao8GY7xvA.text: This was just okay. We ordered a bunch of dishes buddha feast noodle with soft noodles, black peppered beef udon, greens, red won ton, and minced beef over rice. I really liked the red won tons and the minced beef over rice but the noodle dishes were just so so. Nothing really special and really lacked flavor.   Convenience is why they're still packed with people but if you can make the trip, I'm sure anywhere in chinatown (just down the street) would be better.

KohwsI7BhCo5cR0ovxe5Hw.text: Too bland for my tastes.  The kimchi wasn't even spicy.  Nice place to sit, good service though.

oO_MikPLAnfDaLytoJA7mQ.text: Wherever you live in the world, when you're inebriated at 2-5AM and need some sustenance to absord your liquid-filled belly, you probably stop by a local, cheap, tasty, and fatty hotspot to get your fill and make it home in one piece.  In Vegas, after you're done partying at TAO (the best nightclub in Vegas) at the Venetian, your option is Noodle Asia. Open 24 hours a day, it has very good Chinese food of all sorts.   - Dim sum, check. - Noodles of all variety (cold/hot, dry/wet, veggie filled/pork/chicken/beef/sauced up), check. - More rice plate choices than grains of rice on your plate, check.  So what's not to like? Oh, just the $13-20 prices for a plate of quality Chinese food you can purchase at any local Chinatown for $5-7.  But when in Vegas / on vacation.... go to Noodle Asia to sober yourself up after TAO.

sHNoRyJ8D4iDqgEwIdaspw.text: Hot chinese or vietnamese food while in vegas can be very refreshing!  Service is not great, but food is good and prompt delivery...I'd still come back for more.

DRm3YbZadMlaJbSi_wu1BA.text: Overpriced Asian food.  I had the Schewan beef noodle soup- the beef I didn't care too much for (personal preference), but the noodles were good. Service was friendly, but due to construction right outside the restaurant, make sure you're seated further inside so you don't have to listen to drilling noises.  I think for the few extra dollars you pay here, you're better off spending them on the slots!

LaritNZBlFzUhKuUBKAu_w.text: It was a very disappointing dining experience. There was a long line for this restaurant (and decent reviews on Yelp), which is usually a promising sign, but the food was really terrible. One of the dishes I ordered was the famous beef noodle soup that other reviewers wrote about, but the broth was heavily dilated with water and there was no flavor at all. After the lunch, all four of us felt the effect of MSG in the food. Compared to all the other wonderful meals we had in Vegas, this one turned out to be a huge mistake.

1rx4BNQ5Nk9eAU3PW7aaNw.text: Ok if you are hungry,  hit and sour soup was bad,  I like the duck n bbq pork noodle,  ph was bad,  special beef noodle was bad as well,  salty, this place doesn't have consistency on their cooking,  one day it taste less,  next day it's salty,  weird,  but the rice was good,  seafoods pan fried noodle was so so, but don't expect the same everyday.  I gave 3  because it's inside the hotel, we eat quickly then went to gamble lol. It's cheaper compare to others restaurants inside palazzo and venetian

O-ZghglqZiWjG4iDGNc1oA.text: Waiting for nearly an hour before the food was served. All we ordered was simple: fried rice and noodle soup! Even the restaurant was packed, an hour wait for food is still not acceptable.

1A6rb2kNh13_LoHSB9yx5A.text: Food was not good if you are vegetarian and service was bad. I will not recommended any vegetarian here.

BBXcozMkAIcs7IDmiulcrg.text: For a 5 star hotel, the value of this restaurant is very very high.  Decent enough food (if you don't want to taxi to China town where the real Chinese food located ), this is a good options.  Nice environment.  Great service5 stars ! Food is 3-4 stars. Price is 5 star for Venetian.  Will be back !

QGF17TURRn80-kPHl3AzGw.text: A great place to eat after your drunken night of partying, Noodle Asia is open late and offers a variety of hearty warm dishes that are somewhat overpriced, but that taste REALLY GOOD when you're drunk.  After a long night of drinking and partying with my group of friends at TAO, we stopped by here to grab food. I ordered a Spicy Ying Nan Noodle soup bowl which consisted of vermicelli and shrimp enveloped in a scrumptuous chicken broth with Ying Nan chili paste, scallions and cilantro. The broth was fresh, and overall, it wasn't too spicy. The noodles were smooth and tasted great when they slid down my alcohol ravaged throat. Although the dish was slightly overpriced at $14, it tasted good and believe it or not, I would come back again to try out some of the other dishes!  This place is good for large groups and it is an excellent choice if you happen to be staying at the Venentian.

photos.caption: Photo of Noodle Asia - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Ying Nan Noodles

smBZc5a11Efr3VX9jzV9Rg.text: Came here when I was in Vegas, was pretty disappointing to be honest. All the reviews said "authentic Chinese food" and "best Chinese food on the strip" and all I remember was how disappointing it was.  First off, the location is near the betting areas so I guess you get to watch some sports while waiting in line. The problem is you'll be waiting in line for a long time, at least for lunch. We waited nearly an hour to get in and then another hour to finally get our food.  I ordered the Szechwan Beef Noodle Soup based on everyone's reviews. They made it seem like it was amazing but it was just... okay. The soup was strong in flavor, but the noodles were ordinary and the meat was tender yet bland.  Overall, it was pretty average. The food was decent, but the wait really ruined it for me.

BIG7-M625NKBqEckhRtwkA.text: Pretty good Chinese place for Vegas. We wanted to get an inexpensive but good meal and decided to give this place a try. It's located right in the middle of the casino, which was interesting. Saw lots of Asian patrons so that made me feel better! Haha  Food comes out super fast.  Ordered the curry noodles with bbq pork and shrimp, it was DELICIOUS! Portion size was good for $13 bucks. Also ordered a glass of chardonnay for $7. My friend got a beer and the crispy pan fried noodles.  Overall a great place for a quick bite that won't break your wallet.
